reviews.review: fabulous. Stunning park, great views, incredible churches and monuments and a good walk. Would have been good to take a guided tour.

Great view without all the tourists at Prague Castle. Take either the metro or the tram (or walk) from the city center to have a great walk with a nice view over the city! Not so crowded as prague castle, so this offers a great break. The graveyard at the top is also interesting, a lot of great people from prague rests there.

Easily my most favorite place in Prague. A bit far from the main tourist attractions, Vysehrad offers the tranquility of a beautiful park. It's a fortified hill with small museum, church, and a cemetery where famous Czechs were buried. A pilgrimage for Alphonse Mucha would not be complete without a visit to Vysehrad. The tombstones were amazing (and some were even funny). The entrance to the park is free, but you need to pay for the museum/exhibition. Do not miss the beautiful view of the city and the river from up the fortress!
Avoid crowds, visit Vysehrad. Enjoy long walk, great views and nice church. In a cold day grab some hot wine. Very nice and well preserved old fortress, no crowds
Beautiful Park. The Park is located close to a metrostop and the Crongress Center. It has several attractions, including a beautiful church and a cemetary, and great views of Prague.

Peaceful morning walk. Visited the Vysehrad grounds around 9:00am on a weekday morning. This was the perfect time to do so as we were mostly alone to walk the medieval walls and ruins, taking in the ridiculous views of downtown Prague and the river. Walking through the Slavin cemetery is a must for anyone interested in Czech history. By 11:00 the tour groups began filling the area. Still, the views, history, greenery are well worth a visit any time--just a short walk from Hotel Union Prague.
Vyšehrad fortress and famous cemetery, called Slavín. wonderful view on Prague and Moldau river. Many monuments from Czech history to see incl. basilica St. Peter and Paul
Atmofphere of elds. Beautiful place, really old and mystical. Amazing views to Prague and the river Vltava, lots of green everywhere, great atmosphere.

Must see. If you stay in Prague than Vysehrad is a must see location. Very peacefull and quiet place, beautifully decorated parks and one of the most beautifull church you'll found here. Amazing views. You can take a walk or relaxing. You don't need money to visit Vysehrad.

Wonderful city views. This is a great place to get away from the crowds and enjoys some sights of the city. There's a lovely old cemetery with lots of famous people, a church and other architecture, as well as some very pleasant garden walks. Easy to get to on the Metro and well worth a visit.
Great for romantic relaxing walks. We were staying not far from here and our host recommended visiting Vysehrad. very lovely place with great views for a relaxing romantic walks

A great break from a conference at the convention center. While attending a meeting at the convention center, I did a search for nearby things to see. This was a gem. Old architecture, a lovely Basilica, The fort walls, views of the river, an art gallery and the museum were all educational and well maintained. The grounds and the battlements are lovely for a stroll.

Amazing views. Loved this place. The walk was amazing and the views of the river and church are just mesmerizing. It's quiet and not filled with tourists. It was also very interesting to walk thru the cemetery.

Must see. The monument is within the surrounding of St. Peter and St. Paul church. Nice view of Prague. The cemetery is so historical with well known Czech heroes buried in this monument. It is a walking distance from subway station.
Great walk.. Great walk with many sculptures and we'll kept gardens. Now security is strict. Quiet after the castle crowd.

Good quiet place to get away from the crowds. We had researched places to visit in Prague away from the tourist mob. This attraction is worth a visit. There are numerous interesting attractions on the grounds. There is no admission fee.
The location is on the bluff of the river so you can have a good view of the city and river.
Worth the walk. Vysehrad and its ground were worth the 30 minute walk! The grounds are quiet and beautiful and offer fabulous views of Prague.

Spend a few hours away from the crowds. We spent several hours walking around the grounds of Vysehrad, away from all of the crowds of tourists elsewhere in Prague. Although there were a few tour groups, the area is so large that we mainly just saw locals walking their dogs or strolling with children. There are multiple points of interest from various periods in Prague's history and beautiful views of the city. It is located a few subway stops out of the Old Town, near the convention center, but is worth the distance to spend some relaxed time outdoors.

Nice side of Prague. If you want to get another view of Prague but much less touristy, here is the place. The place is so tranquil and scenic. Stop at the Beer Garden to enjoy the scenery of whole Prague accompanied with very reasonable beer and food. Recommended if you have extra days in Prague.

Disappointed after a long walk uphill. We climb up the stairs to visit the place. It was a long, hard climb , up a long flight of steps. Was disappointed with the place, not grand , nor unique. Just normal. The most impressive is the Bascillica Minor, dedicated to St Paul and St. Peter but you have to pay to visit the inside. Many came to visit the cemetery , possibly paying respect to relatives or just to have a look. From here you can proceed to see Rotunda of St. martin. Then visit the garden.
A Beautiful Stroll. This was a cool and relaxing stroll with some awesome views of the city and river. The Basilica had a small fee (I think around $2)

Worth a visit away from the crowded old town. Vysehrad is a nice place, an old fortress with a cathedral, an old building from the 11th century (unique in Prague!) and a cemetary where you can find the tombs of Dvorak and Smetana and other important Czech cultural figures, When you want to spend some time away from all the tourist groups in the city center, I recommand this place. Easy to get there by metro.

Lovely tranquil visit. We did this on our last day and it was an absolutely lovely way to end our trip! If you want to get away from the crowds (and other places can get quite crowded) this is the way to do it. Far less travelled and full of locals. The basilica is stunning with lots of wall paintings and the park is big and lovely for a stroll round.

Beautiful location. There are beutiful views of Prague from the top of the monument. There is also a beutiful cathedral that you can go into. We got there as they were closing so we couldn't go in, but peeking through the windows, it looked amazing. Kind of off the beaten path, so it is not nearly as crowded as some other sites. well worth a visit.

Night visit . Tranquil environment, a fortress. The view was good just unfortunate that I went on a drizzling evening. It offered an overview of the city including the river but it was too far away the castle district for a nice night view

Impressive fortress....and free from tourist hordes. Great views over the river. We ambled round the walls, enjoying the changing prospects. It can be easily reached by about 5 tram routes, then a gentle walk up.
A Hidden Gem. Beautiful walk in the park with hardly anyone around, truly a hidden gem. Beautiful cathedral and surrounding grounds, take a look if you have extra time in Prague.

Picnic . A excellent place to relax carry your basket sleep in the garden and soak in the place , it has a majestic view of the expanse of city and you could walk down on the river side where a walk on the promenade of Danube is excellent , we had lovely experience of local bands playing jazz , index rock and rock by the time you have walked thru the promenade soaking the local ethos you will be having a smile on your face as you meet the local non tourist population which is a blessing believe me .Suggest a must even Rick Steve missed on this one  Enjoy it

Interesting.. Not as many visitors as other parts of Prague but worth the effort to go. Interesting history and stunning views of the river from the walls. Free entry but there is a charge for the church. Small café on site.

Not that well known, but definitely worth to visit. This site was always a rival the Prague Castle since 10th Century, even before. Now you will find here a nice Cathedral, magnificent view over the city and a cemetery with important Czechs. The park around is very beautiful, too.

A fortress with a beautiful church. We went there on sundown and the view was spectacular. We were able to see it both while the sun was setting and at night when the lights of the city added to the dramatic stillness of the place. Few people milling around and the place was big so it was relaxing. The church had a beautiful entrance but it was close that time.

Quiet, neo-gothic and Art Nouveau. It is said that when Libuše, the legendary ancestor of the Přemyslid dynasty and the Czech people as a whole, stood on the Vyšherad escarpment, she predicted that Prague would become a great city.There the ancient Czech built an impregnable battlement as their first defense to the city. Later, the castle was changed to where it is now, but the old area has endured, now as a beautiful, quiet park and the site of the St. Peter and St. Paul Basilica.The grounds are perfect for an afternoon picnic, there are some great views up and down the Vltava river, and you forget that there is a vibrant, sometimes frenetic city only a few kilometers away.The jewel of the area is the church, reminiscent of St. Vitus Cathedral on the outside with its Gothic architecture, its double spires and black stone. The interior, however is quite different. The altar piece presents a gilded frame of sculpted Peter and Paul, surrounded by Czech saints. The rest of the church is painted in the Alfons Mucha's Art Nouveau style. The green, floral motifs on the ceiling and the interior of the arches make you feel like you're in a forest. Saints from the Czech repertoire adorn three sides of each column.Going there is like dipping into a vat of serenity that recharges you for the rest of your Prague visit.Well-worth it and kid-friendly, but also a very romantic spot. The grounds are free; the church has an entry fee.Take metro line C to Vyšehrad stop, get out on the Prague Congress side and follow the signs.

Where nature meets history. A must see during a Prague visit. Very quiet area with no tourist crowds where one finds a lot of green spaces, parks and gardens neighboring historical walls, gates and buildings. In Vysehrad, and in my opinion, stands the most beautiful church in Prague named after Saints Peter and Paul. This church has breathtaking frescoes and sculptures and is next to an imposing cemetery where rest most of the famous Czech citizens. Vysehrad is not to be missed during a Prague visit.

Fun and Less Touristy than Old Town Prague. Getting out of the touristy center on Prague and heading out to the Vysehrad was great. We took a couple hours in the morning and explored the fortress. Walking on the perimeter was probably the best part although the church is absolutely beautiful.

Walk the walls. This fortress offers a different view of Prague, literally. You can walk all around the walls and see stunning views of the city and landscape. There are a few exhibits, but I definitely recommend the church, the graveyard, and the underground tour at the brick gate where you can see how troops used to move around the fortress, it also now houses some of the original statues from the Charles Bridge.

Peaceful!. A lovely park just a short tram ride or comfortable walk from the Charles Bridge. A bit of a climb to get to it, but worth it when you get there. Lovely old church, and a graveyard with a number of interesting names. The tell me Dvorak is buried there, but I've yet to find his tomb in 5 visits! Lovely to stroll around the walls, looking out over the Vltava River and Southern Prague.

nice view of the Vitava river and the praga old quarter. By a hot sept. day it's wonderful to stay in the tree's shadows and to have fresh air above the Vitara river. Amazing view of the river and the old quarter of Praga.Very accessible w/ only two metro stations from Museum metro station at the Vanceslav square.

Worthwhile!. Was right next to our apartment further south of the city so getting there wasn't a problem for us. I think even if you must travel that's well worth the views of the river and city that you get. You can walk on the walls that surround the Vysehrad which is next to the river. You can see for miles to the south of Prague and you can see the Prague Castle also. There are beautiful gardens, benches, cafes and we even smelt a tasty BBQ, but we didn't go. If you want to spend a day relaxing and wanted to relax, this could be your place. The Church was also spectacular inside and is 50kr or 30 for students. It wasn't so busy on this date and probably the most beautiful interior I've seen in Prague, including castle.

Great Peaceful Place to relax and enjoy more History. Vysehrad castle area is actually a very quiet peaceful place to go that isn't usually crawling with tourists. We spend our entire summers in Prague and at least once a week we go to Vysehrad and sit on a bench in one of the many mature treed parks. We just enjoy the scenery and relax for an hour or so before going to one of the great restaurants within a one minute walk of the park we like.

a walk from old town but well worth it ( i could have rode the tram). Not originally on our list to see, we were referred to this old 10th century fortification. Strong walls lead up to a precipice overlooking all views of prague. In addition to a nice church ( 60k) there was a free walk through the grave yard and paths through the summit walls to overlook the river or the town. In the park was abeer garden with tables and umbrellas and of course beer - it's Prague after all but as we walked around the perrimiter we found a second "peoples "park with much mor basic picnic tables , a sausage hut 60k and beer vendor 29k. Great on a nice day.

Beautiful Views. From Old Town Square, it is a short walk to the Tram stop for #18, which takes you to the foot of this place. It is an upwards walk from the #18 but very scenic and the views from atop are amazing. Taking a slow walk and packing a picnic, it could be a perfect all day date up there. I highly recommend going to see this and enjoying that nice view.
rainy day. Rain or no this place is just fantastic to see while you're visiting PRAGUE.The church the gardens the monuments are just waw!!

I think it is my second favourite place in Prague. What a place, I think you can spend the whole day there and this is not enough, great view of the city and the river. Lovely moments of sunset can be spent there.

Great and Relaxing . A 20 minute walk from old town square this is a great walk to get away from all the touristy things in Old Town. Take time to stroll in the gardens and visit the grave sites of many famous Czechs.
Lovely views. Very nice place, Lovely views across the river with a beautiful church. There are a limited number of off places to eat but the place we found was very nice. Beer was good as usual.

The other Prague castle the first residence of Bohemian kings. This castle was turned to a baroque fortress and park with national cemetery.Gothic cathedral of St Peter and Paul and with the ten century ottonic Romanesque St Martins church,offers beautiful views of the castle on the other river bank, Old Town, and from spring many concerts and performances as well as cafes and restaurants all year around. It is close to metro, the third stop from centre and one does not have to climb the hill

Beautiful. This is a must visit. To be honest, it's a bit of a steep walk up the stairs, but believe me, it's worth it.On the day we visited the weather was excellent, which allowed us to walk around the grounds with it's many statues and visit the Chapel. The Chapel is breath taking and like must of Prague, steeped in history.
Nice view. Nice place, gentle, good for relax. Special place for lovers, to take prewedding photos. Worth spending time.

Beautiful place. Took us less than 15 minutes on the tram to get here from the Mala Strana area where we were staying. Bit of a steep walk to the top but worth it to see the beautiful park with views of the city and stunning church. Good ice cream from the little shop just opposite the church too. Only giving 4 stars however as there are a few eating places but not anything available for vegetarians, might be best to bring your own picnic!

A MUST for music lovers. This is a fantastic place to visit especially if you are into classical music and its connection to the Czech Republic. Here you will see the resting places for so many Czech Philosophers and composers such as Dvorak, Smetana, and many other luminaries of the Czech Nation. The garden and the cemetery along with the amazing views of Vltava are done tastefully and with amazing beauty. Don't miss it.

A detour from a run by the river. Took a run along the river one morning and saw blackened gothic spires up high on a hill behind a massive wall. One of the joys of running are these private exploratory adventures you can have while travelling. I jogged up a side street, asked a helpful guard for directions and continued up the hill (walking a bit too). Got to the top and there are various buildings around but I couldn't see the spires. Asked a local who pointed me towards the church. Jogged around the church and up to the edge of the walls where you get great views up and down the river. I didn't spend too long exploring the top but found some stairs the whole way down back to the road.
Good day out. Interesting battlements, national cemetry, lovely church. Nice park, cafes. Good day out and easily reached by tram.

Magnificent and charming!. I have always considered this place as very magical. It is a bit off the main touristic track but still worth visiting as the balance to the Prague Castle located on the opposite hill across the river Moldau (Vltava).

Beautiful view. We came here to visit the cemetery, but then realised how enjoyable the whole park is. It is much less crowded than our tourist attractions and the view is probably better than the one from Petrin Hill. Lovely place to have a pic nic!
Beautiful view at night 👀❤️. Really interesting place in Prague I love the beautiful view from Vyšehrad at night ✨ It's absolutely amazing!
A must visit attraction in Prague. The views is just breath stopping. We have visited the Vyshehrad with private guide but going on your own will be fantastic aswell.

Cultural Monument. A trip to the Vyšehrad is a must if you have more than a few days in Prague or are visiting for a second time. Perched over the Vltava river this old fortification allows great views looking back on Prague. In addition, it has some great cultural gems, many famous Czech poets, artisans, and musicians are buried in the cemetery and the Basilica of St. Peter and Paul is really stunning. There's a nice park to relax in for a few hours and grab drink or bite to eat. It's a fair walk from the downtown tourist center of Prague, but if you take the walk along the river its really quite relaxing. Definitely recommended for this who are interested in Czech history or for this who want to see something a little off the main tourist path.

Hidden Gem. This hilltop castle/fortress doesn't seem to be much known amongst tourists. There is a pretty cemetery where many of Prague's elite were buried, ruins, a park, a cafe, a beautiful church, and stunning views to rival those of Prague castle. A fantastic spot for a respite from the crowds. Mostly locals hang out here and at the river area just below it.

Peaceful. Away from the crowds it was a very pleasant walk to reach it. The park is pretty with lovely views and the church and cemetery interesting. The bar serves the best lemonade in Prague!A bit off the beaten track but worth a visit.
Nice garden. Nice park, not so much known by tourists as "big" attractions as the castle or old town square. Nice garden, and beautiful view

Not to be missed .... After ending a morning walk at the Letna Hill, we descended the steps down to the Cechuv Most and in a perfect timing boarded the No. 17 tram, that just arrived. The 'scenic ride' by the river brought us to the foot of Vysehrad. We did not want to use the Metro, as I much prefer to travel above ground.So far so good. It was one of the hottest days we experienced in Prague - ever! ...and we chose it to climb the many stairs from the bottom all the way up. Of course we should have known better. But we did the climb many times before since childhood (oh, how easy it was then). What a test of endurance! Reaching the top, before attempting anything else we rewarded ourself with a large beer each in a nearby restaurant. Cold and smooth beer, just what you want and need on a hot sunny day in Prague. With our resolve strengthened we proceeded to stroll the lovely grounds, rewarded by the tranquility and beauty at every turn. Grateful, that the segways and the selfie sticks and the large hordes of people with them did not choose to visit the same time we did. The cemetery was so serene, the few people who were walking around did so respectfully and quietly. Such beauty at every turn.The history is vast here, parts of it I remember from my history class years ago, some is easily refreshed by looking on internet. Vysehrad and the structures around it - from the 10th century on - have undergone vast changes. The original ramparts remain ... In the evening, as the sun sets and reflects in the river, the city becomes golden and heart- achingly beautiful. One of my favorite places in the world at any time and in every season...Make time to visit...You'll be glad you did !

Enchanting high spot.. This hill top fortress has much to offer. The cemetery with beautiful tombs including that of Dvorak and Czech notables I'd tiny and tightly packed. There is a fine church, amusement areas for children, a cafe and some of the best views of the river and city. Well worth the climb up the hill. We also found it to be very peaceful, not too crowded, mostly local,people enjoying the evening.

Peacefull and relaxing. If you want to get away from the crowds and still enjoy a sniff of culture and history,this is the place to be! Walk around the gardens,visit the cemetary and enjoy the amazing views above the moldau river!
calm and cool. Nice place to rest or walk, High enough to take some nice pictures, so green and so clean, you can see Vltava river from top, you can visit to discharge your stress

Fortress, church, national cemetery. One of Prague's cultural centerpieces, the beautiful church and cemetery of the land's great is on a commanding bluff with great overlooks of the river and Prague's stunning architecture.

Historical. This was the home of the Prague royalty before the current Prague castle. Expansive, better to download a map or an app before visiting for a better experience. An excellent alternative to the mainstream, overrun sites like the Prague castle complex as this has wayyy less tourists. Lots of mini sites to visit here. Do not miss out on the Basilica of St. Peter and Paul and the Vysehrad cemetery beside it.
Nice place. It was cold outside and warm atmosphere and hospitality together with hot dishes made our day and inspired for next adventures.

Peaceful Place with Interesting Cemetery. This is a rather quiet but historical place.The cemetery is interesting as a number of famous people are buried here and the gravestones and sepulchers are rather ornate.Very easy to find. Worth a visit

Nice place of peace. After spending a morning in the busy and hot town centre of Prague, we enjoyed taking an easy metro ride out to Vysehrad. Lovely views of the town from a different perspective during a relaxing walk in the old walls.

Highlight is the Amzing Cemetery. Easily reached with public transit and walking, this area is a relaxing respite from the crowds in the city center. The National Cemetery has some stunning memorial art work. Stone work, sculptures and floral tributes are amazing. Many famous persons are represented here including Anton Dvorak. St. Peter and Pauls Basilica has beautiful frescoes of the Art Nouveau era on the ceiling and columns.
Good afternoon. Went here on a bus about 10 minutes from The old town. Some lovely views, and a very pretty church to see. Lots of green spaces for walks.

Really Peaceful Cultural Park. If you stay at the Corinthia Hotel Prague this cultural monument is only 5-10 minutes away. Don't go through the metro station unless you have a valid metro ticket or you could be fined, take the pedestrian walkway across the dual carriageway and past the conference centre. This monument is the old castle of the ancient kings of Prague. Whilst the castle itself has gone there is a beautiful church there (entry 30 Koruna) set in lovely gardens with fantastic views over Prague and along the river Vltava. The cemetery is also quite interesting as it is full of University Professors, famous musicians and international footballers. You can easily spend 2-3 hours having a gentle stroll or enjoying lunch or a drink at the 2-3 cafes in the park. If you want to escape the hustle and bustle of Prague, visit Vysehrad.

Peaceful walk and great view. Great escape from the crowded city centre, breathtaking view and packed with history. Many eateries and restaurants around, free public toilets. Perfect with dogs. (only the cemetery is not accessible with pets.)

Peaceful . If you like parks, gardens, scenery, beatiful view and walking, visit Vysehrad!It is a very serene place below south of the Old Town' s center offering peace and excellent view over Vltava river and other parts of the city.
Quiet tranquility. Nice and really quiet place out of the busy centre of Prague. Amazing view to the river. Beautiful cemetery. Use the metro, A line, Vysehrad station.

Excellent exposure to Prague off-the-beaten path. Easily accessible by tram or by foot, you should definitely visit Vysehrad on a Saturday morning as you can also stop by at the open-air market on the walk back to Old Town. With one of the most beautiful churches I've seen with stunningly detailed stained glass windows. And the best thing is, it's off the beaten path so you're not inundated with tourists.

A nice place if you have enough time. This is not a tourist trap where everyone goes. It takes some time to walk around it all - it is good for a picnic. There are great views and it is a nice place. The basilica minor is beautiful and the cemetery has famous Czechs, so it has Czech tourists often.

Glorious Hilltop Church and Gardens. A delightful stroll atop Prague with great views of Prague Castle cross the river. The church is a magnificent 19th century neo gothic gem. Take the metro and walk to the site - easier than walking up the hill. To return walk down the hill and catch a tram to the city center. The park is full off flowers and birdsong.

beautiful green spaces and views of river and city. a great place to spend late afternoon, evening and see sunset over Prague. Great views of the river and ancient city. Green lawns, benches and picnic spots. Nice change for bustle of the busier tourist sights. Old church and cemetery grounds. Beer garden where you can get beverages and light snacks or sausages and enjoy the scenery. It is a 20 minute walk from Vysehrad metro station.
Nice daytime walk . Nice daytime walk. Quite and well organized park. Nice from top view. Not bad beergarden. Perfect location and easy transportations

The other must-see spot in Praha. Most people know about St. Vitus, Prague Castle, and the Astronomical Clock, but Vyšehrad is the less-well-known counterpoint to those historic sights. It's absolutely gorgeous in it's own right (there are beautiful gardens, lots of cool statuary in the church cemetery, and the church itself is gorgeous), but it's also worth it if you're looking for great views of Prague Castle from a unique angle. Additional bonus for classical music lovers: this is where Dvořák is buried! He has a pretty cool monument in the church cemetery (which is also the Czech national cemetery if I recall correctly). Bottom line: It's a bit of a trek to get out here from the city center but it's 100% worth it for the great views and cool statuary.

Magical place. This place is the oldest place in Prague. It is associated with a vision of the emergence of Prague. The history is nice and you can read in many languages about it on internet but I can guarrantee an unforgettable experience if you will visit it. There is beautiful wiew on Prague and a river and even if you will meet ther a lot of tourists you will feel very comfortable and calmly. It causes history and a lot of miracles. Sit down for a moment and listen a wind and wish something

Don't be lazy and go see it. Vysehrad is less known part of Prague city. However, there are so much to see! If you want to relax and rest from crowds of people, this is the place for you. Also, Vysehrad is a perceft viewpoint of the Prague Castle, other parts of city and Vltava river. This is a place there people come to sing, relax, meditate, walk, talk, drink, take some photos, listen to the music, chat, ect. Good place for couples. Good connection with other parts of city. However, this place is quite secluded, so I am not sure if it's safe after sunset. But we were ok and even saw the hedgehog :)

must visit. Once you get down at the Vysehrad metro station its not easy to reach this place, there are some directions from station but once you get 5 mins away from station you are lost, luckily we found someone who could speak english and guide us. Once we reached here its very scenic, you can spend 3-4 hours easily (we traveled in jun, it was cloudy and temp. was 16-17 C and everything was green). It gives nice view of city and good place to relax yourself.

Never to be missed in Prague. I have never included this site into the itinerary of all my previous trips for the last couple of years. However this place is like a hidden gem for me this round and should not be missed by anyone. Coming here is relatively easy via metro line c with the station same name as this site plus another 10-15 mins walk. The direction from the metro station to here is pretty clear and straight forward with the sign post "Vysehrad" everywhere. You can get a map (czk20) from the information counter not far from the main gate (The Tabor Gate) which helps a bit to navigate in this beautiful park.The Church of SS Petr and Paul is very prominent from everywhere and you should not miss it (you need to pay to get in). The Vysehrad Cemetary beside the church is worth a visit especially the Pantheon which is the resting place for many prominent figures in the history of Czech Republic. My favourite place in the walkway near the brick wall nearby which allow the visitors to have a panoramic view of Prague city including the iconic landmark such as Prague Castle and few bridges with the Vltava river flowing around.
Great place to vidit. A very pleasant park to visit in the quiet suburb of Vysehrad. Lovely views over the city and river. We enjoyed many walks around here during the day and in the evening.

Beautiful oasis . Getting there turned out to be quite a hassle. But once we got there it was totally worth it. Vysehrad is almost like a whole neighborhood. There's a church, cemetery, restaurant and cafe/kiosk and lots of lovely greenery. Climb the wall and have an amazing view of the river and city. Go there and relax. Not at all crowded at the afternoon / early evening when we went.
Beautiful architechture. All I can say is that it is beautiful and unlike a lot of monuments which are darker this is in far contrast, it's worth taking a photo of the information board

Prague's "Other" Castle?. Admittedly we didn't do a lot of research prior to visiting Vysehrad, but it was disappointing. We were hoping to see a "castle", which we found out isn't there. Our Lonely Planet guidebook had a map of the park, and with it we were able to have an idea where we were going on the grounds. There was a cemetery, which has a variety of old and new tombstones, but we didn't recognize any of the names. There was a cathedral there, which was about to close, so we looked inside briefly and it didn't seem any different than most other traditional cathedrals. On the west side of the park there were good views of the Vlatva River, both north toward the Prague Castle as well as south. The park itself wasn't busy, which was a nice break from the more popular Old Town and Castle Districts. If you have extra time to spend in Prague, this could be a nice place to go and have a picnic, otherwise I would suggest skipping it. We opted to take the Metro, but in reading other reviews it looks as though one could also get here by a riverside path.

Great view, beautiful church, interesting cemetery and nice neighbourhood with cubist buildings. The Vysehrad area is underrated, probably because it appears understated, does not cater much for touristic and is a bit from the old city center although it is easy to get to by multiple tram lines. The area has so much to offer. The Vysehrad castle is an excellent place for a picnic, it holds the Slavin cemetery with the well-ordered graves of the dignified Czechs (as opposed to the old Jewish cemetery), the Peter and Paul church which is amazingly decorated on the inside, beautiful and far from most great churches in it's mix of modern art nouveau and ancient medieval lime paintings-style, and in the weekends you are likely to find an event or activity of some kind in the park. Add to that the great sunset view of the Vlata river and the west bank (see it from the viewpoint at the art gallery). When you're done with the castle the nearby area is packed with the real Prague. Go to the lost city below the Nusle Bridge and be amazed with the view and the oddity of it all. Or to the streets at the foothill of the Vysehrad castle and get good Czech food in U Kroka, cake and coffee in one of the several small places or beer at the dock side in the summertime. And see several fine examples of the unique cubist architecture in Prague, e.g. Kovarivic House, Triplex House and the tenement house in Neklanova street.

Stunning architecture and lovely walk. Our hotel wasn't located too far away from this attraction, it was only two stops on the underground from Hotel Ankora. The cobbled streets and the architecture will just blow you away. The walk it just lovely.

A nice place in Praha without "group" tourist. Since Praha is a really nice place, the mass tourism will be in the city as you should be, the downtown is a must but Vysehrad is almost for locals, we were in a Sunday and 90% of the people there were locals having picnics, the church is beautiful and the rest of the castle/park too, there are places to eat with local prices were you can spent less than 400 crowns for nice meal for two.

Some stunning views of Prague and the river.. I really enjoyed our afternoon out at Vysehrad. The grounds of this ancient fortress are a little haven of tranquility in the middle of Prague. A great walk, stunning views and a chance to look at the beautiful windows and paintings inside the church. This is only a ten minute walk from Vysehrad metro station so really easy to find your way from the centre of Prague.

Lovely park off the beaten path. After spending two days seeing the castle, old town, Jewish quarter, and parts of new town, this park/monument was a nice break from the crowds of tourists. There are some great views of the city, pleasant walking paths, and a nice place to sit down and have lunch. I took the subway to get there, which I'd recommend since it would be a fairly long walk if you're staying downtown.

Nice place to visit away from the crouds. We went up the stairs and carried our stroller and had the baby in a baby carrier. A lot of steps! I am sure there must be another access for strollers. This place is huge! We didn't go inside the church.

The Best Views! Fantastic Atmosphere. Vysehrad is a fair walk from the main tourist attractions having walked from the Old Town square along the river. This is certainly worth the effort providing you have the time and the correct shoes for the job! There is a steep hill full of stairs up from the river but also a metro alternative I believe. There is plenty to see and do or simply take snacks and relax and take it all in. Definitely worth some time for a slightly quieter experience away from the crowds.

Away from the crowds... Loved the quiet and the beauty. It's a nice respite from crazy old town square. Very pretty with flowers/buildings/cafes. Definately go visit.. Tram 17 or 18 will get you there with a hike up a hill.

Totally worth the trip. Stunning! Far away from the main attractions but I loved the views while walking up to the place and finally when we arrived at the place. We went there in the morning and it was quite misty and it surreal.
Vysehrad. We took a tram there and it was a huge place without much helpful signs other than a map at the entrance. It is a big area on the top of the hill with a nice view.

Worth the walk. Vysehrad is quiet a walk from the heart of Prague, but it's worth it. Just take a left from Old Town and stay along the river for the most scenic route, but make sure not to miss the subtle path up the hill which will be on your left. Take a map so you won't go too far.

Nice hilltop fortress. We actually enjoyed this more than the official Prague 'castle'. Nice park surroundings, cemetery with some lovely tombstones, nice cathedral, all the usual food and ice creams available.
Vysehrad metro station is the easy way of getting here, otherwise it's quite a steep walk up the hill.

More fun than famous castle-don't miss. Nice Czech man helped us find the subway- free on Sunday. Followed excellent Rick Steeves walk. Views were fabulous. National Cemetery was interesting and poignant - found Dvorak. This Sunday morning was a highlight of our trip!

a must see in prague. we took the metro to this place.
very close to station... sprawling grounds, stunning view of river, castle, can laze around and spend time picnicking.... carry snacks, walk down to the tram stop and go to the city.

Absolutely beautiful!. Stunning views over Prague, beautiful grounds to walk around.
Very easy to get to on the tube, although make sure you pay for a ticket - you WILL get fined if you're a little over the time on the ticket and they do not accept excuses.
Very calm and quiet as opposed to Prague's very busy center.
Absolutely beautiful!
Very serene place to visit. This is very silent and serene place to visit. If you want to take a nice stroll on the top of the hill, then this is place. There is one nice church and cemetry as well.

A grat place to visit. We bought a one day metro card, and took the metro to Vysherad. I can highly reccomend the area. Huge parks and recreation area combined with historical monuments and churches. If you go there, it is best to go in daytime. We went in the evening, and some of the buildings were closed. But the area itself was lovely, and you got a great wiew towards the city.

A special place, often overlooked!. As a musician, Vysehrad is very special to me. The great Czech composer Bedrich Smetana wrote a cycle of symphonic tone poems, "Ma Vlast," and "Vysehrad" (the High Castle) is the first. (The four note tune that you hear played in the Prague Train Station before announcements is the opening melody of "Vysehrad!") While here, musicians should visit the graves of Smetana, composer Antonin Dvorak, violinist Jan Kubelik, and conductor Rafael Kubelik. Everyone will enjoy the beauty of the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, and the wonderful views of the city. It is a beautiful spot, and I always find the soul of the Czech people here.

Very peaceful.. This is just the right place for relaxing! Simply sit on the grass and enjoy the good weather or meditate about the melancholy of life in the cemetery where all the famous writers, singers, painters and fighters for freedom from Czech history are buried. And the view is spectacular! Grab a beer and enjoy! :)

Great views of Prague. Just a few stations of metro from the city center and you are at Vysehrad ... and you have several options ... you can just walk in park and enjoy incredible views of Prague; you can visit of old church or to browse through cemetery where are hurried some famous Czech writers, composers and artists.

A nice escape from the busy city, a different view of a busy city. Went there to see Prague from the distance and a different Prague than the one we already experienced two days.Easy to get from downtown , just a few subway stops and the walk can begin.We enjoyed experiencing history first hand and seeing this, really, impressive monument.Looking on how far it expands and the actual size , it must have even been more impressive a long time ago when the horse wagon stood at the gate. City walls that seem not to conquer.In the middle a church that offers for a small free a nice break from walking, alternatively also the option of having a snack and a beef in the small restaurant is available.All in all , put around two hours aside to see this part of Prague ... And get at the same time a public transport first hand experience.

Well worth going out of you way. This is a beautiful park and lovely view of the city. If you want to wander around it is perfect. There were many school children touring which added an different dimension to the visit. The church and cemetery are truly fantastic. Dvorak is buried there among other famous Czech born individuals.

Art Nouveau decoration in St Peter and St Paul. This is a wonderful oasis of calm, with tremendous views of nearly the entire city of Prague. It seems that many tourists don't find their way here, which is a refreshing change to the mad bustle of much of the town centre. It's an easy walk from the Metro station. The graveyard is astonishing and even without recognising the Czech great and good interred here, the sculpture and art of their resting places is easily appreciated. And talking of art, pay a small fee and go inside the Church of St Peter and St Paul. It was fully painted by two Czech artists, in the style of Mucha - so if you appreciate Art Nouveau, you'll adore the decoration, from the wistful saints to the flowers and trees that twine round ceilings, pillars and walls. A truly unique church, I'd suggest and not nearly as well-known as it deserves.
Great views. Quiet and not touristy--seems to be mostly locals. Great view of the city and a nice easy hike/walk.

Stunning and peaceful. Access by metro is easy and cheap and a short walk from the castle itself. Inside is a map and info centre. Not many tourists go so it's lovely and quiet with stunning views all around. Huge statues and the imposing cathedral are inside as well as the cemetery that is clearly listed with several famous people. The gallery was shut for what seemed to be a very long "break" so didn't et the chance to see it. The crypt was disappointing but very cheap. I finally found the Brick Gate which now houses the original statues from the King Charles Bridge. You have to go on tour down there and it's freezing!! Also no English, only Czech and fairly miserable staff sadly, but worth it. Takes all of 15 mins but several hours for the whole castle and gardens. A picnic is a Gd idea subject to weather. Great views of Prague. Recommended

Beautiful garden, great view and less crowded!. Certainly one the best places to be if you are going in peak season (summer). Best thing about this place is that it is not famous. Doesn't feature in the promoted must be of porague. This leaves Vysehrad to the company of those few who have found it out. A great view of city from the edges of that garden. Overall a good couple of hours spent there,

Vysehrad. I was fortunately given the opportunity to study abroad in Prague and Vydehrad happended to be one of my field trip locations. This one of the most interesting locations in Prague. In the museum building you can see how the city of Prague evolved into one of the crown jewels of Europe. Going under the walls of Vysehrad to find the chamber in which thry have stored the original statues from Charles Bridge is a very unique experience. Giving you the feeling of being a soldier from long ago. The complex itself is very large with many green spaces and monuments, not to forget the magnificent views of the surrounding areas. The St.Cryil and Methodious church is located here complete with a cemetery of some of the most important figures to the Czech Republic and Slovakia. Highly recommened.

Well worth a visit. Visited in the late afternoon , walked from the Metro statio of the same name on the red line. We loved walking around the castle walls with the stunning views of the river, and surrounding area. We found the cemetry really facinating, would have visited the cathedral - but it was getting a bit late. Did have a couple of beers in the late afternoon sunshine at the Bar b que resturant . This is a great place to visit away from the crowds of the city. Easy to walk down the hill to the river for a great walk back to town or tram 17.
Great Cemetary. I don't know why more people don't talk about this placae when they talk about Prague. Vysehrad was beautiful and the cemetary was really interesting!
very nice for a walk and relax. lovely place for sunny afternoon walk, can do a picnic, have a view on the river, can come from different directions so its well connected
Place for a rest. This monument is a good place for resting after a hard day, because it has a beautiful part and good architecture.Also from it opens so a good view to the Prague.
Nice place off the main scene. If you want to see something off the really beaten track, you should come here. Nice garden to walk around, and a good place to view Prague

Definitley Worth the Visit. You might not think a cemetery is worth the visit, but I assure you it is. Many famous artists have done sculptures here and some famous Czechs are buried here. The area has much to explore and offers some excellent views. A bit off the beaten path as well so not as crowded.

Amazing. Absolutely the best place in Prague! Not as many tourists as in the centre of the city, a perfect place to just take a walk, relax and look at the city from above. The cathedral's amazing too and the cemetery's very picturesque/

Relaxing and beautiful part of Prague. I have gone here multiple times and usually take visitors here when they come to Prague. There are many things to do and many things to see here. If you want to get a day with less crowds I would recommend going to Vysehrad!

Wonderful place on the rock above Vltava river. Very nice place, I really like to come here very often, several times per year. The first records we can find in the beginning of 11th century and this place was very improtant fortress in that time, even Charles IV. included Vyshehrad in the plan to make Prague a center of the Roman Empire. Visitors can see beautiful gardens with nice flower and trees, many statues and sculptures - e.g. Libushe and Premysl, Ctirad and Sharka, Zaboj and Slavoj etc. These are the persons from old Czech history. It could be maybe interesting for tourists to know that Libushe had prophetic abilities and predicted many things, incl. the place where Prague will be built, the importance and respect of the Prague Castle etc. After the ascent to the walls of Vyshehrad you reveal spectacular views of the Vltava River, Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, Petrin Tower and other nice parts of Prague City. During your walk you can see Cathedral of Peter and Paul, Tabor Gate, Leopold Gate, Slavin - giant joint tomb of prominent Czech personalities, Vyshehrad cemetery etc. And finally - they say that Vyshehrad has very strong positive energy potential, so you can feel really relaxed after visiting this place.

Interesting cemetery and church. We had a spare hour so decided to visit Vysehrad. We looked around the cemetery as there are many famous Czechs buried here. If you are a Czech you will recognize many famous writers, artists, musicians and others here. My husband recognized only Bedrich Smetana and Antonin Dvorak. But even if you don't recognize anyone it's still worth a trip as many graves are decorated with statues and some graves are real works of art.We also visited the church of St Peter and St Paul which is beautiful inside and out. We didn't have time to walk around the gardens and will be back to see them.

Fantastic location. WE spent two days visiting this place..the mythical capital of Prague! It was wonderful to tour all the historical sites, the St Vitus church and the huge cemetery next to the church. It was well worth the time to travel there!

Way better than Prague's Castle. If you visit Prague, really, don't miss Vysehrad! It's a great park, with amazing view of the city and an interesting cemetery with statues. Amazing for a morning walk!
Beautiful view. You could enjoy a beautiful view to Prague from the hill. Lots of things to see, beautiful church monuments to walk around

Very nice park with interesting sights to visit. We dedicated one morning walking down from Wenceslas Square to the Vyšehrad area which is hilly enough to offer some great views over the river Vltava; we visited the neo-Gothic church of Saint Paul and Peter, the nearby cemetery, resting place of many famous Czechs, we walked around the beautiful and clean park (many people jogging, cycling among sculptures), we have seen the rotunda of St. Martin from 11th century and we exited the park from the side opposite to the river (through the old gates of the castle) in order to get to the metro station of Vysehrad (Line C) which is situated at a walking distance.
Great views, neat cemetary. Didn't get to spend nearly enough time up here. Fantastic views, very relaxed atmosphere and impressive cemetery. If i came again i'd allow 2 hours to walk around.
Vysehrad. Peacful yet beautiful place. If fatigue from the throngs this is the place for a rest. Great views. Free of charge. Easy to go.

Suprising. I left Vysehrad, for the last day, because never thought that worth go to there. Was
the most surprising thing in Prague, and if you are staying on City Center, go visit by walk, its a very culture and interesting journey.
Amazing place when it is sunny. With the sun, the park and its buildings are awesome, and it is a perfect option to avoid the crowd of tourists

Very good monument.. Great place to go... Was at the Vysehrad monument walking around since the hotel I was staying is quite closeby - and it was a wonderful 2 hours spent. Surprisingly under-rated, probably since it is 2 metro stops away from Old Town in Prague. Must see monument especially if you are a history buff Or even a fitness enthusiast. The walk around the walls are not exactly the mildest ups and down path.The Sandstone spires are quite different... The view of the river and Prague is wonderful. The local maps at each key sighting points really help!Lovely place and would recommend to everyone.

Don't miss it. However, it's not that far from centre, many people just ignore it and they make huge mistake. Vyšehrad offers stunning view, medieval atmosphere at its cemetery with all the Czech legends buried there and walking through its park is unforgettable experience, especially in Spring.
Nice walks. I live in Prague and use to go here often, is a place with a great view and nice walk without a lots of tourist. Its amazing especially in the evening.

Best view of Prague. This was my favorite place that I've visited in Prague. It was very quite and the view was amazing. This place is not as crowded with tourists as the other main attraction of Prague.
Quiet and out of time. Nice view from the top of the city, quiet park. Walk around the place not forgetting a look at the old cemetery.
What a view!. What a view! Hiked up and really enjoyed walking around. There was plenty to explore and great photo opportunities

Bike heaven.. We took our bikes from CITY BIKE (WHOOWHOO :-D ) to Vysherad. There are so many cool little places here... from a very bohemian pub&grill to a gorgeous cemetary with many famous artists within. The view of the river from here is absolutely inexplicable. Stay until the sun starts setting. Just awesome.
Wonderful. Felt like we were the only visitors in Prague. It was fascinating. The inside of the church was amazing.

Perfect escape in all seasons. The grounds are lovely with many areas to explore and enjoy. Pack a picnic, wander around, enjoy the views over the Vltava River and do take a long, leisurely stroll through the magnificent cemetery. Easy to access from Metro or Tram and a short walk (although from the tram on the riverside it is an uphill hike, it is not too strenuous).

So many things to do and see!. This was my third visit at Vysehrad, but totally different from the last two, and this is why. I chose another route of approach. Instead of climbing up from the river I came from the "inland" entrance, from the metro station, and since the area is so big and so varied there is always new things to view. This time I first stopped at the St.Martins rotunda, one of the very oldest churches in Prague, and then walked up next to the Chapter house towards the cemetary (which I hadn't seen before). And what a sight is was, with masses of huge and very impressive graves of the more celebrated citizens of Bohemia over the last century. Especially gorgeous was the artwork surrounding many of the graves under the arched peristyle, rich mosaics, amazing statuary etc. Then I went in to see the St. Peter and Paul cathedral, and again I was very surprised, because the entire church is painted in murals in the very colourful and rich Art Noveau style, which enhances the New Gothic feeling to great heights. After this I walked around the grounds to take in the view from the bailiworks down to the river and town below, when I stumbled upen the Gothic cellar, where there is a much worthwhile exhibition of the history of the place. Very interesting indeed. After this, and further exploration of the grounds I left by the "river" entrance, very satisfied. I will be back, and no doubt there will be things there that I haven't seen before also then.
Hidden gem. This is missed by most tourists but it is wonderful for strolling and has a marvelous church with painted interior and from the walls surely the best views of Prague.
Awesome Views. Wonderful 360 views across Prague in beautiful grounds. Easy to get to via Tram from Wenceslas Square

Highlight of Prague. Our morning spent hiking up to Vysehrad was definitely the highlight of my trip to Prague. It was a snowy day, and the everything was just so beautiful. It's much more secluded than the touristy Prague Castle, but I ended up liking it much better. The church is stunning and a must-visit...and just exploring the grounds -- little trails and doorways, the views.. Stunning!

Well Worth the Walk. We visited on a Autumn Sunday, a bit cloudy and cold. The walk from the subway station is pretty clearly marked and it was just easy to follow others. After the old city, this location offered perspectives of the entire area. Historically, it offers a sense of place.
One more place you do not wanna miss. Very nice historical fort! Nice for walks, lots of nature there, nice historical buildings, Church etc. If you want to relax a bit very good place for it!

Away from the crowds and tranquil. The views from the ramparts are great, and the interior of the church is amazing - the art nouveau style hand painted panels and ceiling are very different from the other frequently visited churches in Prague. There is a very small admission charge for entry to the church. We always make sure we are there at midday to hear the bells ringing - they must continue for about 15 minutes. The cemetery is the resting place of many famous or important czechs, with some beautiful headstones and sculptures. Unlike many of the main Prague attractions, this area is peaceful and tranquil - a good place to escape for a bit from the hustle and bustle of the castle area, Charles Bridge or old town square

Stunning!. Having been to Prague several times before I was looking for something else to see. A friend told me about Vysehrad so I went to have a look. I was not disappointed! It about a ten minute walk from the closest metro station, once you've gone through the archway on the right is a tourist information places with a lovely little cafe in it too. The grounds are big with plenty to see and do, I did pay 50kč to look at the history museum which is very good value for money! This is the only thing I had to pay for while I was there. There are beautiful views of Prague form several places around the perimeter walls so don't forget your camera!! It was beautiful in the winter and I bet in the summer it's outstanding!!! :)

Beautiful place to visit. It offers great views over the city and of the Vltava river. This is a perfect place for people traveling with dogs; while dogs get their walks, the owners can admire the historical buildings and beautiful nature.

Little piece of serenity. Very nice walk through the old castle of Vysehrad. You can just walk through the park and enjoy the scenery or visit the beautiful church and its cemetery. It was very quiet when we went and this was a nice change compared to the Prague old town. Good experience if you have some time to spare.

Worth visiting. Vysehrad is a nice place where you can take a walk and enjoy the view. It's a bit far away from the town centre but it only shows that Prague has many beautiful sites. The old cemetery and Saint Peter and Paul church are really worth a visit. However, when coming there with a car it isn't easy to find a way while there is only one singpost.
Not so crowded as old town square and Karluv Most. It's nice place for lazy walk around old walls, sitting on bench and just admiring landscape. On every full hour, beautiful song plays from belfry.

Old legend place. According to legend is Vysehrad place where Libuše said her prophecy and Šemík with Horymír jumped over the rampart and scampered to Neumetel. Magic ambience is still there! Old cementary, mysterious catacombs and beautiful park with more beautiful view on Prague make this place perfect for turists trip but also for peaceble walk.

Hidden treasure! Beautiful place to walk around and enjoy maginificent views. This place served to various purposes in the past. There used to be a castle, which some of the Czech sovereigns prefered to Prague Castle. It was an important centre of the church, later it became a fortress, the walls of which are still kept. In 19th century a famous cemetery was founded where the most of the Czech famous writers, artists and even sportsmen are burried. Today it serves as a recreational walking area of mainly local people. It is a beautiful large park where while walking along the fortress walls you can admir beautiful views, visit Saint Peter and Paiul ´ s church with art nouveau interior, see one of the oldest churches in the country-Rotunda of Saint Martin. There are also couple of restaurants and fast foods, so you can easily spendthere a half day on your leasure.

Beautiful walk, excellent views . We went up to Vysehrad on a sunny Sunday morning and it was probably one of the highlights of our trip. We didn't take the usual route up but walked around the back to find a narrow passage leading up between the houses. This was much nicer as the other side was full of tourists. Arriving to the top the view was breathtaking. Either we were lucky or Sunday is not a popular day for Vysehrad, it was very peaceful and quiet. It only started getting busy when we were leaving around 1pm. Walk around the church, check out the ruins, admire the cemetery and just soak in the view.

Great views and beautiful cathedral. If you want a different poit of view of Prague and get away from the crowded Charles bridge and Mala Strana, this is a great choice. Pice of advice: walk over there along the Vltava to discover the beautiful Art Nouveau / Jungestil buildings. The climb to Vysehrad is ot that hard. Beautiful cathedral (one of the nicest we saw) and hardly anyone, so we could enjoy a great walk in the park.
Calm walk. The church and the cemetery are the highlights of Vysehrad but the walk in a green environment was a nice diversification of the busy center of prague.

Go If You Have The Excess Time!. I stayed 7 nights in Prague and decided to go Vysehrad on foot from my hostel near Old Town Square. This place definitely lacks the tourist crowds and it's very peaceful walking around the hill. Up here sits The Church of St Peter & Paul, next to it, is the cemetery. The edges of the fortifications walls offer a panoramic view of Prague and the River Vltava.

Vyshehrad Art Nouveau Cathedral. Vyshehrad is a huge castle. You will find there a prison, impresive defensive walls, a cemetery-a kind of national panteon, green spaces and Peter and Paul cathedral which was a big surprise. The hole church is decorated in Art Nouveu style.It is so beautiful I couldn't belive my eyes. Do not miss the place.There are not many tourists, the place is green and calm so you can spent there anice half day.For the church you have to pay, for the rest of the complex no

A less crowded seat of kings with a view of Prague.. A visit to Vysehrad rounds off an understanding of the history of Prague alongside a view of the city from the South. St Peter and St Paul cathedral and the adjoining cemetery are worth a visit and the grounds are less crowded providing a relaxed stroll. We walked from here right up to Charles Bridege along the river Vl

Great view and walk. It is a bit out of the way, so no crowds. Great views overlooking the river. Worth seeing Basilica of St Peter and St Paul and the cemetery when there. Just plan to take the tram or subway to the hilly part to start and then walk down, finishing at the tram close to the river.
Nice place e even in winter. Great place for a walk. Amazing view from all around the walls. A little bit far from city center, but reachable by team in 15 minutes

An oasis of calm. Walked there for a quiet morning. Amazing views onto the city and the river. The old heart of Prague and indeed Europe still beats here. It is hard to see how it would have been originally as it has been so developed in the 19th Century but the geography and location speaks for itself. The catherdral and churchyard are special.A great hour or so away from the madness of the old town.

Vysehrad the oldest place in Prague. Great place for walk, church Petr and Pavel and great park nearby. If not to cold!Great view from above on the city and the river of Vltava. Also has one of the oldest cemetery.
VISIT!. A little bit off the tourist circle, it is a very beautiful site with great views over the river. The cathedral in it is very impressive. One of the most beautiful sites in Prague.

A short walk South from our hotel.. Vysehrad (the first castle) and grounds are worth seeing. There were almost no tourists and some fabulous views of the city and River Vltava.We stayed in the Park Inn on the South Side of the city and Vysehrad was a very comfortable walk for us. Should say quite a lot of it was uphill but not difficult.There are a few very interesting shopping opportunities which are not totally touristy.Very lovely stop off point on the right hand side on the way in with a lovely wood burning stove where you will be guaranteed a very warm welcome from the smiley lady and a lovely hot drink.
Great outdoor venue, educational and historic. This is a wonderful historical site . . . churches . . . amazing graveyard . . . ramparts . . . and green areas for children to run and play.

Superb View. We caught the tram from the city. It went along the river bank past the dancing building. There is also a metro station nearby. Having caught the tram we walked up the hill. The views are amazing from the walls of the fort. You can walk round 360 degrees. From one side you have views over Prague and the Vltava River and on other sides over the suburbs and outlying areas of Prague. In the moat there are now tennis courts and an outdoor concert area in one corner. There are plenty of grassy areas and small roads to stroll about. As it was such a cold day we took shelter in a small cafe/bar where we had coffee and delicious chestnut cake. We also walked to the church in the middle of the area. Behind its decorated doors are lots of frescoes and paintings in the small chapels on either side of the main part of the church. As it was the Christmas season there were several Christmas trees and a large nativity scene with lifesize figures. There was a small charge to enter the church. Beside the church is the National Cemetery where many famous Czech citizens including Smetana are buried. This beautiful cemetery with its snow covered graves, many decorated for Christmas, was a perfect place to visit. Vysehrad is a quiet place to visit, where, in summer, you can see the locals enjoying picnics, walking, running and playing games. Just past the side entrance on the right is a wonderful souvenir shop where the gifts are made by disabled people. Really good and authentic souvenirs.

Serene place. I grew up couple streets away. It was the first Prague castle that was made out of wood. It's such a nice place for a afternoon walk with great views. Great for picnics in the summer. Go see the catacombs. See the Cathedral. There is also a cemetery with many famous Czech people from our history. Love this place.
Out of the regular. If you want something out of the Town and quiet you should go. It's like a happy morning excursion with the classic beauty of Prague without being crowded

Incredible place!. Just go there! 5 minutes by foot from metro Vysehrad, an unexpected calmness and ancient atmosphere awaits you. What's there? A great view over the city, a great hidden beer garden, some space to chill and read under roses, and an old church with a graveyard, where not only Bedrich Smetana, the famous Czech composer, has been buried...

The quieter counterpart to the Prague Castle. This is where the kings used to live before building the Prague castle, and it is a great place to go for a walk and see the bastions and castle walls. Since it is up on a hill, it offers another great view of Prague from above. You can also visit the church, and the nice little cemetery next to the church, where you can find the grave of Dvorak. The place seems to be pretty popular with local people, for walking, playing with dogs or jogging.

A relaxing visit for my last day.. The Vysehrad castle is away from the tourist crush, and the district is well worth a stroll along the river bank,It was the palace of the first Czech kings, and has a small museum/interpretive centre with English text too.There is a peaceful cemetery with some quite ornate graves, of Czech artists, writers, musicians, and other famous people.There are gardens to picnic in, and the views of the river, and the city are splendid. It was all under snow the day I visited, and had been -16 degrees the previous night (bracing!) but the sun came out and sparkled on the river, making it a lovely farewell to the city (not a tourist taking 'selfies' in sight!!!!)

Great relaxing walk through the past. Very few good sights in Ptague are free? This being the exception.We walked through here on a Sunday afternoon and saw many locals walking dogs and couples kissing. Nice historical sights such as castle walls, bastions and a nice church and graveyard where you can see the famous composer Dvorak's grave/monument. Relaxing hour stroll. Could have stayed longer.

Quiet and Nice part of prague. Not very well known by touristes, the "other" Castle of Prague is a very good place to visit, through a walk in the park and a stop at the site seing places, visit of the Church and the cementeryThen you can end up close to the river

My favourite place to visit while in Prague. Easy to get to by Metro, it has it's own stop and then easy to walk back into the city centre from. It has a very relaxing atmosphere and is full of people enjoying themselves, walking dogs, exercising and taking in the views. Great beer garden in the summer months with the best views in the city.
Great Walk and view. Nice walk in December not to cold, beautiful church inside and Vatican houses. The view to river is very pleasant you can stay hours enjoying view.

It's good, but it's not a must see! . This place is ok. it's good to see and spend sometime( max an hour). A beautiful old church, a beautiful cemeteries and a beautiful park. They are so ordinary. Nothing exciting. You can skip it easily and go to more exciting places.
Old place in Prague. The place is connected with many legends. You can for example see the devil stones in the park. There is also the old rotunda. And nice view to Vltava river

Best part of my Prague trip!. We visited this in winter and it was covered in snow, making it so surreal and beautiful. It's so understated but very steeped in history with breathtaking structures and landscapes. Spend time at the cemetery where many historical Czechs are buried, next to St. Paul & Peter's basilica. This was the highlight of my Prague trip by far!

Away from the crowds. A bit off the beaten track this place doesn't receive half of the attention of the old town and the presidential palace and this is a shame. There are amazing views from the hill any time of the day. From the top one can see the defense wall to the east, the river winding south and the rows of bridges to the north. In the park can be seen the Peter and Paul Cathedral. I couldn't stop wondering how the builders 100's years ago were able to cut the stone to such perfection. The place is definitely worth the visit.
Vysehrad park. Amazing panoramic view.. you will see prague from above across prague castle , charle bridge and valtava river
away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Stunning view from the top, beautiful cathedral and next to it is cemetery where are buried some famous czechs.
Worth seeing!. Ruins of the old castle, with great view on the river. There is also a small cemetery where many famous Czechs are buried.

A stroll along the castle walls. Needing a break from the tourist crush and queues we headed to vysehrad a UNESCO listed monument. Lovely historic precinct, gorgeous views from the wall and stunning church. Cafe Citadella provided good coffee . Full of local families a gorgeous winters afternoon

Highly Recommended To Visit. A visit to Vysehrad is highly recommended. A 10 minute or so walk from the metro is an Oasis of calm and beauty away from the hustle and bustle of the tourist areas of the city centre and Prague Castle. Interesting architecture, a beautiful Church, a large cemetery where many famous Czechs are buried (including Mucha, Dvorak and Smetena ) and the Slavin memorial, gardens, a quaint open-air theatre and great views of the city. When we visited, it was also possible to take a short tour of the Casemates ( tunnels built to enable the army to move between the walls of the castle without being visible ) for 60 KCS for which you can also watch a 20 minute video on the history of the development of Prague and its defences.
Recommend going here. Went here twice during stay in Prague. First time at night, then went back the following day. Beautiful area. Very scenic and peaceful.

Little Away and Awesome. Just a 10 min walk away from the metro station, take out time for this lovely place. Away from the city center crowd this, large residential cum museum cum garden complex is steeped in history. I suggest, read a bit about it before your visit to soak in the place even better. Then sit back in one of cafes' there to reflect upon your great choice.

Go there for the History and the View. I very much recommend a leisurely walk through this historical site, the grounds are inviting, the view from the top spectacular. Also found a visit to the cathedral and the adjourning cemetery worth while.

great views. A much lesser visited part of Prague but well worth the trip we visited on a sunday morning when it was really quiet after the chaos of the main square a wonderful relief for some peace and quiet - great views of the city from here

Stunning view and interesting findings. Pity that not many people take the time to see this part of town. Easily accesible by public transport or car, you won't be disappointed. Stunning view from the top of the wall of this amazing place, favorite location for local joggers and curious tourists. Very nice cathedral and a cemetary next to it worth visiting.

Untouched beauty . We were staying at Holiday Inn, about 10 minutes walk away. This is a very beautiful place, though a little chilly when the wind blows. The park is huge, with some joggers and people walking their dogs. From the top, we can see some parts of Prague. Then we walked to the cathedral, surrounded by the cemetery, all seems to be untouched. We paid about 50 crowns to enter the cathedral. We thought that there was a castle, there is none. Away from the hustle of Prague castle, this place is peaceful and quiet. It is definitely worth a visit.

A nice side trip. When you have done all the "required" sights in Prague, this is a lovely diversion.It's an easy tram ride #17 and then a short walk to one of the oldest parts of Prague. Great views from the walls. Beautiful Basilica on the grounds. Rotunda of St. Martin one of the oldest buildings inPrague. If you like to hike, this is a great area. Not crowded at all.

Helps you understand the history of Prague...and enjoy outstanding views. Try to go with sunshine! not a lot of tourists reach here, so it is peaceful and quiet. Views over the Vltava river are oustanding. Read the legend of the Prsmyl family before you go, to understand its historical significance
Must visit. So interestingersting, lovely gardens, views and beautiful walking areas. Lovely cafe within tourist info bureau.
Good park walk with a view. For those that enjoy a good walk in a park with an elevated view of the river. A little more peaceful away from the more crowded parts of the old town.

Great place for a walk with good vistas. Vyšehrad is definitely one of my favourite places in Prague, just to go for a walk, jogging or a picknick. You can visit the graveyard where a lot of famous and important people are buried and if you have a chance, go visit the cathedral, it's absolutely amazing and wonderful. When you walk around the battlements, you can enjoy great vistas of the river and the Castle. Also, if it's summer, don't miss the open-air pub.

Definite must-go. The Prague Castle is usually the highly publicized one, but this is definitely a hidden gem. You will need to take the metro to Vysehrad (not far from old town) or a 40 min walk.It's a big space, and not crowded with tourists at all, unlike the Prague Castle. You can take walks along the grounds, with benches for you to sit and rest on. There's a great view from the grounds overlooking the city of Prague.There's also a chapel to visit (50Kc per entry) but it's worth the entry price, to see very intricately made ornaments and stories in this church.There's also a cemetery plus quite a few buildings to explore.
Great views!. Amazing views from the top of Vysehrad, you can see all of the Bridges of Prague from up here, well worth a visit!

Place for beautifull view!. A beautiful cathedral with a lot of detail seems unreal because of its size . It's quiet and a lot of greenery, pleasant for walking and staying . In contrast to the crowds in the center could use to go to some distant part and walk to the top. The view from here is beautiful!
Very nice walking area, love it!. I do really love to walk on Vysehrad. Nice area, park, amazing views of different parts of Prague... If you have chance you definitely should go there!

Absolutely gorgeous. Vysehrad was only 10 mins walk from our Hotel. We were delighted to have visited this beautiful area. It has a large park, stunning views over the town, beautiful Church of St Peter& Paul and stunning graveyard. We missed the museum part as we were flying home that day. So happy we seen so much. It was one of the best highlights.

Good views over town and a bit of greenery. Great church.. Visited here on a sunny November day. Only a couple of metro stops from the centre. Great views over the city and the river. Interesting and surprisingly ornate graveyard (Alphonse Mucha's remains are here). Very impressive church (Peter and Paul church) with an interior totally covered in colourful murals. They were filming some sort of Nazi era drama when I was there so entry into the church was delayed, but got there in the end.

Please don't miss it. Easily accessible using metro C this is an amazing place to explore Prague. This place gives breath taking views of Vitava river and its huge grounds are just great to stroll on to. There is a cathedral and gallery in the main grounds. And a good suggestion to walk on the pathway following the castle wall. It gives 360 degree view of surrounding area. It's a place not to be missed at all.

Visehrad park. Above the Prague ,sees almost all bridges at both sides,nice view.... and church of SS Pavle and Peter and Vysehrad cemetery with monuments of Smetana and Dvorak...Beautiful St Martin's Rotunda and many monuments ...The sculptures of Libuse and Premises and Lumir and Pilsen....beautiful nature ....I like it and enjoy it

Simply incredible . I didnt have anything to do on my last day in Prague so had a look on tripadvisor. Found this place and it has really good reviews so decided to check it since i've got the whole day to kill before i head back to London. This place didn't disappoint me. I took the tram to Vyton and then walk up the steps. It was sunny but windy and freezing cold but walking did a lot of good to keep myself warm. It was a massive place and the parkland has amasing view. There were loads of benches to sit on if you get tired walking. The highlight were the National Cemetery with incredible graves which must have cost millions of CZK and St.Paul and Peter Cathedral. The cemetery was more like a gallery of statues and monument. It was kept well. You have to pay 50CZK which was really cheap to get in to the cathedral. There was also a leaflet which was really handy so you wud have an idea of cathedral. As usual it was amasing inside. I took so much time here especially walking around park though it was cold because the scenic view was inviting. Did this walk on Saturday where weekend market was on so decided to walk to the market at Vyton on my way back to old town square. Loads of food, wine, products and etc. It was an amasing day to end my trip in Praha.

Quiet day away from the tourists!. As the original fortress of Prague with over a thousand years of history, it seems to be off the beaten track of the tourists and is nice and quiet. An imposing fortress as it stands with many things to see. We spent 4 or 5 hours here and were surprised that it wasn't that big.
