Buy a guidebook and plan from the gothic cellar to ensure that you cover the park. It was a bit of a trek (four bridges down from Charles Bridge and up a steep slope but it was worth it.1. Church of Saints Peter and Paul - chargeable2. Gothic Cellar - chargeable3. Gorlice - chargeable4. A cafe - not cheap but couldn't be bothered walking away and back5. Prague version of a pantheon - look out for DvorakAnd other bits of the fortress, statutes and archaeology and a walk in the parklands.

Perfect place for a nice walk. Took the Metro from Muzeum to Vysehrad (only 2 stops, 6 minutes). From there you have to search a bit for the entrance of Vysehrad, but just follow the Congrescentre and the big road and you will get there. In autumn, this park is really really nice. You will have a fantastic view over the city, and the park itself has some worth-seeing elements as well.

Great if time and weather permit. Someone said that Prague residents consider this the "real" castle of the city, rather than the Hradcany. Much of it was destroyed over the centuries, and is now basically a beautiful park. You can still walk a circuit around most of the ramparts, and there are some interesting sights in there, including a beautiful Gothic church, a cupola or chapel that looks Byzantine and is said to be the oldest standing building in Prague, and the graves of Smetana and Dvorak in the cemetery. It takes half a day to appreciate it, so it might not be possible for a visitor with very limited time.

Well worth it: escape the crowds. This was one of my favourite places on my recent visit to Prague, mainly because there weren't too many people around - unlike most of the other places more centrally located. I walked here all the way from the old town area - it was an easy enough walk, with a few interesting places to see along the way. The site itself has some impressive old walls, a beautiful old cathedral, and some pleasant park land, plus some great views out over the river and the city. Worth the effort if you can spare the time.

recommended by Rick sTeves and worth it. it's a slight challenge getting here; requires biting the bullet and learning about the Metro. In fact it was very easy, 4 stops and one transfer. You come out in the ugliest building in Prague - thank you communism - and then walk through a beautiful park on the cliffs over the Vltava. A welcome change from the fascinating urban architecture of this amazing city.
Do not miss!. I came her for the congress center nearby. I strongly recommend a walk in this area. There are also some good pictures to take.

a different view over the city. For unknown reasons, these views aren't often found on postcards, but they're still stunning. The cemetery is filled with well known names, and the graves are pretty. The cathedral is pretty, but the lighting inside doesn't really offer the chance for good photos. Wander through the park areas, relax, and take in the views :)
Absolutely beautiful. This is a completely beautiful place to walk around. The church is historic and elegant, and well worth the visit. Be sure to sit down in the park and take it all in.

Time to kill in Prague?....chill and relax in its soothing gardens. If you are in Prague for more than 2 days, its a nice place to go, walk, relax, read books or do nothing! Metro leaves you right next to it and then you should enjoy a walk down the hill, through local streets to get tram from another stoppage nearby.

favorite place in Prague. if you have not been there - then you hav't been in Prague.you should come here alone or with a company, in a fun or in a sad mood.landscapes, nature, narrow streets, old cemeteries, museums and the unique spirit of the city.

Really beautiful church and cemetery in park. My boyfriend and I were staying just beside here on holidays so we decided to check the park out. The cemetery is beautiful with some amazing pieces of art up as a tribute to those buried there. The Cathedral has a beautiful interior and admission is very cheap - definitely worth a look. A few cafes are around but we were happy bringing a little picnic and eating in the park!

Massive park-like old fortress. This may be a little out of the way from the old city but well worth the walk . This is a massive park-like area with a basilica (St Peter and Paul) and more . There is also a cemetery where many famous people are buried e.g. Dvorak . Being on top of a hill it also offers some great views of the city . There are several statues in the surrounding are of the basilica.
Walk through Vysehrad. This area provides a nice counterpoint to Old Town. It describes the early part of Prague history and provides an excellent vantage point of the Vltava River

Different perspective of Prague. Vysehrad is being forgotten by many tourists as it is not recommended anywhere. I love this place, its spirit, its view, its magic. You can see Prague from different perspective and I am sure you will love it :)

If there's good weather, have a walk there!!!. Hey visitors, this is Prague!Yes, Old town square and Kings walk... and the best known Prague classics are not bad, but the atmosphere in Vysehrad is totally different. Only a fraction of the visitors go there, usually are there people living in Prague.The walk takes at least 30 minutes, but if there's good weather, you will be willing to stay there definitely longer.Simply take subway C (red) line, stop Vysehrad. If not sure, ask people there. I've lived in Prague for 4 years, this is the highlight.
Lovely walk, nice garden restaurants. It is easy and nice walk from metro station "Vysehrad". Not so crowded as Prague center. There are sevaral nice garden restaurants.

Pleasant Place to Spend an Afternoon. Standing on the ramparts was very nice overlooking the river. This is a very pleasant park with a great deal of history and folklore. The church is very beautiful to take in. We really enjoyed our peaceful afternoon exploring this area. We were able to take a cab out here and then we walked back to town following the river after. If you have the time, it is a very pleasant way to spend your time in Prague.

Time Limited? 5 Good Stops at Vysehrad. You could spend hours exploring Vysehrad, but if your time is limited, here are 5 interesting stops you can make to give a short visit some punch.1. Panoramic View. Take Prague Metro Line C to Vysehrad. As you exit for the short walk to the fortress, look to your right for a stunning panorama of Prague's domes and steeples, the Vltava River and Hradcany beyond.2. Photo Stop at Leopold Gate. You'll enter the inner fortress through this 17th century Baroque style gate near the old moat. Quick pic here makes a charming frame and shows you've arrived. With more time, you can explore the casemates (the network of passages through the fortress ramparts) through an entrance to the left of the gate. Ticket costs 30 CZK or Prague card gets you in for free.3. Rotunda of St. Martin. 11th century Romanesque chapel that is the earliest surviving structure of Prague's ancient citadel. Walk around it to feel the history: looted in 1420, burned in 1523, damaged by Prussian bombardment in 1757, it's seen it all. The south facing portal magnificently modified by architect Antonin Baum in 1878 when the chapel was reconsecrated is a great photo spot and the symbolic frame for a moment in history at Vysehrad. 4. Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul. Founded in the 12th century, but reconstructed 1885 to 1903 in Neo-Gothic style with eye-popping art nouveau interior decoration and one of the most colorful doorway entries one could imagine in a house of worship. This is a place to linger, gawk, and photograph. See my pictures to get an idea of the beauty, including frescoes strongly resembling works by Alphonse Mucha and not to be missed if you admire that artist (who inspired the actual artists, Frantisek Urban and Marie Urbanová-Zahradnicka.)To understand what you're seeing, you can borrow an English-language information sheet at the entrance to read along as you walk through. There's also an inexpensive 32-page booklet with good color photos and an English-language insert that gives quite extensive details of the seven different reconstructions that transformed it from 12th century Romanesque to early 20th century Neo-Gothic. Makes a nice souvenir of your visit and gives you something to read later on at your leisure.5. Cemetery. For a Vysehrad death trip, you'll find a gallery of notables buried in the cemetery next to the basilica, many of them in the beautiful art nouveau Slavin tomb, conceived as a pantheon for national luminaries in art, literature and science. Alphonse Mucha is there, very appropriately considering his artistic influence on the turn-of-the-century basilica renovation. You'll also find the world-famous Czech composer Antonin Dvorak (New World Symphony, Slavonic Dances) and science fiction writer Karel Capek (his play R.U.R. coined the word "robot" and gave sci-fi its first example of an artificial but human-like entity). If the grim reaper isn't your thing, you can just snap a photo of the lovely angel sculpture atop the Slavin tomb and go away happy.There is plenty more to see if you decide to stay longer, which you may want to do on a beautiful fall day. In contrast to Hradcany, Vysehrad is tranquil and uncrowded. There are cafes where you can linger and nice spots (including a playground for the kids) where you can pass some pleasant moments with nature and history. This is the ancient citadel where Prague was born, and thus widely regarded as the heart and soul of the city. Whether you spend an hour or a day, you should visit here.

Great views from the walls. This place seemed to be more interesting in pictures than what really is. It is basically a park with monuments, a cemetery – where some famous Czechs are buried - a church and great views from the walls. .It used to be some kind of castle or fortress in the past, which explains its huge grounds and walls. It’s a bit out of the city center and it seems to be a residential area, so not much to see around it. We saw two restaurants on the grounds: one seemed to be expensive and the other was cheap, had limited options and didn’t look very inviting, if you ask me. There was a lot of ground to cover, but we didn’t feel like exploring more than we did, since it was a very hot day in July. Actually, it is quite a walk just to get to the place itself from the tram stop. We had five full days in Prague, so it wasn’t a huge waste of time going there, but if your time is limited, you should skip it. It overlooks the Vltava River and you have the chance to see other incredible views of Prague – and that’s it.

Great adventure. We loved it out here!!! It was beautiful and took a couple of hours to venture through the entire thing. Beautiful place! EXCELLENT for picture taking and a beautiful stroll. There is even a playground for the kids..and adults. Beautiful views!

Origin beautiful natural place of Prague. I went there in the early morning so, there are no any tourist just the local. It's the natural origin of Prague where I really recommend you to visit. I went there on Saturday morning because there is the fisherman market at the Valtava river where is near this place. You must visit then you will see local life and local food there too!

Relaxing and surprising. This is a excellent place to visit. It offers great views and it's nice for a romantic walk. Also you can check out the cemetery, the church and the fort tunnel for a small fee.
Highly recommend.

Read learn and ponder ourelders errors intranquilsettings.. A touching memorial to the horrible treatment handing out to the brave Czech people by both the Nazis & the former USSR Communists in and after the Second World War with useful displays to read and beautiful well kept and tranquil garden to ponder man's inhumanity to his/her fellow man. Not far from the astlesowortha detour.

Vysehrad. This site is a short metro (subway) ride. When taking the metro to this site you will use the C (red) line. My hotel Park hotel, had a machine that dispensed the ticket there. Taking the metro is the best way to go, be wise of the taxis my hotel told me they like to take advantage of tourist. This ride took all of minutes. When leaving the metro you will go out the doors and walk up steps to the outdoors. Follow the walk and you will see signs directing you to this site. There is a lot of walking involved with this site, so make sure to have your walking shoes on. There are also several gift shops along the way as well as small cafes. This site can take as long as you want to take, there is the church of St. Peter and St. Paul, many statues, cemetery, many sites overlooking the river. Lots of places to take great pictures. In the church of St. Peter and St. Paul there is a small fee to enter, and you may take pictures. This is a self tour. The grounds of the cemetery is also self toured, no fee and you are allowed to take pictures.

Surprise Walk. Our hotel overlooked Fortress walls so we decided to go for a walk to see what was there,what a surprise,historic church and cemetery of notable czech subjects,some lovely cafes but best of all superb scenic views in all directions from ramparts of Vltava river and Prague.
Very impportent. Very important place for visit. Excellent view of church and wall. Beautiful panoramatic view on river.

Beautiful area. What a contrast to Prague castle. It is far quieter and lovely to walk the grounds. The views are spectacular from the castle grounds. We used the metro to get here and walked a short distance There are signs that easily guide you to the area. If you have time it is a nice change to visit this part of the city.
Visit pragues other castle.. Highly recommend. In many ways more lovely that St vitus and much less crowded. Beautiful frescoes, very interesting grave site, lovely grounds.

A little getaway. It's a bit out of the way and getting there takes some consideration, but this is well worth the time and effort. This is really a park above the city with ruins, church, snack bars, bathrooms, gardens and trails. Take the train because it is above the bluff. Walk down to the tram on the river to get back.

Go even further back in history. The first time I visited Vyseherad was back in the fall of 1990, only a short time after the Velvet revolution, and it was then as now pretty bare. Bare but non the less impressive, because what you don't see you can surely imagine, and there are enough remains there for you to construct what's missing on top of them and perceive the full glory. Then there is the setting, high upon a hill right up from the river, it is easy to see why it was an obvious choice for the earliest (?) fortifications in Prague. Bring a picnic basket, and enjoy the splendid views and the strong feel of history that permeats this place. I have been back many times since that first visit 25 years ago, and never seem to tire of it.

Do not miss the cemetery!. It is a beautiful place to visit. The view of the city is breathtaking. The cemetery at this location is as interesting as Père Lachaise in Paris. The statues are very unique. Do not miss the tomb stone with two hands sticking out of a pillar.

Best for romantic walk. This is an easy stroll ideally from Vyšehrad metro station, and you end up down by Vltava river. Apart from gothical church, there is a cemetery with graves of most famous persons of Czech history. Some people connect it with a outdoor theater,which shows Hradčany background, I prefer pub "na Hradbách", where you can sit with your beer outside and watch Prague´s beautiful panorama.

Less visited but splendid views!. Not too many people visit Vysehrad as most gun for Prague Castle. This complex is accessible by metro (stop by same name) and offers splendid views of the city and the river. It has a tranquil feel to it and is great to walk around without much crowd. There is a lovely church in the park that one can visit (entry 2 euros).It is not full of attractions as Prague Castlle or Pražský Hrad but defnitely worth a trip. We intended to spend less than an hour and ended up spending over two because we stopped for so many snaps of the view.
so peaceful. We always make a point of coming here when we are in Prague; the grounds are lovely and the views of the city and river are great.
Nice place. Nice place, very green, and not so crowded as the other districts in Prague. I highly recommend to visit premises fo Wyszehrad.
Peaceful. A hidden tranquil area with lots to see. Basilica is lovely and views add to the visit. Weekdays are quiet with very few visitors.

Only 2 metro stops from Old Town Prague - and well worth it. It was great to get out of the super crowded old town city center packed with tourists to this relative oasis of cultural tourism. It's only two metro stops from the main tourist area in Old Town and it's so much calmer - OMG. I felt like I was stepping back in time seeing and touching old, medieval walls, the basilica and the cemetery. I really recommend doing this.

Unexpected charming place. Spent the morning walking around this peaceful place. The park, the church, the walls, the views... Perfect way to get away from the bustle of the city and enjoy some history and nature...

A nice monument. We spent a few hours walking around the Vysehrad Monument. The park is beautiful. We were lucky to see 2 weddings while we were there. We took the metro to the monument, but wish we had taken the public ferry - I think that would have been more enjoyable.

wonderful visit. We enjoyed a peaceful walk along the river, saw the dancing buildings and then went up some stairs to reach this fantastic place. The church is beautifully decorated, the cemetery is interesting, and the grounds are extremely peaceful and not crowded at all. Several places to eat lunch up there, or bring a picnic lunch. We went on a Saturday, and there was an extensive farmers' market along the river. After our visit, we walked about 7 minutes to catch the metro back to the new town, which was a quick ride. Agree with the many reviews that this is a hidden gem.

An unexpected gem!. If you like taking scenic routes with fabulous views, this is the place for you!The church in the middle of the park is beautiful, there's a small playground und the view to the vlatava river is amazing!

Lovely place, especially in nice weather. So lovely place to go to. This place has amazing view of the river Vltava, cemetery of many famous people, one of hundreds churches in Prague, very friendly and cheap pub with many seats outside and large area of grass to lay on and many paths to walk on.

Nice Park with Historic Overlay. We went here to get away from the hustle of the city and to find out more about the Czech people. It did not disappoint. The stroll along the top of the walls overlooking the river was a perfect mild weather activity. The park was lovely. The four statues next to the church were also very interesting, but we wished more interpretive information were available

One of the symbol of Czech nation. This place above Vltava river is really atmospheric, full of history, monuments and culture. But it's also one of symbol of Czech nation because there was first castle of Bohemian kings. And there is a cemetery where the best and most famous writers, composers, poets, scientists and engineers are buried.
Shouldn't miss it if you are in Prague. This place was very close to our hotel and we went there just to see what it is but it should be in site seeing list of everyone.

A magical place. As is the case with most if not all the western metropolises, Prague is saturated with tourists and has been seduced by global capitalism. But its impressive history, rich culture, stunning beauty and mesmerising texture shines through all the layers of cultural commercialism. And nowhere this irrepressible character can be seen so prominently than in the enchanting grounds of Vysehrad where the Church of St Peter and Paul towers over the River Vltava and staring down the Prague castle at the opposite end of the city. The Church was reported built in 10 century, but like many historical building it has had its share of difficulties and has been rebuilt a few times. The current interior was designed and finished in the style of art nouveau the 19 century. The Vysehrad cemetery is simply a work of art, with elaborate headstones marking the final resting places of many prominent Czech artists among them Bedřich Smetana, Antonín Leopold Dvořák and alphonse mucha. This is must see place.

Park south of central Prague good for an afternoon get together with friends or stroll with views over Prague. Vysehrad is a fortress built to protect the area from enemies coming from the south. Today it offers a nice park to stroll through high above the river and great views. There are several small bars/restaurants where you can eat and drink. Close to the entrance on the left side up a small hill there is a larger area with long tables, a small playground and food stalls selling barbecue type food and beer. It seemed to be a popular place for groups going out together perhaps after work or a weekend afternoon or evening (not sure about opening-times).

Please don't miss it. This was my third visit to the castle, my first visit was 19 years ago, I was traveling alone with my backpack in Europe and my hostess in Prague recomended this place I totally fell in love with the whole place, the church, the cemetery, the views, the pleasure of watching the locals young and old enjoying the grounds and the great feeling of peace this place has. My second trip was 12 years ago with my wife, we stayed there for hours and this year I took my 3 kids (ages 7 and my 6 year old twins) along with my parents and although my mother uses a wheelchair (difficult to push through cobblestone) and that the weather was very cold, everybody was so happy they didn't want to leave, my father kept telling me he couldn't believe how "tourist-less" the place was. So if you are in Prague don't miss Vysehrad and enjoy it

What a gem.. Missed this area on previous trips to Prague. So happy we made it this year. What a gem. The views are beautiful and the attractions are well cared for. It is an easy subway ride from the old city to stops out on the redline from the museum stop.

The befginning of Prague. To really have a sense of the beginning of Prague, this fortress gives you 'just that'. We were fortunate to be able to have a visit inside the wall as well to view six of the original Charles bridge statues which are kept here to preserve them. Part of the Vysehrad is the oldest building in Prague as well - The Rotunda

Very worthwhile. Far less busy than a lot of the other main attractions. Spectacular views. I can't help but feel a tad guilty contributing this high of a rating, like others, as this seemed like a spot many locals still enjoy visiting ;)

One of my favourite afternoons in Prague. Finding myself with a couple of hours spare one afternoon I came here to get away from the crowds, and it delivered on that. I enjoyed a peaceful and picturesque stroll around the perimeter, admiring the fortified walls and magnificent views back to the Old Town. There are numerous things to see within Vysehrad too, including the impressive church, and several places to eat. I must admit that I didn't stay long enough to fully appreciate all this, but I imagine you could easily spend half a day here.I find it surprising that many people get put off visiting by the supposedly remote location but I definitely found this not to be the case. It is only a five minute walk from the metro station.My lasting memory of this place is taking in the fantastic views on all sides. It certainly presents Prague from a different perspective and offers more than just a place to come and take great photographs.
Must see atraction in Prague. Amazing views from the top of Vysehrad makes it one of the most favorite place to visit in the capital of Czech Republic,

Hidden jewel of Prague. the place is quiet and perfect for a walk on a nice day, it offers history, great views of the city from new perspective, places to refresh, lovely church, old castle, cemetery. it is not far from the subway Vyšehrad oryou can walk up from the river, tram stop Vyton

Quiet calm place in Prague. A place a little bit far from the center so less tourists. But its also a pretty place with nice views on the center, the river and the castle. If you want to have a quiet moment in the capitale, come and visit the park, the church and the cemetery around the church (very interesting).

Impressive citadel. In reality this citadel is more or less a small fortified self-contained village with impressively high walls surrounding the area. It contains shops, restaurants, churches, chapels, cemetery, and numerous statues. Its elevated position affords great panoramic views over the river below and the city beyond. It appears to be little visited by tourists so you should find it a quiet and relaxing place to visit. To get there we took tram 17 to the base of the citadel and walked up the hill. However it should be noted that there are very few signposts along the way. There are other trams that go that way but you should be aware that have been some recent changes to tram routes in the city which many maps do not yet reflect.

Peace and quite. This place, which is a little bit out of the main area, is a hidden gem. You can easily spend half a day here. Special attention should be given to the church and the wonderful views on the Danube from the walls. You can get there by underground and a five minute walk. Sufficient signs to help you find you way. Alternatively you can use tram line 3 but beware there is quite a climb to conquer.

You have not seen Prague until you have been here.. One of the best of plagues kept secrets . They say oh have been to the castle old town etc, but not until you have been here that you have experience the original Prague , it is so open to the public , soo quiet and acceptable, views are amazing, and inside St. Peter's basilica is breathtaking, it s even with Notre dame, ant then go into the tunnels 10 metres below the surface and see the original sculptures of Charles bridge. I can go on, but, and so easy to get there , via metro.

Impressive!. I often come to vysehrad after eating at my favorite restaurant, which is very close, just to have a walk and admire the amazing landscape you can see from its outer walls. Many people don't visit it given its location, but it definitely deserves to be taken into consideration. It's just a short walk from the city centre (Max 15 mins) and along vltava there are many cafes where you can stop for a break. Totally recommend!

lovely place. The best place for me .From this place is so beautiful view.There is also good playgrojnd .But eating oportunites are very poor.You can spen thee all day to have a picnic or just lay on grass or sitting on bench..... .You can visit there church ,cemetery with famous Czech persons and more .
Maybe. maybe if you have time. I myself was not that impressed. After glorious castle and old town, you dont find this amazing.

More castle-ey. We just wandered around the Vysehrad castle grounds and enjoyed grounds and the views of the city. Its just far enough out of the way to keep the throngs of tourists at bay, but close enough that its still convenient.

A peacful break.... The tramway, direction the south...One stop and we walked to Vysehrad. A nice place to be quiet, see the town and enjoy to visit this old place, take a coffee, touch the grass and just listen to the nature...

Lesser Known,Mysterious Place. This is a lesser known area in beautiful Prague.It is a fortified castle with a museum with pre-historic connections,wide passages with large grounds & remains of a medieval Bascilca.It is a scene of archaelogical excavations associated with the myths & legends of the Bohemian kings of the past.It also served as a national cemetery for the notables of the Czech intellectuals & artists from 18th & 19th centuries.A good peaceful place to stroll around with some good cafes around.

''Don't miss this splendid location''. Situated in the nearby Corinthia Hotel, we had gone into the city the day before and had this morning to while away some time. The ensuing walk resulted in entering the district of Vysehrad. A small Tourist office were not good with their English but continue into the well signposted village, for an absolute delight. Superb views of the river and historical information displayed to good advantage. Worth a couple of hours of your time. More if you eat and drink locally. The Metro opposite the Corinthia is 5 to 10 minutes walk away. Incidentally the Metro is half price for those 60 to 70 and free for over 70's. Just have your passport on you.
Nice place. Perfect place for a rest after spending time in crowded city center. There is a lovely view and a few small cafes, where you can sit down and relax.
Less known but worth the visit. Leisurely gardens and cathedral impressive. Great view over river nearby and recommend cellar display
Back in time. You must enjoy walking a lot, but then the whole area is lovely. It is like a separate village. A jump in history.

Great for a long, quiet stroll. Large and well kept estate, with gorgeous views of the city and beautiful gardens to have a picnic in. Quiet - not too many people here, even in peak season. We strolled around for 2 hours without noticing the time. A must visit.
lovely to spend a day there. it's huge, with a magnificent view of the city and very off the beaten track. loved it! You can have a picnic there as well.

magical place. Vysehrad area is very special place with so long human history and so many places one coul see...what we like probably most was just space it self, nice and nearly empty park where we have enjoy our time, relaxed right on nice grass and later moved to east side where we have enjoyed great view all over Prague...make sure ro visit Takavarna coffee shop which is part of handycap school, quite unique space with geat vibe and very positive energy not mentioned great coffe they made there...
historical treasure. Our guide told us she loved to go to the cemetery when she was a child as there was so much beautiful art to be seen. We have to agree with her, it was breathtaking.

Well worth the tram ride from the city center. The view of downtown Prague from this promontory above the river is wonderful. The park has nice gardens, and the church graveyard contains the memorials for both Dvorak and Smetana. Take the #17 tram and hike up the hill. It is well worth the trip.

Great views overlooking Prague.. Walked over from the Vysehrad subway station just before sunset. There are some beautiful views and a couple of spots to eat or drink (we did not do either). Walked down the far end to the river to catch the tram #17 back to the old town (but stopping first to see the Fred and Ginger building).
Very relaxing place to visit.. Besides taking strolls through the park there are some great places to stop and explore including a church and cemetery. Very easy to get to on the metro.

Seeing Prague up there is different. Seeing Prague from up there is different it is the opposite side of Prague castle. If you will go there i do recommend to go up 1 hour before Sunset to get the max benefit from seeing Prague morning and night views.

You should not miss it. One of the nicest and famous places in Prague, located outside of city but close to metro station. Nice park with reasturants, offers niceview on Prague castle and Prague Charles bridge.
Very calm and interesting place. Quiet place with great views. Wonderful space to walk. Views of the river and the city are beautiful.

Just a unique history, and a amazing place.. Just a unique history, and a amazing place.
My advice is to pay for a private guide. It is well worth the money, and you wi'll be able to skip cues and get access to off limit areas. Ask for a private guide at your hotel.

Fantastic views and less crowded that the main castle. Did not go inside as it closes around 6pm, but still walked around the grounds and took in the great views of the city. There are several cafes but we ate at the open air Balkan BBQ place, which was a great find !
Worth visiting. Not much advertized, it's definitely worth a visit. Very interesting, relaxing and peaceful park on top of the city

the best view of Prague you can get it. situated on a top of a hill, the views from the top of Vysehrad's walls are breathtaking. the small cemetary is beautiful. imo it's worth paying the small admission price for entering the cathedral because it's interior is even more impressive than it's exterior. because it sits outside Prague's touristy center it's much less crowded than Prague's castle for example and makes for a very pleasant walk
Prague must see. Hidden gem. Lots to see here and no charge to get in. Beautiful Basilica to see for a small charge.A 10 minute walk from the subway.

Not worth the time. There are no signs or explainations, not how to get there from the underground, or when inside. There is alarge cemetary in the centre which is just what we want to go to on a family holiday. Take the time to go south of Prague to Cesky Kromulov. It's pretty, child friendly, and much more interesing than the Citadel in Prague.
Worth the hike. Absolutely charming area, especially nice after braving the crowds in the center of town. Cemetery with amazing monuments, lovely church, fantastic views.

Go for the views. Amazing views of the whole of Prague, great place to chill out in the sun. Not half as busy as other attractions with a much more relaxed pace. Just hop on the 17 it's a two minute walk although quite steep on the way up.

Old Prague. If you want are looking for a place to inspire you should visit Vysehrad. Quiet, solemn, it takes you back through history. Chill in the park, pray in the cathedral, think about the transience of life visiting the cemetery and enjoy the view of Prague. You will discover a new side of Prague!

Most amazing (free) views over the city. As I live five minutes from Vysehrad, I go there often for a walk or enjoying the view over the city from a whole different side. Great for people with children.

Way better than Hradcany!!!!. Way better than Hradcany Castle! Outgoing atmosphere, beautiful park, quite nice bar with drinks, beer, snacks and fast food. I've also noticed that the yoga classes was led, and was probably free! Great way to spend afternoon with cold beer :)
Top in Prague?. Forget Hradcany. Skip the main square. Visit Vysehrad instead. Less people, better views, lots of interesting history.
Off te beaten track. Off te beaten track with a very nicely decorated church, ancient city walls, a cemetry where you can seethe graves of Dvorak, Smetana and more. Recommended!

nice and quiet. A very relaxing place to visit with spectacular views of Prague.
Also lots to see here, a basilica, a cemetery and a church to name just a few of the sights.

Dont skip it. Far off the beaten path, but worth the time. Excellent views along the walls and down the river. Enter the main gate and go up an to the right. Walk the outer walls and around the entire place. Sure looks like an old fort to me. Walk takes you to the middle where there is St. Peter and Paul Basilica and the cemetery. Spent time in the awesome church and strolled quickly through the cemetery.

nice view, excellent place to relax-drink-eat. hill overlooking Prague, nice views but not spectacular. Went a few times as my hotel (Union) was nearby and enjoyed the open area with an many benches/bar/grill where also many local people go to relax during hot summer days

A monument with a relaxing garden. Vysehrad National Cultural Monument is a place with a church and a garden to relax. The stroll to this place is fun that you can see and feel the the old city environment.

tombs of the great Czechs. This place, holy to the Czech nation, was honoured by Smetana in his Ma Vlast. And yes, the Moldau passes it as well. And the great composers, many directors of orchestras and artists have been buried here. And that is only the burial ground, to begin with. Nice walks on the hill, narvellous views, eating and drinking possiiblities as well as the neo-Gothic church that is worth while. Go there by tram and take the short but steep climb uphill.
One of the best places in Prague. If you would like to rest a bit from the tourist crowd in Prague, try this semi-hidden place. Up the hill with an amazing view.

The Fort of Prague. For our first visit in Prague in 2013 we never heard of Vysehrad--we only knew of Prague Castle. It wasn't until our second visit when a local took us to tour the "real" or fortress castle of Prague: Vysehrad. It has great views of the city, Petrin Hill, and Prague Castle and you get the sense that it was a real and functional fortress. Prague Castle is a chateau serving wine; Vysehrad is more of a fortress built for war.

Castle without the crowd. Catch a tram a few kms south of the main square and you will find Vysehrad perched high above the banks of the river. An imposing fortress now hosting gardens, restaurants and pubs. Its a glorious place to relax with a beer and spend a few hours. After all, that's exactly what the locals are doing.

The REAL Prague castle. Unlike many places in Prague, this one still feels authentic. Very nice park, super-old cathedral and fortress, great view of Vltava river and center of Prague. You can get the idea on their web: http://www.praha-vysehrad.cz/lang/l2. Also a great beer garden (very modest / real stuff local people would go to in summer).
Hidden Gem. Not listed in many tours, but it has church, fort, cemetery, statues, park, restaurant and great views.

Really great view!!. So today I went to Vysehrad and it was a great way to spend the morning. It's not too large so to walk around it took me a couple of hours really but I did take my sweet time seeing every viewpoint and building the fortress had to offer. It would be great for people looking for a perfect picnic location in Prague.

Away from the city but try not to miss Vysehrad. A brilliant place to go to and the views of the city have to be experienced. It's cut away from the rest of the city - use the train to get here. It's 10 minutes from the Vysehrad train station and a very pleasant walk. An hour if you don't plan to go inside the cathedral.
Not what I expected but.... Great place for a day out! lovely and peaceful. Great if you like 'historical' tours but also if you are into walks in the park. Can't miss it!

Tranquil hidden gem - the graveyard is amazing. Set a couple of miles from the centre of the city, this place isn't the easiest to get to (a climb or a taxi ride) but is amazing when you get there.It is a large open space with very few people around. An impressive looking church, incredible graveyard and a peaceful square.The views from the area are brilliant and at night it's nicely lit up. A real place to see Prague from afar in the peace and quiet. The bar in the compound was also very friendly.The graveyard was the main highlight for us, with some fantastic monuments for which I'll attach some photos.Don't miss this when you go to Prague.

Lovely place to visit - has a certain authenticity/lack of tourist feeling. Lots to see up there. Feels like the real history of Prague. When I was there they had a wedding at the cathedral. The cemetery is one of the coolest I've ever seen (the one at the Jewish Quarter was pretty cool, but other than that the last cool one I'd seen was in Buenos Aires). I went down to the cellar which is super old and historic. The park is nice to wander around in. I walked down past the Farmer's Market along the waterfront on a Saturday and then up the hill to this park and it made a lovely outing.

My favorite part of my trip to Prague!. I went to Vysehrad on my first afternoon in Prague, and I'm definitely glad I did! The entire fortress area is really beautiful and offers unbeatable views of the city. I picked up a magnet in one of the small shops - and it was by far the cheapest souvenir (and the nicest) that I bought during my entire trip. Walk around the outer edge for fantastic photo opportunities and a very peaceful setting away from the hustle and bustle of the city. There are plenty of places to sit and relax on benches on in the grass, and many people were having picnics. The basilica there is stunning (although I didn't go inside - there was a wedding) and the cemetery beside it was also beautiful, with very unique headstones and decor and a lot of famous Czech persons buried there - there's a map near the entrance to show you who is buried where and the tombstones are numbered as well. I also went into the small museum that offers a history of the fortress, and I'd definitely recommend going in (for a small fee) so that you can understand the history of where you are. Overall, highly, highly recommend visiting Vysehrad while you're in Prague - definitely the most peaceful and beautiful place to go (IMO).

Peaceful. Of all the things we did in Prague, I liked this best. Quiet, peaceful, historic. The basilica and the cemetery are well worth a look, so is the exhibition of the historic fort. Great views of the Vltava up and downstream. Not heaving with tourists.

Views that are worth the hike. Though this is quite south of the other tourist sites, you can reach the gate via tram or by walking. The hike up the hill to the church and park are well worth the effort as you can see all up and down the Vltava River. Also, nearly everyone who was anyone in Prague is buried in the beautiful, ornate cemetery there.

Watch the history of Prague. Vyšehrad is one of the most stunning sites of Prague, with the gothic basilica of St. Peter and Paul (low admission fee), roman rotunda (which is the oldest building in Prague) and spectacular views of the river and the city. You can visit the peaceful cemetery where rest may famous Czech artists, writers etc. In a hot day, buy some ice cream or cold beer and rest on one of many benches, watching boats on the river or read legends about this place – about female ruler and prophet Libuše, founding the city of Prague, brave Bivoj or Horymír and his faithful horse Šemík.
Off the beaten path. The original statues from the Charles Bridge are kept here. This is a great place to get away from the crowd, enjoy the scenery, and experience some of Prague's history.

Jewel not far from Prague centre. Just down the river (or tram) from the old centre of Prague, lies another beautiful place perched on the rock overlooking the Vltava. With a number of cafes and restaurants - indoors and outdoors, plenty of grass to relax on or walk around and not to mention some wonderful views, Vysehrad is well worth a visit. It is free to go inside and wander around and kids will love the wide open spaces and huge playground. Worth a visit if you want to get away from the crowds in the centre, especially in summer.

Away from the crowds. With a free morning we wandered to this area. Found ourselves mostly with the locals. There is a beautiful basilica, but the most interesting site was, the Vysehrad Cemetary. Lots of famous people buried here, and it is an active memorial, some of the locals were there tending to the plots.

A hidden treasure in Prague. Beautiful, peaceful, quiet, full of surprises. Don't miss the National Cemetery and its famous inhabitants and gorgeous sculpture. Go all the way to the top of the hill for some of the best views in the city.

Lovely. I enjoyed getting out of the busier part of Prague to explore Vysehrad. I did not go inside the church but enjoyed some of views from around this area. It is a beautiful place to walk around and just be.

Takes the breath away. I have spent almost 4 hours at this amazing place. Old cemetery, amazing chapel (and you must to see it from inside). The most important thing this place is not overcrowded, so you can really take a rest in the beautiful parks, squares and enjoy the amazing panorama of the Prague.

Walk throug Vysehrad to get energized!. This area was my favorite. Peaceful and beautiful. Wonderful views of the city. Fabulous architecture. Incredible gardens. The cemetery was beautiful, too. I wish I had a guide when I went though the area. I'm sure I missed so much. I did find a museum of local artists in the gardens. I was too early for lunch, but the café looked excellent. Quaint and rustic.
Great view and.... there is a kind of peace surrounding the Vysehrad area, which is amazing to experience. The higher you go, the better.

Beautiful very romantic way to spend a day there. We learned that Vysehrad is the Old City of Prague. We made a nice long walk from the hotel through a bridge. The view is amazing. We have seen 2 marriages 1 art gallery and a cemetery where famous Czechs are buried. The park was not crowded we met only few tourists. There are several restaurants we choosed a cheap one that was quite good. We spent a wonderful day there.

Off the beaten path. Not many people go here and I don't know why!! This was actually my 4th visit to Prague and my 1st time here. I can't believe I passed this up the last 3 times! Here you will be able to see a few of the original statues from Charles bridge as the ones they have now are replicas. Spend a few hours here... So worth it. The number 17 will take you right to it from the bridge.

Need to see in Prague. Vyšehrad (Czech for "upper castle") is a historical fort located in the city of Prague, Czech Republic. It was probably built in the 10th century, on a hill over the Vltava River. Situated within the castle is the Basilica of St Peter and St Paul, as well as the Vyšehrad Cemetery, containing the remains of many famous people from Czech history, among them Antonín Dvořák, Bedřich Smetana, Karel Čapek, and Alphonse Mucha. It also contains Prague's oldest surviving building, the Rotunda of St Martin from the 11th century.Local legend holds that Vyšehrad was the location of the first settlement which later became Prague, though thus far this claim remains unsubstantiated.

Perfect for a casual stroll with great views. The only downside is that for non-locals it's kind of difficult to navigate your way in and out of when trying to work out how to get there from (or get back from there to) the city. That said, it's only about a 10-minute walk from the Višehrad metro along a clearly marked path, and we walked back along the river once we did find our way out, so that's only a small issue. The place itself is like a giant park with the added bonus of ancient architecture. The church (and graveyard) are gorgeous and the views over the river are unbeatable.

Nice out of the way place. Just a bit of the beaten track so made for an enjoyable day.In olden days it was a fortification to rival Prague castle when the area was not all one.Now it is a large park area nice to stroll around and some good view points of the river that you dont see from further up by Charles bridge.There are attractions to visit some just taking a few minutes to do hardly worth the time.I could.t decide if this complex was worth a very good or and excellent but in the end I went for excellent for two reasons.First of all there is a very nice church with a small charge to go in , we wondered if it was worth it but decided to go in.We were glad we did because it had a fantastic painted ceiling and other nice decor .the outside was very nice as well.Secondly the Vysehrad cemetery was a very nice laid out area many famous Czech people buried there.Look out for the unigue way some of the dates are done on the tombstones.So if you want to get a way from jostling crowds have a nice walk around and visit two places I mentioned then its a nice way to spend a sunny afternoon like most places not so good if its raining.It is easily reached by metro line and you get off at the Vysehrad staion and its a five minute walk .

Charming corner of Prague. Ok, if you are 'doing' Prague for the first time, then this is not the most spectacular sight it has to offer. But if you've had enough of the jostling and pricey city centre, this is a pleasant and restful place offering views, a bit of history and a choice of reasonably priced cafes.

A beautiful moment in Prague. The ancient grounds, somber yet beautiful cemetery, and the breathtaking views made this a memorable stop in Prague. Away from the hustle and bustle of Old Town lies this amazing sanctuary where you can stroll through the open grounds, peer out over the Vltava River, and just relax and let your time in the Czech Republic sink in. Along the edges of the grounds afford you amazing views of this old and wonderful city. This place is not about shops and trinkets. Nor is it about guided tours and busy sites. Your time hear is a great way to get lost in the sounds and music of the city from its lofty perch above it all. Fun little side note there are Buckeye trees in many areas of the park. It brought a smile to my face to pick up these brown little nuts of the state tree where I live almost 4,500 miles away.

Would skip unless you are in Prague for more than a week. I was in Prague for 3 nights and I went on the advice of an article dated 2 days in Prague .the place is a bit far away from the city and there are absolutely no signs to point you anywhere .Yes there are reasonably nice views and I had the Prague card to see all the stuff listed in there ,but its really more for Prague locals wanting a nice relaxing evening out rather than tourists .Prague is a very beautiful city but this was a complete waste of our time and I would recommend skipping it .A much better choice would have been a second walk on Charles Bridge or anywhere in the historical center .
Beautiful!. So lovely. The most beautiful church I have ever been in and worth the small entrance fee. Large grounds to walk with gorgeous views of the city and a cemetery also!
Worth visiting. Great place to visit! Amazing nigt view of the rest of the city, although walking around is a little scary when not a lot of people is around at evening. ;))

So much too see. Save time to visit the Vysehrad Monument. There is a beautiful view of the city, an old cemetery, fortifications, restaurants and much more. You need a whole day to see it all. Spectacular!

Absoutely my favorite place in Prague. I lived in Prague as an expat for two years and of all the wonderful sights and experiences, and there are many, my personal favorite is the Vysehrad. The Vysehrad is an area on top of a promontory overlooking the Vltava River. It contains a large park, the Prague minor Cathedral, a museum that contains the original statues from Charles Bridge and the Hirbitrov, which is the national cemetery used for important Czechs. The views are lovely, there is plenty of green space and places to have a pivo (beer) and some nibbles and enjoy a spot seldom visited by foreigners. In high tourist season that is especially appealing. The Cathedral, which was restored in the very early 20th century, has small but interesting religious exhibits and the wall paintings, done in the Art Nouveau style are beautiful. Pay the small entrance fee (sometimes it is free) and wander around this lovely building and sit and soak up the beauty and the peace. It is worth the fee. Finally, take the time to really visit the cemetery. It is so much more than just a burial ground. The personalities of the families, because most are family crypts, are shown in the decoration of the crypt sites or the markers in the central area. The full spectrum of possibility is there from religious to wonderfully strange. I think many people just walk straight through and don't take the time to go up and down the aisles and really look at the markers, and that is a pity. Also, famous Czechs like the composers Antonín Dvořák and Bedřich Smetana are entombed here as well as the famous Czech artist Alfons Mucha. It is a magical place and not morbid at all.

fortified village. Very beutiful cathedral, painted all inside with saints images, which is rare for the catholics. Food and beer shops, not expensive.Not well indicated, I had to ask twice from the metro to the castle, in a 7 minutes walk.

Beautiful serenity!. Somehow Vysehrad is off the tourist beaten track - they don't know what they are missing. From the church to the cemetery where many famous names are buried; to the wonderful views over the river and to Prague Castle beyond - stunning; to the peace and serenity of the enclosed gardens - beautiful. Don't miss it!

Pleasant, but not much more.. It's a nice place to walk around, and a nice alternative to Prague Castle if you don't feel like dealing with the crowds. You can see most of it for free, which is always a bonus. The lack of an actual castle makes it a bit less interesting, though. The church is very nice, and the cemetery is interesting. Don't bother with the casemate tour - there's not much there and our tour guide didn't even speak English (a fact no one mentioned before we paid for the tour).

Good views but not much else. We were quite disappointed with this venue. It is billed as Prague's second castle so we were disappointed that there isn't a. Castle there! Some interesting graves in the cemetery but otherwise not much to see as we could not get in the church. We tried at various times through the day but it was always closed.
Park cemetery and church. Great park for walking and picnics, and then the wonderful cemetery and the marvelous church of st. peter and st. paul

Definitely worth a visit. This is an easy metro ride from the city and a great way to see beautiful views and sights away from the larger tourist crowds. The Church of St. Peter and Paul is truly stunning and worth a look inside. I really enjoyed walking around the parks and getting away for the morning.
Great spot for histoey in Praha. Great walk great history we used the Rick Steves Guide and did it in the evening The views at night were wonderful

Wonderful Art Nouveau interiors. The Church of ST Pater and Paul with it's wonderful stained glass and Art Nouveau interior is worth the cheap admission price alone. There were also lots of lovely silver and silver gilt goblets and monsterances.
A great place. An amazing place. Much quieter and calmer than Prague Castle and yet it feels it´s got much more character, especially the parks with statues.

Excellent. Wonderful park, brilliant view from Vysehrad rock, cemetery with the tombs of many famous Czechs. I'm very surprised by the Vysehrad church: it's decorated inside in the Modern style in spite of its ancient history

majorly significant. Visited this site as part of a wider tour following the parts of the Czech republic which inspired Smetana's Ma Vlast. Very significant and it is the place where Smetana is buried along with a number of other major figures from Czech history and the Arts. Architecture is significant and the place highly emotive,. Do visit. I went by car but there are undoubtedly other means, whatever it takes, Go!

A great palce to chill out away from crowds. The Vysehrad National Cultural Monument can be seen by getting the red metro route and getting of at Vysehrad station and then a 5 min walk.The whole place was so quiet and the views over prague were amazing.No entrance fee so walk around see the cemetery , open air theatrealong with a church. and enjoy a lunch in tranquil surroundings.

Views without the crowds. A friendly park with great views of the Vltava, no crowds. The adjacent cemetery has a large number of famous residents if you're into that sort of thing. An art gallery, a couple of restaurants, several large statues, And various historic buildings.
perfect locality. you can see the church build in 11 century + graves of many fanous czechs, including milada horakova, innocent woman hanged by communist in 50-ties

The old fortress of Prague!. You must find the time to leave the old city center and go to this place south by the river. It has 3 of the 5 remaining doors of the once fortified Prague and you can visit the gothic Basilica of Peter and Paul. The walls of this church are beautifully painted with frescoes and the bells at noon chime with nice music before the Angelus' bell ringing. There is a guided tour to the underground passage of the battlements used to defend this city's southeast outpost and the vault where some of the original sculptures from Charles IV's Bridge are kept for restoration. It's worth it!
Just beautiful. Nothing to say, just a paradise in a city because of green everywhere... Good spot to breathe and relax yourself in this big city !

The cemetery is a monument to Czech cultural history. In the cemetery there are so many memorials to famous Czech people who have contributed to the wonderful Czech culture. You can just walk in and explore, soaking up the atmosphere. I got a real sense of creativity, tolerance, diversity and unity. There are also guided tours if you're unfamiliar with Czech cultural history.

Peaceful, pretty and perfect Prague panorama. A little bit further away from the main attractions in the city, sitting on top of a little hill is a very nice church and graveyard, surrounded by a parkland within a fortified wall. You get a great view over the river looking back at the city and its a great way of getting a free vantage point of the city for your panorama and "selfie" shots (though I hate selfie sticks)There's a gallery and the Cassemat to visit also and nearby is a chocolate house and.... Wait for it....a toilet museum!!!Definitely worth a trip to Vysehrad though. Its quiet and peaceful and free (outside the buildings)

view to city. Recommend to watch cemetery and church. But dont eat at vyshehrad its expensive. underground dont cost mush only 30czk, but its only in chech and nothing to see, only long underground coridor and some sculptures at the final. nice place to view a sunset.entrance is free.

Breathtaking!. The view from inside this fortified city is amazing! The church and castle are great places to visit without the crouds, you can even pack a pic-nic as there is a beautiful park there as well. A walk through the cemetary is a must!

Well worth a visit. Vysehrad was recommended to us by our walking tour guide who took us through the Old Town. He thought it was the third place to visit after the Old Town and the castle and we agreed. It was a lovely walk from our hotel in Mala Strana along the river across the bridge and then up the hill. The grounds are really beautiful, the views of the city from quite a high viewpoint are great and the beautiful basilica of St Peter and St Paul is astounding. The doors of the basilica are just unbelievable. We caught the tram back towards the city as we were tired after walking around for the morning - don't forget to validate your ticket on the trams - we did!

Kingslike and beautiful. It is really worth to see in Prague! Not bir, but you wouldn't feel tired, when you decide to walk there. They have an impressive St. Paul and Peter chapel and mediaeval cemetery. The view on Vtalva river is also breathtaking!

Visit this site. This site has the oldest surviving building, the Rotunda of St Martin. The castle itself was founded in the 10th century, but most everything has been covered or altered to fit later tastes.However, the site is wonderful, and the neo-Gothic church of Sts Peter and Paul, built in the 1400's and covered in the last century, is an Art Noveau dream-come-true. You can wander around the grounds for at least an hour, spend time in the beautiful cemetery, an art piece all by itself, and then finish your visit sitting in the cathedral awestruck by the intricate Art Noveau walls and ceilings and arches, as the organ induces a spiritual moment. This spot is the perfect antidote to Karlova Street and the bustle there. Very accessible by tram

Minor Basilica. A fantastic spot. The church was magnificent with a wow factor. It highly decorated walls are wonderful. The cemetery is well laid out and the view from the highest spot looks out over the river with view of the city and beyond.

A hidden gem with beautiful views. My husband and I happened to discover this place while walking around aimlessly. Our hotel receptionist did suggest it to us also but we were going to give it a miss having not heard much about it. However we were glad we came here! With a bit of a walk, this place is nice and quiet with a church inside and a cemetery of the famous Czech. It has some really beautiful views of Prague with a few small eateries where you can grab a bite or ice cream and stroll around in it's park. It's not a must as many other attractions in Prague offer some breath taking views but it's nice if you don't have anywhere to be and all afternoon to just be by a view.
Nice walk. It was a beautiful day of walking around the monument and the surrounding parks. We also had a great lunch in a near by restaurant (cafe) which we found only by a chance (forgot the name).

nice stroll around the castle - close to nature. A castle with a nice garden and nice views to the river on one side and to the city on the other side. There is a church inside - need to pay an entrance fee though. The cemetery is also pretty nice.

Great for lazy afternoons when one wants to just relax, walk and enjoy great views...... It is a wonderful walk to do. Has a lot of interesting angles, wonderful views of Prague, churches, rotund, huge park and I especially love the Slavin cemetery. Most famous people of Czech nation are buried there, eg. Antonin Dvorak, Bedrich Smetana and many others. It is a pleasant walk when you are in no rush and want to get some exercise. Definitely recommend when running out of ideas of what to do in Prague.
Must see in Prague. This is very worthwhile as you get amazing views over the city and towards the Castle. There is also a graveyard full of famous Czech including Dvorak.

Love it at sunset. When I lived in Prague and on my most recent trip for Christmas December of last year, I often go here near sunset. Watching the sun cast shadows on the city below, then, the river, and finally looking back at the top of the church steeple catching the last of the sun for the day is beautiful. This area is nearly as scenic as Hradchany (Prague Castle) and a lot less crowded. The cathedral here is gothic in style and the interior is beautiful. A national historic site, many important Czechs are buried on the grounds in elaborate crypts and with ornate tombs. Yet another reason to visit as they're unlike any I've seen in the world. Poets, artist, politicians, the rich and the famous are buried here. I also enjoy walking the grounds and sitting upon the stones forming the walls. You will love it here.

Wonderful atmosphere and view over Prague. Wow what a stunning view over Prague! The graveyard is also a must see! So many famous artists are buried there! A park next by where you can bring picknick basket!

Pick a dry day for this one!. We really enjoyed this place - known as the "Castle on the Hill" It is really an old monument - no real buildings to visit but lovely to walk through the area, great views of the city and you can access the Church of St Peter and St Paul - for the price of a "donation" worth entering. Suggest enter the Vysehyrad location from the Metro end and walk right round the monument / gardens - through the church and cemetery exiting at the other end so you can use the tram back to the city centre. Take tram 17 and half way back along the riverside to the centre you pass right by the "Dancing House". Get off the tram and seek some refreshments from the rooftop bar!

One of the best!. We found Vysehrad Castle and it's grounds to be even more enjoyable than Prague Castle! First, it was less busy and more spacious. Secondly, it was more original and authentic than the more famous PC. We found it to be much more 'real' if you can use that term. It contains so many viewing points that you can see and take great pictures of different areas of Prague. It has great sight lines just about everywhere. Not only that, but the Cementary was truly amazing and a little creepy. Some of the pictures and statues are interesting to say the least. The cathedral was truly awe inspiring with it's architecure and truly great condition for it's age. I hate to say it, but if you see one castle in Prague, see this one over the more famous cousin. If you can see them both, that is great, but if only time for one, I would say this one!

Best View. On our last day we strolled around this beautiful area - metro line C Vysehrad and a short walk to the park. The views were better than The Astronomical Tower and St Nicholas Bell Tower. After walking around the tranquil park and we visited the cemetery and admired the stonework - Bedrich Smetena and Dvorak are here. Stroll down the steps and catch tram 17 from Vyton to Old Town. Take a picnic if weather permits!

Lovely relaxing spot in a busy city. My wife and I popped up here on our last day in Prague. We only had a few hours to kill but could've spent the whole day there relaxing in the sun! Had a tasty lunch at a cafe whilst sitting outside. We found our way up here by a bit of a roundabout route through old parts of the city. The easiest way to get here is actually on either the number 3 or 17 tram along the river. One of the stops is at the bottom of a path leading right up the hill to the main park. Well worth a visit on a nice day!

Different view. The day after you do the obligatory walk from Mustek to Staromestke Nam, to Karluv most and Mala Strana to the castle, take the Metro to Vysehrad, and walk west towards the Church, you will see it from a distance, Nice walk, check out the interior, but also the cemetery where the Czech writers and musicians and important people have been buried for generations. You might recognize some(Dvorak) and admire some of the stonework. Continue towards the river and enjoy the view of the Castle and the New and Old town, then walk down the steps and join the people walking and jogging along the embankment. Go north and you will pass the Gehry dancing house, the lovely Art Noveau houses, Manes, and the National theatre. Lots of places to stop and have a refreshment along the way.

Serene and Beautiful. I love that it's less populated than its more famous counterparts such as Prazsky Hrad. The cemetery is indeed lovely and well maintained. The church is gorgeous, especially the sculpture of the mourning Madonna with her fallen son. It's very evocative. The beer garden is cute and affords lovely views. Mostly you can wander off into any part of the park and you'll find exhilarating views, quiet, peaceful moments and few tourists. Maybe it's bad in summer but still there's places you can find to be alone. One of my top favourites in Prague.

unexpected visit- so pleased we stumbled across it. We had just arrived in Prague and hadn't decided on our itinerary. Went wandering and came across the monument. Fab views all across Prague and a lovely basilica, which we couldn't get into due to to our late arrival (6pm on Easter Monday). Really peaceful up there and great for a good walk and panoramic views of all parts of the city. Toilet facilities were a little rustic but not unbearable.

Best view of Prague. If you want to see all parts of Prague and a very nice view of Vltava river you find the best place. The best way to go there is to take metro line C and get off at Vysehrad station and walk about 500 m to enter the castle and park. The view is more beautiful than that from Petrin Tower where all the time is a long queue, or from Strahov Monastery where you have to climb up about 2000 meters from Karlův most.
Loved it!. The trip to this place was not planned properly for me but I'm glad i went because it is a great place to just walk around and the park offers beautiful view.

A peaceful escape from the tourist hordes. Whist the famous attractions of the Charles Bridge, Prague Castle and the Old Town Square have to be seen when in Prague, Vysehrad is a welcome escape as very few tourists see it. They are missing a quite large hilltop complex with superb views of Prague. There is a small exhibition detailing more than 500 years of history at the site, and the church is well worth a visit. It's graveyard contains many of the great and the good from Czech history.There are 3 cafes/restaurants on site, and the vcafe we visited was good for an inexpensive lunch.If you are good on your feet the 1 hour walk along the river from the Charles Bridge is worth it. If you can only manage one way, get a tram or metro there, and walk back to admire the views of Prague Castle as you get closer.

Great view of Prague. Must see place if you are a historical lover and if you wanna view a Prague castle from a different point of view. Very nice park as well for a picnic with a good and cheap Czech beer and grill garden restaurant....

Wonderfull!!!!. It is a good, pleasant walk near metro station with an excellent view!!!
.................................................
The best view in Prague!. Excellent old cathedral, old cementary, goaches view to Vltava, old and new Prague, Stary Grad! The best place for walking by old walls.

Peace and quiet away from the crowds. After 3 days in the beautiful but very crowded centre of Prague we wanted somewhere for a more relaxing walk and this is just the place. It's only 10 minutes by tram or Metro from the centre. When you get off the tram there are no directions but it's obvious how to get to the castle area - up! At the entrance to the site there is an information office where you can pick up a useful map (20 czk). It is free to walk around though there are some museums which you pay for (we chose not to as it was a lovely sunny day). A lovely historic location, plenty of interest including a Basilica and cemetery - the latter with some incredibly ornate mausolea of the Prague elite of a century ago. Add great views and places to eat and drink in the sun and you have a great day out. We were among very few tourists there, most people were locals especially families with young children

Wonderful park, tremendous church.. Best church in Prague, from my point of view. Great park and cemetary. Very nice views of Prague in the distance and the River.We walked from Charles Bridge down there, as it was sunny , along the river bank. An hour walk, but worth the trip, and so much nicer to admire the gorgeous buildings along the way, without being disturbed by traffic!

famous Vyšehrad Castle. Vyšehrad Castle is about 50 years younger than Prague Castle. The most famous ruler of the Premyslides Dynasty was the first Czech king Vratislav, who founded the rotunda of St. Martin, the Basilica of St. Lawrence, the Chapter and the Church of St. Peter and Paul. Now that Basilica is in neo-gothic style. At the end of the 19th century was founded Vyšehrad graveyard. These are graves of famous Czech people, for example: Jaroslav Heyrovsky (Nobel Prize winner for his work in polarography), Antonín Dvořák (author of the New World Symphony, the Slavonic Dances, Slavonic Rhapsodies, ...), Karel Čapek (known writer and friend of T.G. Masaryk), Ema Destinová (world famous soprano - featured eg. the Metropolitan Opera in New York), Hana Mašková (world-class figure skater), Josef Bican (famous footballer highly acclaimed as master by master Brazilian Pelé).

Interesting area. Very interesting church and the associated graveyard. The surrounding park gave a great view of Prague, the Castle and the surrounding area. When you leave walk down to the U Kroka restaurant for a good reasonable meal.

Quiet and relaxing. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of central Prague, this is the place to go to! This rocky hill in the southern part of Prague has been inhabited since prehistoric times. (Thus St.Martin Rotunda, one of the oldest and best preserved 11th century monument in the city.) Situated within the historical fort you will find the Basilica of St Peter and St Paul, as well as the Vyšehrad Cemetery, containing the remains of many famous people from Czech history, among them Antonín Dvořák and Bedřich Smetana.

Bit of a distance, but interesting. Quite hard to get to (easiest is by Metro Line C), but worth visiting for the fine views up and down the Vltava river, and the fascinating cemetery with spectacular tombs of famous artists and composers (Dvorak, Smetana, Mucha etc.). If you walk down the hill afterwards, you can catch a tram back to the city centre.

A visit at Dvorak´s grave. We adore the music of Czech composer Antonin Dvorak and so we always wanted to visit his last resting place.The cemetery where he is laying is dedicated to great Slavs and is well worth a visit for its fantastic Art Nouveau-Monuments dating mainly from the 19th century.Dvorak´s grave is adorned by a most elegant "golden shower".We went on a really cold day and it was quite peaceful. I can imagine the place brimming with people in summer.Leaving Vysherad, there is a glorious "Fine Cafe", they saved us from the freezing cold with their hot apple-juice!

A relaxing alternative. This place is very relaxing, quite off beaten tracks, but definately worth it. You can just walk around well preserved fortifications and enjoy views of the Castle and the river from there.

The oldest part of Prague. There is a very old and nice story about this place. Nice place over the river Vltava. There is a buryal ground of cultural celebrities as composer Bedrich Smetana (opening composition of Prague Spring).

perfect relax except weekends. This is a nice place, kind of a park with a church and a cemetery, good view point. One of the best oportunities for a little walk. The cathering oportunity is quite week, I can recommend a nearby Thai restaurant on the Vysehrad underground station. But be aware on weekends the pace is often a venue for overcrowded children events.

Nice view and cathedral. we were there between christmas and new year, very windy and cold but nice view and the cathedral was nice. They also have a graveyard with family graves which was nice to stroll around. (very beautiful gravestones and such).Since it was so cold we mostly went from pub to pub to get warm while walking around. hehe, probably nicer during spring/summer!
Valentine weekend break. Beautiful. Go in the summer and spend half the day there with a nice picnic. Open space, trees and take a look round the cemetery ....very interesting
Nice tour away from the crowds. Lovely cathedral and grounds. We visited on a cold day but still enjoyed our walk through the grounds. Biggest bonus was the absence of tourist hordes. Lovely

One of the most important sights. One of the most important monuments of Czech history. Peter and Paul Cathedral , rotunde St. Martin and Vysehrad cemetery where she is buried lots of famous greats of Czech history.
A pleasant escape from the crowded town centre. Well worth the short metro ride from the town centre. Drop into the visitor centre just inside the gates to pick up a guidebook.

Vyšehrad National Cultural Monument. Vyšehrad, a National Cultural Monument, at one time second Prague castle, a princely seat in the 10th century and a royal seat in the 12th century. Was situated at a strategically important place overlooking the Vltava river on the edge of the Prague basin. Its significance was understood by Charles IV who built a Gothic fortress here. In 1420 the castle was destroyed by Hussite troops. Vyšehrad Cemetery, resting place of outstanding personalities of Czech science and culture, is dominated by the common thomb Slavín, with sculptural figures by Josef Maudr from 1892. The architectonic remodelling of the cemetery and the design for Slavín was the work of Ant. Wiehl in 1889-1893.

Real Prague not so busy with tourists. This park feels like the real Prague and not so busy with tourists as the Castle and Charles Bridge area. There is lots of green space with fantastic views of the city on one side and of the river and bridges on the other. Cathedral, must see graveyard with ornate statues and tombstones, noted yoga classes on the grass, locals strolling, art gallary, old buildings, eateries (not abundant).

Off the beaten path. If you feel fed up with all the tourist buzz and look for something quiet but yet beautiful, with ancient atmosphere, take a trip to Vysehrad. Not that far from city centre. Getting there very easy by metro line "C" stop "Vysehrad". You can spend several hours strolling inside the fortress through the parks, have wonderfull views, learn some history and also find some reasonable places to have something to eat or drink.
The most beautiful sight in Prague. Day or night, you won't find more beautiful and peaceful sight. Awesome view in all directions, nature at your fingertips. I love that place <3

My favourite place in Prague. I am a long time lover of Prague and if you have more than a couple of days in Prague and you've seen all the sights, go spend a few hours in the lovely, lovely Vysehrad. The Church there is divine - a miracle of Art Deco. The cemetery is home to a few famous Czechs and don't miss the 1000 year old rotunda. Walk around the edges and see spectacular views of Prague. It will be you and Czechs up there. It really is a special, special place.
outstanding. This is very a very monumental place where you can leanr history of Czechoslovak republic in past. Possible to go on top witt lift from where you can see WHOLE PRAGUE.

Include in your Itinerary. All those who visit Prague will include Prague Castle in their itinerary and so they should. However they should also include Vysehrad in their trip. In fact I would suggest a visit to Vysehrad first and then go to Prague Castle to get a real feel for the history of Prague. There is a wonderful contrast between the old and the new here.There is a tram stop at Vysehrad and a short walk will take you to the fort. On your return use the Metro from Vysehrad to P. Pavlova (one stop) and get the 22 tram to Bila Hora to exit for Prague Castle.The fort is impressive in size and fortifications and gives a spectacular view of the city of Prague from a side you may not have seen. It is easy to understand why this site was originally selected. You will get a real feel for early Prague here. The interpretive centre is a must to visit to truly appreciate the site.There is a pleasant coffee shop serves excellent coffee but if you require something more substantial then try Rio’s restaurant above the coffee shop for a real surprise which will certainly add to the experience.
Panoramic view. This is a good place to walk, look around and explore art styles in every single building. You can make great picrures, visit church and cemetry.

My favourite place in Prague. An old castle complex, rebuilded into a stronghold hides a beautiful park, some of the Prague's oldest monuments, a church that resisted Hussite Wars and a nice pub with nice beer, nice svařené víno and nice panoramic view at the city.

Tranquil getaway from it all. I was getting a little tired of the touristy nature of Praha 1, and had planned to visit Vysehrad anyway. I was very impressed. The lady at the information centre was very helpful. The views of the Vltava river were amazing and the park was well maintained with food stalls and historical churches. I especially enjoyed the cemetery as a musician - it is the resting place of Dvorak and Smetana. Shame it was cold, but in summer it would be a great picnicking ground.
