The "Other" Castle. Fantastic views of the river and the more famous castle downriver. Don't miss the basilica and the accompanying cemetery. This a quiet place, well away from the press of the old town. There are some open spaces where young kids could run around, though no playgrounds. Stroller or wheelchair friendly for the most part. There is a gallery that contains the original statues from the Charles Bridge, but it was closed on the day of our visit. (Small fee for the gallery, the walkabout is free).Subway: Red line to Vysehrad stop. Then about 500 meters west and through a large gate.
Beautiful!. Great walk to get there but the view was amazing! Not crowded with tourists at all, excellent for a quiet promenade.

Escape the Tourist Madness.... The Prague Metro is easy to use and fun to travel in non-rush hour times. Vysehrad features a nice gothic church, a wonderful graveyard and lots of local families walking their dogs. You have great views of the city, calm and quiet and quite a bit of Prague history packed into a large area with very few tour groups. Small cafes for a snack or a beer make it a pleasant stop once you've hit all the hot spots in Old Town and need a fresh air break. Highly recommended. Take a little time to wander through the graveyard.

Away from crowds!. If the New Years crowds get on top of you, this is a lovely relaxing place to visit. Admittedly it was chilly but even so we could see the potential for a lovely summer stroll. Beautiful panoramic views, history and a vuiet very pleasant district.
Prague without the Old Times Square crowds. Vysehrad is one of the oldest places once inhabited in Praha. Nowadays it is a pleasant quiet spot with great views on Praha, Vltava, Prague Castle.

Fantastic historical sight. I loved this place. The cemetery was beautiful and well kept up. The church was very peaceful and I loved the stained glass. There is a great view from the wall around the grounds and you can just go here and sit for hours. We spent several hours wondering around. The headstones and monuments were more like sculptures and pieces of art. There weren't a ton of tourists and that was a nice change. There was a little snack bar or restaurant outside the church. I didn't eat there so I can't comment on the food.there was a small fee to get in the church but the grounds are free to roam around on.

quiet and crowdless. Prague is packed with tourists, and in this partiular place you can have some peace and solitude. It's got a beautiful cathedral in Gothic style and a big territoty to walk and explore. You can enjoy the beautiful views on the river, as this castle/fortress is perched high above the rest of the city. To get there you'll need to climb quite a few steps up the hill. Just walk along the embankment, pass the Zelesnicni bridge and on your left look for a small brownigh sign with the name "Vyshegrad".

Lovely place!. This was one of our favorite sites in Prague!It offers pleasant strolls through green parks, beautiful views, an elegant cemetery, and (yet another) gothic church (quite impressive, though).But mostly, it offers an escape from the tourist rush of the old town!Well worth 3-4 hours!

Great park with a Wonderful View. This December we went to Vysehrad the day after we went to Prague Castle. It's a park set on the site of the other major castle location in Prague. The views are beautiful and we loved walking around on the paths.The cemetery is small but houses the remains of many famous Czechs and the neighboring cathedral is very pretty. Since it was chilly outside the cafés were closed or deserted. It's very easy to get there by taking the Red line subway to the Vysehrad stop followed by a five minute walk from the station.
Stunning Church!. I loved this place. Peaceful and beautiful. I think it is the best place in praha.

A lovely stroll. This is a lovely place to have a stroll and soak up the atmosphere. It's a beautiful fortified area with different elements to see including a rather staggering graveyard! The oldest tower in Prague is also there. Apparently there were a couple of elements you can go into and look around but my Mom has bad feet so we tried to just keep to a simple stroll and felt we still really got the drift of the place. Well worth it, especially on a nice clear day where you are afforded some beautiful views up and down he river.

atmospheric and beautiful. We went just as light was falling. There are views down over the river, and Vysehrad rock (legend about the first Princess of Prague) It's easy to get to on line C Metro. We have visited often, and it's good at all times of year, or day. Beautiful parkland, cafes, and the church which you should visit, is painted on every possible surface. Also a cemetery where Dvorak is buried, which has beautiful statuary

One of my favourite spot in Prague. This part is slightly out of the way, but number 3 and 17 tram will take you there (there's a stop close to Charles Bridge). The cemetery in particular is amazing, and the higher ground in the park offered a great view over the city. Definitely worth going out of your way.
good place. This is a wonderful park and is a very enjoyable walk, easily entertaining for a couple of hours please we visted and loved it

Go back for it. This is definitely one of the places i would go back for, as i did not have enough time to explore it. It is like a separate city in the city, with its own cathedral and cemetery and even a school. It was already dark when i went to visit the place and i had the pleasure to admire the Prague by night - an overwhelming view, i could not take my eyes off it.

The other castle in Prague is no less attractive.. I used to live 5 minutes from Vyšehrad and it was a great place for a Sunday morning walk. My wife and I have minded dogs for a friend before and it is the perfect place to take them for a walk.There are lots of interesting paths to follow around a variety of different architectural styles and it is full of interesting curiosities. The cemetery there also has some very interesting grave stones and the cathedral building is a fine example of gothic architecture and dominates the sky line of the south part of the city.The walls of the castle give excellent views south of the city down the river, and amazing views of Prague from the south of the centre, and of the main Prague castle. We have visited many times and it is always worth visiting again whatever the weather.

Art Deco and neo-Gothic mix together. The outside looks like an ancient Gothic cathedral, but inside is decorated with Art Deco paintings! Many famous artists and sports figures are buried in the small cemetary. Nice restaurants on the grounds - walk along the cliff wall to find them.
Best fort. The Palace gets all the tourists, but Vysehrad, being off the beaten track, has great views and lots to do. A less frantic pace, with a wonderful national cemetery, church, etc.

I love that place.. small piece of history out of center Prague. Really nice place for small trip where is calm, peace and enough green space for families or bigger groups of friends or some home pets, nice view for whole Prague and beautiful cathedral inside with very old and nice cemetery. I recommend it.

Beautiful place. Beautiful place with great energy. One of my favourites in Prague. Definitely a must see - although there is nothing particular "to see". Just walk around, feel the energy of this place, have a drink with this wonderful view... or just be.

Enjoyable and away from the crowds. Great views of the city. Beautiful Cathedral. Small Art Gallery near the Cathedral had an excellent contemporary art exhibit. The Fortress is very easy to get to using the Metro. Enjoyable 2-3 hrs including the travel time. No charge except for a small entrance fee to the Church and the Gallery.
Fresh air, old sites, great views. This is a wonderful park and is a very enjoyable walk, easily entertaining for a couple of hours. Perfect photo ops over the river.
Magnificent. The most important place was the cemetery..with the tombs of great people..the tombs are masterpieces
Calm place. A perfect place for walking in autumn. Nice view and calm atmosphere. In the cemetery you can find many humps of famous czech people.

Awesome place. Very picturesque place. We climbed from the tram stop №17 behind Vysehrad. The narrow path under the wall of the fortress. Very impressive. Evening.If not for the light of the lantern - it would be terribly frightening.In the autumn of Vysehrad fine. Contrast delights of the fallen yellow leaves and green grass.Second time walked up to this point from the center of Prague on foot. Very impressive views with Nuselský most.I advise everyone to walk around it

Great day. We took the subway to Vysehrad-easy and well-marked walk from the subway station of the same name. It was great to be here away from the throngs of tourists in the old city of Prague. Beautiful parkland. The cemetery were many famous Czechs are buried was really interesting-Dvorak and Smetena are buried there. Amazing tombstones incorporating sculpture and art. The Minor Basilica was a treat-art nouveau style which was a welcome relief after so much baroque on our trip. The views from the ramparts were stunning. Great place to hang out and relax.

WHAT AN AMAZING PLACE. A little bit off the beaten track and requires a bit of effort to get there. But what a relief to be away from the crowds and to enjoy the peace and tranquillity of this very ancient spot and to commune with some of the souls of the dead, particularly the artists and musicians of the old Prague. and to learn that it was from here that the demonstrators assembled for the demonstration which triggered the Prague Spring. For my wife who had been in Czechoslovakia under the communist regime and had had a Czech boyfriend it was a particularly powerful place to be. Very different views over the Vltava. A friendly café. And a spectacular art nouveau interior to the Church. If trolling round palaces and museums is not your only thing, do try this lovely site

Perfect place for walking ans wondering. If you want to rest from occupied Prag by tourist, crowded streets this place is perfect for you. You will enjoyed view for other part of city as well you can have picnic there in nice sunny day.
Walk, Run, dine, view. Close to the hotel, kept well for walking, sufficient for a small jogging, nice view. And you may dine, there are nice pubs around.

Vysehrad Castle is nice. I ve walked and had jogging 2-3 times in the caste area, that is nice. They say that that is the oldest settlement in Prague. Not vwry old actually like 7th century. Nice places to walk.

no crowds, and no cost. Prague's 'other' castle is very different as it is a ruin, rather than an intact furnished palace. It is well worth visiting, the view over the river and the rest of the city is excellent. There are no crowds, and the cemetery at the church is fascinating. The little community north of the castle, adjacent to the railroad bridge, is a good place to stop for refreshments. From here, it is about a 45 minute walk back to Old Town along the river, or you can jump on tram 17.

Great way to spend 1/2 day. Without knowing a lot about it, we decided to visit Vysehrad with a friend from Prague since it comes highly recommended and was not that far out of town. Also, she had never been there, so it was something new for all of us. We took the metro and would have had a lot of trouble finding it if Marketa hadn't spoken Czech! Everyone we met was nice and helpful, and after a couple of wrong turns, we made it to the gate. This is an amazing place with beautiful grounds and buildings, great history and interesting sites - including the church and cemetary where we spent a lot of time. We can't recommend this place highly enough. It's close to the city, but appears to be miles away once your are inside the comples. All together, a great day.
Lots of tourists but worth it. There are usually a lot of people up there but the beautiful castle and lookout point makes it worth it.

Don't miss this hidden gem. If you are staying close to the main attractions this may be a little out the way and hard to find but it is well worth a visit. Great views over Prague and a lovely church and cemetery. If you stay at the Park Inn it is not far at all, looks for the two spires.

Relax off the beaten track. Vysehrad is not a building or an attraction that you visit. It is more of a park on a raised site south of the historical city centre overlooking the Vltava river and with great views of Prague castle (although a bit far). The quality really is that it is a fairly quiet area (although it can be crowded with people when the weather is nice or when there is some activity going on) where people just hang out to relax. The graveyard holds many famous Czech people and is well kept in an Art-Deco style. You can walk over the walls surrounding the area and have many views over Prague that you cannot get otherwise. There are a few places where you can sit and get a drink or some food, but for the most it is really a park. For children there is a large playground and plenty of opportunity to run around.

Somewhere a little different. A beautiful, calm location which includes the graveyard were the composers Smetana and Dvorak are buried. This was quite different to the bustle and busy-ness of other parts of Prague and give you space to reflect.

Second Times a Charm. I visited Prague in August 2013 and completely missed this area. I fell in love with Prague nonetheless and little did I know at the time i would return a little over a year later. I loved the city even more after my second trip because I was not confined to the old town and got to see more of the "real Prague". Vysehrad was probably the main highlight of my excursion. The Views over the vltava rival that of any of the most touristy spots, and it is large enough to walk around and explore. Also its much more interesting and less crowded than the Prague Castle complex. the place isn't completely isolated, but there are many just a handful of locals there and sometimes a tour group will go through the cemetary. definitely a breath of fresh air if mass tourism drives you crazy.

Excellent views of Prague. this was a pleasent surprise. we noticed this place through trip advisor and found it to be really nice. It offers the best views of Prague and has many things to visit within. The church within is the only attraction worth paying for. this place is well connected by public tranport.

Amazing trip to past.... As a local person i can recommend this place to everyone who is visiting Prague. You can't miss this historical site. I always take here my friends who come to visit me from the whole world. They are charmed by the remains of old castle and mainly by the view from park... Don't forget about this place during your Prague visit!

Peaceful place with lovely views . This castle was way out in the new town area, a good 30-40 minute walk from the centre. We went on a Sunday and it was a bit dreary because that part of town was really empty. Nothing to see on the way, no buzz of tourists or anything. The castle itself was actually lovely, with some very nice views and gardens. Autumn was a great time to go, with all the golden leaves covering the area. A beautiful cemetery lies inside alongside a basilica. The hilltop location actually makes this a worthwhile visit. I would definitely take the bus or metro next time. The walk there is quite long and rather unremarkable, even alongside the river

One of my favorite places in Prague.. You are in the middle of a busy city but you would not know it. There are old castle ruins, an beautiful church and a graveyard with Czech luminaries. Surrounded by a park. It's a lovely place to relax.

Place to see. if you're searching for a piece and quiet in the middle of the busy, tourist's filled city. We spent a nice afternoon, walking through the cemetery where most of the Czech famous artists, composers, writers, actors and singers are laid to rest. A nice lesson of Czech history right there. We enjoyed the view from the Vysehrad mountain.

Always loved the view, but it needs a little planning to get here.... Most of the "must see places" are in walking distance from the Prague's center. Vysehrad is a little bit out of the way, but definitely a sight to visit if you have the time. The dominant spires belong to the St.Peter and Paul Church. The rotunda of St. Martin dates back to 10th century. Not much is left from the castle, but the complex covers beautifully kept large park and a very famous cemetery, with the most beautiful gravestones and sculptures. Many famous and prominent czech people are buried there, among them Dvorak, Smetana and Mucha. Also other famous composers and writers whose names will be recognized by the younger generation.The church is worth visiting, but there is a fee and hours may change in the fall. Refreshments and restrooms were available.If you really have a lot of time you can reach it by walking on the riverbank, perhaps starting at the National theater and then climb the steep steps uphill - mostly for the young and fit:)The views are amazing at any time, but sunset was my favorite time to visit. You really get the best view off the river and all the bridges from this rocky hill. Hradcany in the distance dominates the spectacular view...

Quiet & serene, must visit. It is a quiet and nice place away from city centre crowds and reachable by metro. Spend some alone time in the gardens, allow kids to run around in the greens. There is an Old church and Russian Cemetry to visit. A small park is also tucked away near entrance for kids. Overall must visit.

Don't miss. Although off the beaten touristic path, it's well worthwhile to go out of your way to make sure you see this park!We walked there from our hotel in Republic Square and it was a nice easy walk along the riverside . Also, it's close to a metro station. The park is beautiful and the ramparts provide an amazing sight of the city and the river. As the entrance is free, it's a great way to spend a lazy few hours in this romantic setting.

Beautiful site. This beautiful site with very nice views is just 5 tram stops from Charles Bridge and several minutes walking uphill. Once there you can take a walk around its defense walls and get nice views of Prague.

not a typical tourist plays. It's a little bit out of the city center, but close to metro station. National cemetery is probably interesting place for czechs but garden bar is great place for all young people.

Beautiful park. This park is out of the centre, though close to the metro. It is peaceful and beautiful and well worth a visit. There is a lovely church, and a very interesting and well designed graveyard. The views from the ramparts across the river and the valley are some of the best in Prague.

magnificient view of Prague. This place offers a better view of Prague than the one from the castle. Not crowded and less obstructed by trees, it gives a panoramic view of the city, and of the Vltava river. The church is not as elaborated as the other ones in Prague, but the view from the encircling rampart , especially the one on the left side close to the vineyards and the small cafe provides a magnificent view of the picturesque river and the town below. The grounds are well kept, and you can spend hours strolling around, soaking in the beauty and serenity of the area. We take the metro to station Vyserad, and from there, the road signs will direct you to the monument.
romantic place. If you like a view ..you must to come to Vysehrad...really romantic place...loved the cementary..also the childrens place is really helpfull.

The hidden gem of the city. I think this place is overlooked by all the toursity "must-dos" that you always here about in Prague. Vysehrad is simply gorgeous and massive. You climb up to the top of a cliff to find a gorgeous church and cemetary, lots of parks and greenspace, and incredible views of the city.
Beautiful. Very impressive and fascinating. One has to dwell here for a bit to take it all in. The environment is busy and worth exploring further.

better than castle. We had to visit there in the dark. Eventhough we couldnt see everthing in light, it attracted us more than the castle. It is just opposite of the castle (there is a big distance between them off courese). People should begin their journey from there in Prage.

a UNESCO heritage site that is under the radar. A peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of old town Prague, this Park includes the neoGothic Basilica of St. Peter and Paul. We did not get to see the interior of the church but the architecture is impressive . The intricate mosaic work on the doorways alone are worth a long close look.The cemetery next to the church includes remains of famous residents of Prague such as Dvorak and Mucha. Headstones, sculptures , flowering shrubs and a nearby vineyard gives the illusion of a botanical garden. Views of the city and the river compliment the celestial ambiance, ideal for meditation, reflection or solitude.

Beautiful historical place. My favorite place in Prague. I really like Vysehrad with its beautiful view and the church with old cemetery. And not many tourist are here. There are some nice restaurants .

Nice restful place with good views and more. Bit of a climb, but the views from the battlements up and down river are nice. Not very many people there on a Sunday. There is a little gallery with works by various local artists, similar to my local church's annual art show.Most interesting is the cemetary; the final resting spots of Dvorak and Smetana appealed to me as I listen to classical music. Graves of nuns with well tended roses. Family (Rodino) sites in differing styles.We wanted a calm day with a younger person who had lived in Prague, we achieved it.

A must-see. While Prague Castle had a whole section in my, and probably most, guidebooks, Vysehrad was barely mentioned. Perhaps this was why it was almost deserted on a sunny day in early September.As others have commented, it's more a park than a castle, but some old walls remain and there is a church and a cemetery. The main reason to go is for the views, which are stunning. Many are hidden behind the walls, but explore a bit through an open stone doorway and you step out on to a balcony overlooking the Vltava for some of the best views around.

Romantic place in Prague, Czechia. Vysehrad is an excellent place with a nice parc to walk or just hang around. From the ramparts there is a beautiful view towards Prague castle. In the evening it is even more romantic place!

Hidden Gem - oasis of quiet and beautiful views. Having been many times to Prague we were looking for something off the beaten path. Its a short ride on the metro and a small walk to this terrain. Its a castle and historic grounds, but, surrounded by the old wall. So you can walk the whole terrain up high on the wall (not small, big park path) having the most amazing views of the castle, and of prague center and the river. The park itself is beautiful, many flowers, fruit trees etc. The church is also very pretty. Its amazing quiet and peaceful, nice clean air, a touch of history and a great excursion.

My favourite spot in Prague. I love going up to Vysehrad and wandering through the park. There are always lots of people there, without being overly crowded. The view over the river is spectacular. The cemetery is also interesting (if you like those kinds of things). Smetana and Josef Suk are buried there, along with a few other musicians, politicians, etc.

Quiet. A little out of the way of all the other major attractions in Prague, but that makes this place quiet. South of the Charles Bridge, just follow the main road down and you will find it in front of you. Old cathedral with a cemetery in its shadow. Great view of the city from the top, well worth a visit.

An Absolute Gem. Vysehrad might be my favorite place in Prague. The grounds and cemetery are incredibly peaceful and contain the resting places of some of the most famous Czechs. While it is a bit off the main path, it is a must see.
A hidden gem. A huge castle to explore, with its own cathedral, gardens, cafes, etc., its own metro stop, 10 minutes from the centre, and no tourists. Perfect. ;-))

A Beautiful Quiet Walk. This is a beautiful, quite place to spend some time. Out of the hustle and bustle of busy Prague, it is well worth your time to explore the grounds, the cemetery and the wonderful view of the city. Well worth the time, if you can find it!

nice place. Very pleasant place to stay and relax. This place offers view of the city, pleasant park to walk around or sit and old historic cathedral.
There are also restaurants and goog accessibilty by underground.

A Nice Change from that Prague Castle. This is Prague's "other" castle. While it doesn't have the concentration of historic and cultural sights, it also is not chockablock with visitors. You take a walk all the way around the battlements and never see a tour group's "lollipop." In addition to the battlements, it has two churches, a sculpture garden, an historic cemetery, an art gallery, beer gardens, and more. Saints Peter and Paul is amazing: Gothic meets Art Nouveau. The cemetery is the final resting place of Antonín Dvořák, Jan Neruda, Bedřich Smetana, and Alphonse Mucha. The art gallery shows off the works of contemporary Czech artists (you can buy them if you want).Vysehrad is an easy walk from the Metro station, and the route is well marked in both directions.

Half day visit in Vysehrad. A small town by itself surrounded by building from the city. Is a nice hideaway from heavily infested tourist place. I love the serenity of this place. You can access this place via Vysehrad station metro (red line). Once you are there, walk towards the Asian restaurant side.

Beautiful gothic church and amazing view. If you are in town you should invest some time to get out of the center and reach (easy to get by tram or subway) this amazing place on the top of a hill with gorgeous gothic church and absolutely stunning panoramic views of Prague.
One of my favorite in Prague. Beautiful views of the river!Unlike most of the tourist site, it wasn't overcrowded, which was fun.

Never seen anything like this - just amazing!. This is the most incredible cemetery we have ever seen. Writers, artists, musicians, scientists - people who have left their mark on history.Every tombstone is completely unique and most are absolutely beautiful and personal.
Less crowded. Nice place to bring a visit. Especially nice to have a great view on Prague, without being surrounded by people everywhere.

Wonderful Introduction!!. My wife and I had just arrived in Prague, late afternoon, staying at a great Guest House a short walk from Vysehrad. It was a natural selection for a short walk before dinner to take in the sights of Prague and to introduce ourselves to the Czech Republic. Its may have been the late afternoon light but the place was something of a scenic wonder that wasn't short on history!Pros: Uncrowded (hardly anyone around actually), great grounds, wonderful views of the Vltava River, some very attractive historic buildings (along with the Czech equivalent of the Cimetière du Père Lachaise in Paris), a couple of nice (albeit expensive) restaurants and great views over town as dusk settles. Cons: The Cemetery closes a little too early (19:00) particularly in summer and a cheaper restaurant or two might be worthwhile!!For my wife and I Vysehrad was a wonderful introduction to Prague!!

True old world castle. Everyone goes to Prague Castle, but not everyone knows about the opportunity to see Vysehrad. It is on the opposite side of town from the castle, but positioned right on the river. It was obviously a protection fort/compound from anyone coming up the river to attack Prague. The compound walls and battle stations are preserved well so you can really go back in time. One of the most interesting things on the compound is the cemetary. This particular cemetary was used to bury some of the most prominent people in Czech history and it truly shows in the extravigance of thier burial plots. If you have not experienced old European cemetaries, this is certainly a must-see!
The old fortress. A sense of history pervades this hilltop castle fortification. Yet a serene walk through the grounds and overlooking the river is always available.

Mostly Free excursion!. You do not have to pay a bunch of fees to enjoy the Vysehrad! The grounds are lovely and quiet with great views of the city. The highlight for me was walking through the unique cemetery of famous Czechs, including Mucha and Dvorak. Some of the buildings and churches on the grounds have small entrance fees, but it is not necessary to go inside them.

Quiet and peaceful place to walk around.. Historical place with lot of green and peaceful atmosphere. Brilliant view from its walls and beautiful historical cemetery to explore. Lot of important and famous people are buried there. Summer amphitheatre available with interesting list of plays. Recommended for couples for a romantic walk, for families and for single travelers as well – you never know where you meet your mate.

A lovely park with great views. We came here on the last day of our visit to Prague and it tied everything up nicely. From the top of the park - which is high above the city noise - you can see almost 360 degree views, including the favourite tourist spots in the distance. The cemetery in the middle of all of this contains some famous composers, including Smetna and is a very peaceful place to meander. There are also good facilities including a couple of cafés and toilets.

Fewer crowds. This is the castle on the other side of the river. Legend has it that it is older than Prague Castle, though archeology does not support that claim. There is an old romanesque church, lots of park to walk through, lots of nooks and corners to lose yourself in. I like cemetaries as well, and there is one here packed with the Czech elite from the last century and a half or so.

Stained glass windows like fragments of a kaleidoscope. We spent about half a day in this lovely area. There are small and large wooded and grassy gardens for relaxing. We also enjoyed the superb scenic vistas and the cemetery where the classical composers Antonin Dvorak, Bedrich Smetana, and Joseph Suk are buried. We found so many kinds of statues (from small busts to monoliths) and odd-shaped decorative headstones (from stone toadstools to towering marble slabs).At St. Peter and St. Paul’s sanctuary, there is none of the baroque bravado and arrogance of Prague's St. Vitus. Nor is there the grandiosity of the superabundant treasury at St. Loreto. The few treasures at St. Peter and St. Paul’s while not ostentatious are elegant. In fact, everything at this church in Vysehrad is tastefully done: the pastel Art Noveau paintings of saints on all of the pillars, muted frescoes of New Testament scenes on the upper levels of the nave, the intricately folded cloth wrapped around the thighs of Jesus and the undulating folds of Mary’s robe as she encompasses Jesus on her lap in the marble Pieta, and in another Pieta, this one wooden, the unusual portraying of Mary covering her face with both of her hands in quiet anguish. Even the obligatory baby angels are unobtrusive and miraculously attractive. The silver-plated altarpiece primarily devoted to St. Peter and St Paul, with the Crucifixion placed above high above them, while relatively ornate, is not gaudy.Perhaps it was the time of day and the intermittent cloud cover, but there was a breathtaking contrast between the ten intensely colored stain-glass windows and the subdued colors of everything else in the sanctuary. Each one of the thirteen-paneled spotlighted windows (three of them behind the altarpiece) gleamingly displays a different Gospel scene that is so realistically drawn that you think that you are a part of the drama. Right above every one of these depictions is a sharply detailed picture of the church’s spire. The top and bottom sections of each window consist of various arabesques that look like the coruscating fragments of a kaleidoscope. What a sight! What a marvelous way to spend a day away from the crowds in such a quiet and beautiful place. For us, it was a must do.

Amazing Views, Peaceful Location. I am not a huge history enthusiast, and I tend to find castles overwhelmingly touristy. However, Vysehrad was not at all overrun with tourist traps, gift shops and loud groups of people. Walking along the fortress includes a beautiful panoramic view of the city surrounding the river. There are several attractions in Vysehrad as well, including a fascinating cemetery.
Quiet place in busy city. If you need some quiet place just to relax and "recharge your batteries" from busy city, this is a right place for you. Nice park with old historic buildings.

Out of the centre, great for some green / fresh air. Have a wander around some gravel paths on top of the old walls, see the priory and generally relax. Nothing amazing here but a great contrast from the tourist trap stare mesto and if you have more than 3 days I would definitely include it.
Basilica minor. The church, the cemetery, bells ringing, the splendid views of the city and the river. There is a park and we stumbled upon some sort of festival taking place which was quite nice.

It's a church !;). First of all I wasn't aware of the fact that it's a church. It's a bit far away from the city center and there is not that much to see so you might consider selecting something else to see if you don't have much time in Prague.

A surprising slightly out-of-the-way place. Everything was wonderful at this easy to access but slightly out-of-the-way place. Little mini Basilica of Peter and Paul was so incredibly beautiful, the cemetery was so interesting, and there was even an excellent little art gallery. Views of the city are stunning from here

WOW. Wow, we were living next to it, visited it and it's nice. Theres a part where you can get fantastic pictures of the vltava river(not facing the town center)..
Church is also very ornate and nice with a interesting cemetery around it.
Worth a visit. A very nice place to spend a couple of hours far from large groups of tourists and still doing some historic tourism.
Average. You wouldn't miss a lot if you don't visit. The cathedral inside is nice but almost same style as the one in Prague castle

One of best places in Prague. Vysehrad is very nice place in Prague where you can see all Prague and river Vltava from the top. There is also very nice big garden restaurant with very cheap and afforable grilled specials. Restaurant "NA HRADBACH" ("on the wall"). Vysehrad is one of the best places where you can make very nice pictures and photos with view of Prague Castle. And there is alo very old big gothic church and alo very old rotunde. Nice park..And connection is also good - Metro Vysehrad.

Three hours of enchantment,peace and beauty. History takes a back seat when you wander its emerald pathways and towering brick ramparts, with their dramatic views of the river and Prague Castle. The ancient, mythological spirit is very much in the air,allowing for your imaginings, as well as,your spiritual capacity. We started our circuit from the metro stop and went through the first gate, Leopold, from which bear right around St Martins' Rotunda and the Plague Pillar,whose faces are as close as you'll ever want to get to the real thing. There's many paths and leafy nooks to explore,as well as, a stunning cemetery ,where the nation's literary and cultural luminaries are buried and celebrated.  The church we encountered,on leaving the cemetery is Saints Peter and Paul,an elaborate gothic basilica with detailed stone reliefs, mosaics and towering castellated spires. At this point a cool garden is what we needed,so into the Sculpture Garden we trooped for a looksie at the larger-than-life Czech mythological heroes. From here we climbed the ramparts for the best vantage spots... the city laid out before us with red-roof tiles punctuated by church steeples with boatyards,marinas and bridges. Superb three hours of enchantment.peace and beauty.

Lovely place for a Sunset. And it settles right over the Castle District, so it makes for some lovely views. But it is a little bit of a hike if you miss the easy stairs method, which is fairly hidden from view. But it is beautiful up there!

well worth a visit. the walk from the metro to the area is only about 5 mins through lovely gardens. Lots to see when you get there. The views are fantastic from the walk round the walls, and the gardens are lovely to sit in and have a coffee or a picnic. Cafes are on site, and reasonably priced. As with most areas of Prague, the architecture here is amazing.

Good for the neat green parks and the view. We enjoyed the walk though Vysegrad space. We got here on a Saturday hot morning and couldn't get something to drink until noon because all restaurants and pubs were closed so take some water with you if you come early in the morning.The domain is well kept, all green and neat. The hilly place is amazing for the view over Vltava and the city.The church has a 30 czk fee (a fee to go inside and pray?!) so we didn't go in. There are some other expositions or places you could go visit for small fees but we just liked to enjoy relaxing on a bench. If you can, have a blanket with you and lay on the grass at the shadow of the secular trees. I think that for this place having a guide is useful, you can learn about the history of the place about the heavy imposing walls, the old buildings, the succession of regimes over Vysegrad and Prague. Otherwise enjoy the walk and the view, it is a nice place.

Prague's second castle. We realised we had enough time on our visit to Prague to go to the second castle . We were glad we did , the views are great it is a worthwhile visit . There is no entrance fee and only a very small fee to enter the church which is also beautiful

Gorgeous views! A hidden gem of a sight in Prague!. We were recommended this by our hotel as a nice place to get a view of the river from above. It was a long walk but well worth it, as the views we got were magnificent. It would be nice to have a better restaurant to enjoy at the top, but otherwise this is the perfect spot to go to for a view of the river and parts of the city not often visited.

A nice half day excursion. This fortress complex is located a few kilometres south of the main tourist sights in Prague. It can be easily accessed by both tram and metro. One of its draw cards is its location high above the Vltava River and offers several lookout points with different views of the city. There are several brick gates, St Martins Rotunda and the Baths of Libuse ruins to see. The complex is dominated by the St Peter & Paul Cathedral. There is also a large cemetery with well tended graves. There is an interesting statue of St Ludmilla with several arrows sticking out. There is a small museum in the Gothic Cellars . There were a number of pieces of pottery, coins and religious vestments from over the centuries stored here, and scale models showing how the fortress looked over time. There are also various myths attached to Vysehrad, including one featuring the knights that were sleeping under the rock. It was believed that a lion would come out and roar once a year, and if there was no response it would return to the mountain. Otherwise if there was a response the knights would awaken to protect the city. It was also believed that St Wenceslaus himself would lead the knights. We skipped the casemates because we had just missed a twenty minute tour and it was another hour until the next one.Overall it was an enjoyable experience. The only surprise was that the complex with its many administration buildings had a more suburban feel to it than you would expect from a fortress.

Best afternoon we've had in Prague. The casemate tour where we walked inside the fortification wall to the Charles Bridge original statues alone was who the trip. But, I loved the park like atmosphere. Sitting on a shady bench with bird song all around. Then who wouldn't find interest in the 19th C cemetery with Smetana's grave among other illuminaries. And the views from the wall! Altogether a perfect afternoon without the hustle and bustle of areas like Old Town.
MUST SEE!. Beautiful quiet place! Wonderful for picnics, walking and listening to birds singing. Very nice and peaceful place not to far from oldtown square. Birthplace of the city of Prague.
Vysehrad. Worth the short metro ride to see tombs of some of the great composers. Tends not to be quite as crowded as many other sights.

Where locals relax on weekends. We visited Vysehrad on a Saturday in July, and it was obvious that were were among locals. This seems to be the place to come for a nice walk away from the noise and bustle of the city. The views from the (very high) fortification walls are an extra attraction. Nothing particularly "wow" here, just a peaceful place to stretch your legs and relax on a nice day.You can get to Vysehrad via metro, but the trams along the river get you closer (such as line 17). And if you take the tram, stop in at cafe U Kroka (Vratislavova 12) which you will pass on your walk up to Vysehrad.

A break from tourist areas. Long walk uphill. Beautiful view but not much to see when we got there. You can walk along city walls way above the city.The cathedral has beautiful Art Nouveau paintings that are worth price of admission 30 kr each).

Beautiful place to watch the sunset and the city light up!. We visited Vysehrad on the recommendation of a couple we met on an e-bike tour and it did not disappoint. We took the Metro to the Vysehrad stop and walked (about 5 min and it's slightly downhill) to the monument area. There is a map when you come in to the park and info booth. We expected to see maps throughout the monument, but there weren't any - so pick up a map so you can see it all!This was a very peaceful and beautiful park-like area that overlooks the river and the Prauge Castle. There are several places to visit inside the monument. We walked along the walls and took in the views of the river, we visited the cemetery and admired all the sculpture and beautifully kept gravesites, we visited the Cathedral and the outside statue garden. It made for a lovely afternoon. Bring a blanket and Frisbee as this would be a great place for a picnic and to relax a bit. There were lots of little places to get food and drink. The WC's by the Cathedral were a donation to use, so make sure you have some change.We loved this park so much that we went back on our last night in Prauge. We stopped and had dinner at an Asian café at the subway station and then walked in the to park. We made the first right and found the Beer Garden, which was full of people, which was full of people having a great time. It looked like rain so we headed further along the walls and in to the park. We had the most gorgeous view of Prauge Castle as the sunset and the lights starting coming on in the city. There was a concert taking place, and while we did not have tickets we were still able to enjoy the sound of the music with the incredible view. From the monument you can walk down some stairs to the riverfront and then it's a 10 min walk in to Old Town. Made for a very romantic last evening in Prauge.

If you have free time - definitely worth the metro drive.. I wouldn't say its a must, but if you have the time definitely worth it. Went with my 16 years old daughter - we had 4 days in Prague. Loved the peace of the gardens and even sat and read for about half an hour. Good break after all the city walking around. Nice church and gorgeouss view. SO easy to get there - was one metro stop from our hotel.

Peaceful Setting with Great Views. We spent a couple of hours wandering round the attractive park and buildings. It was great to get away from the busy central area and spend some time in relative peace and quiet. Vysehrad isn't on everyone's itinerary but it was recommended to us by a tour guide and I'm glad we made it. We used the Hop On Hop Off tour bus to get out there. There are some brilliant views down the river towards the city centre where you can pick out many of the famous landmarks and also lovely view up the river.The Cathedral is interesting if you like that sort of thing and the cemetery is OK to wander round. You could probably spend most of the day here if you had the time to spare but I enjoyed my couple of hours strolling round the pleasant grounds in the shade of the trees with my ice cream.

Lost on me!!. I'm not sure what the monument was! I never read up on it beforehand but had been told it was amazing. There was a map at the entrance to this park - which in itself is a pretty, relaxing area and has a great view of Prague, but there was nothing to explain what we were looking at or what things represented. We found this to be a problem a few times - given Prague is a main tourist destination, it wasn't very tourist focussed.

The place we like most in Prague. We were so happy to find this place. Away from tourist groups, and the view is so amazing. The cathedral and the gardens are beautiful. Perfect place for everyone who wants to avoid the crowds in the old town.

A piece of history... When you go to Vyšehrad, you should know, that it's a place with tons of stories and legends around it. It's a piece of a history itself. You can find some very nice gardens there, a lot of interesting buildings from many different centuries and some very special views on Prague.What a lot of people don't know is, that the view gets even better when the sun goes down and the street lamps goes on together with lights of prague castle. The view from Vyšehrad is one of most amaying night views on Prague you can see!That's why I've only been there about 2 times by day and almost twice a month by night :D :)You should definately try it if you have occasion! :)
An oasis of tranquility. The best time to visit this beautiful and relaxing area is in the morning before 10:30, just to not be caught by the hordes of tourists flowing from the crowded Old Town.

Good but not wondeful. The place is generally nice, especially the cathedral because the interior is surprisingly different from the outer gothic looks ( the admission fee is only 30 kr). The cemetery is interesting, too, but i'm just not into this kind of attractions at all. After seeing all the other Prague attractions this place seems, well, kind of average. There are better churches and better parks. Plus the view of the city is absolutely not good compared to the ones from the Prague Castle(Hradcany) and the top of Mala Strana. I would recommend going here if you have at least three days to spend in Prague, otherwise, don't.
Peaceful place. Peaceful place to rest your legs and mind. Good weather is advicible to visit this place as it could be challenging in cold weather.
Not bad. It looks like Glasgow's Necropolis and despite I prefer Glasgow's version, it is worth for short visit.

Lovely stroll through fortress. Vysehrad was very easy to get to by metro, and a nice short walk through the gates. We walked throughout and were amazed at the history - loved St. George's round bldg., the cemetery, and the views both of Prague Castle and downriver are the best. Spent about 2 hours here.

Quiet place to absorb the history of Prague. Vysehrad Castle and the surrounding district is less than a mile from the heart of Prague and is easily reached by metro and then a short walk. the quiet park area includes a view of surrounding areas and a variety of religious buildings, cemetery and the Church of Saints Peter and Paul.

Wonderful place. The architecture of this castle is amazing. It gives you feeling of this country and its traditions. It was interesting to see the change of the guards. We could see tourists from many countries there.

A great counterpoint to the more well-known Prague Castle. Vyšehrad is well worth a visit.. Three weeks ago I took the Metro out to Vyšehrad, and it was a wonderful and leisurely afternoon. I visited the cemetery, where Jan Neruda, Bedřich Smetana and Antonín Dvořák are interred. The interior of the church is absolutely impressive, I was especially impressed with the Art Nouveau paintings. The grounds of the castle and fortifications are wide and sprawling, the park spaces are great for lounging around, and the views from the castle walls are breathtaking.I'm so glad I spent a leisurely afternoon at Vyšehrad, I feel it's a great counterpoint to Prague Castle. Vyšehrad does have it's share of visitors, though when I was there three weeks ago not to the extent of the crowds at Prague Castle. If you have the time in Prague, I highly recommend going out to Vyšehrad, and spending a relaxed, leisurely day there.

Cultural. We visites Vysherad by train. A lovely fwe hours out and well worth a visit. There are a few nice restaurants serving delicius food. The church is ancient and houses many relics. The cemetery has the famous composer Smetana's burial plot.

Hidden gem - the most beautiful art nouveau church interior. On my third visit to Prague, I was keen to visit Vysehrad as it had always been on my list but behind the usual spots. I was pleasantly surprised by the peaceful gardens containing the original statues from Charles Bridge & the fact that there were no entry fees to the grounds etc. We then went into St Peter & Paul's Basilica which I think is one of the most stunning art nouveau interiors I have ever seen. A couple who worked at the church and were fans of Mucha (who is buried in the crypt under the Slevin monument in the cemetery) undertook to paint the whole of the interior in his style. It really is beautiful and well worth the visit if you are a fan of that period.

An unexpected gem!. We were staying at the Corinthia Hotel, a short walk over a footbridge to the fortress. We had been given a small map with a walking route to the fortress and thought it might be a nice place to explore away from the somewhat hectic pace of Prague's city center. We were wowed. The beautiful grounds, the incredible cemetery and the lovely church were such a pleasant surprise. We enjoyed the views of Prague from the various overlooks as we walked along the grounds. It was such a wonderful way to spend our last morning in Prague.
Excellent. Excellent but often neglected attraction in Prague. I recommend not only because its beautiful views over Prague but also because really amazing Gothic chamber in it.
Amazing place to relax. A hidden gem. Less tourists than you'd expect. The cemetery is breathtakingly beautiful. I took more photos here than anywhere else in Prague.

The place where Prague was born. According to a myth, a wise chief built a castle here in the 7th century. Nearly everything was wiped out during the Hussite Wars of the 15th century. What remains is the wall, a peaceful park, several churches and a cemetery with the final resting place of famous Czechs including Anton Dvorak.Catch the metro to Vysehrad on line C and take the time to explore. You will be rewarded with great views away from the hordes of tourists. It's also a great place to relax - plenty of shade for reading a book or having a nice picnic.

My favourite observation in Prague. Very nice place! There is remains of the oldest romanesque basilica, ancient bridge (X century), beautiful neo-gothic church with awesome bell. Special attention for National cemetery near the church - there are greatest Czech citizens buried here.My favourite place for observe is situated contrariwise

Peace and quiet away from the tour groups. What a lovely haven of peace and quiet in Prague. Caught the metro to the top and then took a steady walk down to the river. The views from the top are lovely and Vysehrad is well worth a visit whilst in Prague.

Awesome views. This is an area of town that often gets missed as it is a bit away from the centre, but it really is worth a visit to see the magnificent church, all the crypts and as you walk around the whole area you keep getting magnificent views of different parts of the city. well worth the extra walk to go and see.

Peaceful sanctuary, great views. From the river you have to go uphill to get here, but its much quieter than other places so near Prague 1. Superb views over the river, and excellent history to browse in the hilltop parks and gardens, and the wonderfully maintained cemetery of famous local people. Find out where it all began.There are refreshments. I was drawn back here several times.

Original and Magnificent Charles Bridge Statues Here!. Vysehrad is definitely worth seeing in general. I want to highlight, however, the casemates. They are located in the Brick Gate, which is at sort of the far end of the castle off Pevnosti. A guide is on duty and leads you on a tour. Each tour starts on the hour and lasts about 20 to 30 minutes. The ticket office is a little hard to find. It is on the left side of the arch under the Brick Gate. A sign is posted on the outside door, saying when the next tour will start. The price is cheap (30 crowns for an adult and 20 for a student or child). Although the place will seem deserted, do not give up. The guide is definitely there, either inside the office or outside sitting on a bench, and he gives the tours. He speaks hardly any English but is very friendly and helpful. He will lead you down some lighted corridors, then take you into a large room. When the lights are turned on there, you will see five or six stunning, well-preserved statues that date from the early 1700s. They are the originals from the Charles Bridge. We were blown away by their beauty and especially appreciated being able to see (and photograph) these icons of Czech history and culture. The guide's friendliness and humility made the whole experience THE highlight of our visit to Prague. One should not miss seeing these statues!

Vysehrad Fortress Monument. Vysehrad felt as if I walked into a Fortress and a Kingdom at the same time. It dates back to the 9th Century at the time when the Premyslid Dynasty was established into Prague. It is now a Park with some statues and monuments but it is actually a kingdom where people that existed close to a millillium years have walked these grounds before us.
Don't miss Vysehrad. Great walk through the neighbourhoods to Vyšehrad . Beautiful views, lovely grounds, Church, and cemetery. Well worth the walk.

a beautiful and peacful park. the castle at Vyshrad was built about 150 years after the prague castle and little of id actully made it to this day. the beautiful (but not as big) cathedral is well preserved and still used for ceremonies. the park is clean, quite, full of small cafes and places to get a beer. it has a great view from the east side of the river to the south (a sight you probably won't see in any other place) and west of the river. great place to sit in the sun, relax, even take a nap on the grass of just walk on the ancient walls. there is also a galerry near by
Nice for a walk. If you enjoy nice walks, you must go there. The place is romantic and offers great views over the river and the city. You will just love it.

Awesome. Right next door to the congress centre. This amazing monument is a must. Whether to walk around the fortress and the old castle walls, the visit the church or to look at the river.Definitely a must do in Prague

Great way to spend a morning. This (free) ancient fortress is where many Prague residents spend lazy summer days. Fantastic views over the river and the city and the monument is very well preserved. It's a minor detour away from most of the Prague attractions but well worth the effort. Take the metro there to avoid walking up the hill and walk back down and along the river for more great views.

Where Prague started. Prague is a wonderful City and the main tourist attractions are a must to see, but this location dates back to the origins of the city. It is well off the tourist track although the discerning few found their way to it. It is so peaceful, with extensive wooded grounds and a beautiful church as a centrepiece. It is surrounded by high brick walls topped with earthen mounds to create a well protected site. It can be reached by Metro via Vsehrad station and is well worth a visit.
Beautiful view over Prague. Have visited Vysehrad several times. Most convenient take a Pragues metro and walk through green parks. Amazing view over all city.
Go there as early as you can. if you want to have a peaceful time, uninterrupted by other people. The cemetry is amazing and looks more like a museum more than anything else

Peaceful in Prague!. We walked in quiet pleasure along beautifully maintained paths, hearing little other than Czech from our fellow visitors. A wonderful Sunday morning with views to match, and great photographic opportunities in every direction.We saw the graves of Smetana and Dvorak - the bronze sign at the entrance to the graveyard made finding them very easy.The only downside to this lovely day was the problems we had in buying a "Senior" day ticket from the Metro station at Starometska. We had insufficient coins for the automat, so we went to the ticket office. The official there told us we could only buy them from the automat; if we had no coins we should buy them from a Tabak above ground. There we had to pay the full price. Call that a TICKET office??
A lovely quiet spot for a chill out sit in the sunshine. Not many people make it this far on a weekend in Prague but we love it. Very quiet and a great place to chill out in the sunshine.

I hope in more. Nice place but prices was terrible . I understund , that this is monument place but still so much on coffe etc. We have beeen here for lunch but we didint eat well. I was disappointed.

Amazing silence and view on Sunday morning.. We went there in the morning, it was nice sunny day, and the Vysehrad was only few steps from our nice apartment in the Emma Apartments, where we were accommodated. We love it there,the church is great inside, the view from the walls to the city was breathtaking and our children were happy on the playground and in the park too. This is not a massive touristic place, this is heaven on earth.

Hidden gem with great views. This is a great place to go during summers or warmer weather... not that many tourists visit Vysehrad and they are missing out! You can have a nice walk on top of the old castle walls with great views of Prague and the river. You should not miss it!

Great church, interesting cemetery, great garden. Try not to miss . Many famous people are buried in Vyshegrad cemetery. The church next to it is just stunning. View from the gardens to the Vltava and the city of Prague are spectacular. The walk up to the church, gardens etc is interesting. They have a gallery as well. It is small and when we visited it had a small exhibition of paintings by a local artist. That was too small to be of interest.

Nice views and a good park. Very nice views over the city and a nice church and cemetery with nice park. We liked it, it's a very good alternative for Petrin hill, if you don't want to go to Petrin tower or funicular.

A Day Out Of The City. Vysehrad, easily reachable by metro from central Prague, is the ancient capitol of the first Bohemian kings, predating Prague and the Castle by hundreds of years. Although there's not much left from those times to see today, Vysehrad is more like a beautifully maintained park surrounded by the ancient city walls, from the promenade on top of which you can enjoy stunning views of the river and central Prague just upstream. Vysehrad also contains Prague's "society cemetery", in which are buried such luminaries as Antonin Dvorak and Karel Kapek and which offers some stunning funerary sculptures. The basilica of Saints Peter and Paul dominates the park and is worth a visit for its baroque ornamentation. Highly recommended.

Start at the top and work your way down hill.. Get the metro to Vysehrad stop. easy to find entrance which is free. Do a tiny bit of reading before you go and you will appreciate what you are looking at. There are may photo opportunities here and a wonderful cemetery to discover. There was a wedding in the big church when we were there so we couldn't go in and it was bitterly cold. But well worth it and I rate this as one of my best days in Prague. Keep walking down until you get to the river, turn right and if it is Saturday you will come across a farmers market by the water. There you will find yummy food, hot drinks and buskers to enjoy. Keep walking and you will soon get to the Dancing House.

When you need a place to relax in Prague. First of all - it is easy to reach by metro - line C, station Vysehrad is about 5 minutes walking away.You will be rewarded by beautiful views, a quiet walk in the parks, you can sit on the bench and just relax and observe people....or you can go and visit the cemetery where great minds of Czech nation are burried (Dvořák, Smetana, Čapek for example). You can have coffee or ice cream in one of the small cafes . Worth a visit and not so crowded like the centre.

My favorite location in Prague. This was the first places I was taken to 16 years ago, and it has become one of the places I like to visit each time in Prague. Great view of the city from the lesser known "castle". Lots of things to discover in the large complex, and plenty of romantic areas to be found amongst the historical settings.

Great views. The walls of the old castle are very imposing and impressive, and provide an excellent platform for views of the river. We don't pay to go into churches, so missed some of the details, but going to Vysehrad was a very pleasant outing. We got there easily on the underground, and walked down to the trams below for a ride back into the city centre using our 3 day travel ticket - an essential thing to have in Prague.

PEACE & QUIET HERE, PLUS LESS CROWDS..!. We made the big mistake of walking to this place from our hotel, and what a walk that was as Vysehrad is situated on a steep hill over looking the river Vltava. Talk about doing things the hard way, so do use the metro/tram to get here it's more civilised trust me, and saves getting filthy looks from the wife in the process..!As for this "Castle" which is what it really is, I can honestly say this is where the locals come for some peaceful R&R and who can blame them as this historic place is very well kept and along with the spectacular views over the said river are something else. Do pay a visit for a small fee to the cathedral too and have a walk around it's also very peaceful as well as historical along with the church treasure room, which is well worth a look. As you leave here there are extensive gardens to explore and one can tell the locals as they tend to bring picnics, and have a great time with their families. Walking around you do eventually come to the ancient walls which border this place, and the glorious views over the river which on a clear day make good photo opportunity's. Even better if you want a snack at the many restaurants here and get a table over looking the river/city, and what a nice lunch this makes... We stayed up here for a few hours just walking around having a drink/ice cream etc, taking in the views before getting the metro back this time, which are situated just outside or take a tram, the other good thing about Vysehrad is it's downhill for the trams and there are no "lager louts" up here as everyone seems to respect this quiet corner of Prague, even the dreaded tour groups...A really nice way to spend a few hours..!

Much preferred to Prague Castle. Got the tip from the taxi driver on the way from the airport. If you want a bit of peace from the hordes in town, this is absolutely worth making the 30 minutes effort to get there. Peaceful, beautiful, interesting, good views. Get the Metro there and tram back 'cos it's up a big hill from the tram!
peaceful place. Great old walls, nice views and a peaceful park. The church is nice, but not spectacular to visit. The cemetery is really impressive to visit; some of the thumbs are pieces of art.

Go For The Cemetery!. Vyšehrad is Prague's second castle hill. What is left today are extensive fortifications, a cathedral that has undergone numerous changes since its erection and is maybe the only church today with a neogothic exterior and an art nouveau interior (See also the treasury). The area around is a quite pleasant park with several restaurants and food stands, sculptures, temporary exhibitions, souvenir shops (one of them run by an initiative for handicapped children) and - the highlight - the cemetery which is a sanctuary for famous Czech artists and politicians. Some of the graves are art nouveau masterpieces, the small cemetery radiates a wonderful atmosphere and is not overrun. Vyšehrad can be easily reached by metro C from the homonymous stop.

Worth a visit. Only did this on the second visit to Praha but it's worth it. Nice old church, not that busy with tour groups like most of the Old Town areas. Plenty of restaurants around and some very nice views overlooking all of Praha. Easy to get to from the metro line, probably allow 1.5 hours for a very casual walk around the entire area.

One of the highlights. The Vysehrad fortress was one of the highlights of our stay in Prague. The interiors of the church are breathtaking and standing by the grave of Dvorak was a special experience for us. The entire site has a unique atmosphere and the views are great. As suggested by our guide, we visited the fortress on Saturday morning and descended down to the farmers’ market, which was one of the best things we did in Prague. The place is crowded with locals and has a really pleasant vibe. We loved it all.

BEAUTIFUL VIEWS OF THE TOWN. In the 10th century, 70 years after the establishment of Prague Castle, the church of Peter & Paul and fortified trading post, were built on a cliff top overlooking the Vltava River, on the heights of Vysehrad.The views are really beautiful especially at evening with the lights on.We had snacks and beers at a cafe in the area.We went there as a group, with our bus but is easy to reach, taking the metro.Nice experience.

Worth The Time. Great architecture, beautiful streets and buildings and a lovel restaurant at the entrance. A great place to walk in the sunshine and admire the surroundings. A must along with Prague Castle and Charles Bridge.
Beautiful. Go there! Easy access and a flavour of what Prague is all about. See the views and the memorials to Bohemia's great figures.

Away from the crowds. Just a short walk from the metro stop of the same name,Vysehrad is a nice change from the touristy center. Great views of the city and the river, a quiet cemetery and old castle walls make this a great place too visit.

Stunning Interior to the Peter and Paul Basilica. Like others, my wife and I found this a great place for a peaceful walk in the historic fortress and much less touristed than most of Prague. However what makes this one of the high points of any trip to Europe ( and I have been there over 15 times) is the stunningly beautiful and powerful frescos(?) that cover every inch of the interior of the church. Painted by Frantizek Urban and his wife Marie in 1902-03 they are an art nouveau masterpiece that is a tribute to their mentor Anton Mucha (who is buried in the cemetary). While I had previously dismissed much of his work as sentimental pictures of pretty girls and flowers, the undeniable emotional impact of the work exceeded and expectations I may have had. We would visit Prague again, simply for the privilege of spending time here. The entry fee of 30kc is a ridiculous bargain.

Beautiful park. We stayed at the corinthia hotel which is just a stones throw away from this park. We stumbled upon this lovely park on the way to a cafe. It's a wee treasure. Very peaceful and picturesque.

Outside the center of tourist traffic. If you have an extra day and just want a more open outdoor experience, take the metro to Vysehrad, walk behind the conference center to the Vysehrad grounds and en dup at the cathedral stairs down to the tram #17 to return to town. It's a very refreshing and relaxing outdoors stroll through this monument.

Nice stroll, great views. I visited in the early evening. It's a very pleasant way to spend an hour or two in Prague. Just wandering around, you can get really nice views of Prague and also exploring the buildings and statues in the Vysehrad area.It feels very local. When I went, there were almost no tourists. Only locals going out for a jog, walking their dogs, or taking a romantic stroll with their significant others.Note: There seems to be only one entrance into Vysehard. Make sure you know which street it's on. Otherwise, you may find yourself circling around the half the fort before you can make your way up like I did.

Well worth a visit if you have several days in Prague. The old walls are impressive, views are phenomenal and it would make a fantastic location for a picnic in the summer. There isn't a massive amount to see but all the attractions are low cost or free and we found them pretty interesting. For me one of the attractions is it's clearly a place frequented by locals as well as tourists so you feel like you've sampled a little bit of the real Prague. If you have a free morning it's a nice ride by tram along the river from Charles bridge and if you don't fancy a picnic you could call in at U kroka restaurant for a cheap, filling and tasty lunch on the way back to the trams.
Away from the crowds. Away from all the crowds of the city centre we spent a relaxing morning at the cathedral,viewing the cemetery and sitting in the park with the monuments.
Peaceful. Very nice area without the tourist hordes of the city center. But only during good weather. Some nice views and big lawns.

A must. One catches the underground tram to Vysehrad from the Wencelas square underground stop--2 stops. From here it is a short to Vysehrad--most of it can be walked around and see for free--except 2 underground bunkers--one which houses the originals statues form Charles bridge. We did the free walk and sites--which was well worth it. The grounds are good to walk around, there are immense statues in the park and the church still stands--the only building not destroyed in the war like the castle. Best of all--here is where the famous graveyard is--where famous artists,poets and writers are buried--we saw Dubrovnik;s grave. Because these were artists the graves and statues are artistic and is it really worth visiing it. There is a café where one can get snacks and drinks outside--and one in in the small information centre,

Take a step back in Vysehrad. Only 20 minutes away from central Prague via metro (including walking), Vysehrad is a beautiful place, perfect to take a stroll, or enjoy the view of Prague (and visit Mucha and Dvorak). Despite being so close to central Prague, it is not as crowded as other tourist spots are. If you are in Prague for only a day or two, perhaps not enough time to visit this lovely place, but if you have some time on hand and looking for a quiet place to absorb yourself in history and scenery, this is the place to go.

Prague foundation & the Prophecy of Princess Libuše. Vyšehrad is a magical place. It is now ruins of a castle where the founders of Prague lived 1000 years ago. Princess Libuse once had a vision and ordered her staff to find a man, a carpenter, in a forest who will be their future leader and a city to be established there. She than made her famous prophecy: "I can see a great city whose glory shall reach the stars". People who deal with energies know that Vysehrad is of the feminine nature (yin, if you will) and the Prague castle is of masculine energy (yang). There is a direct line of sight between the two. Even if you are not into these kind of things, a trip to Vysehrad is worth it for the views, the cathedral, the park and the cemetery of famous Czech people such as artists.

Mystic place. Vysehrad is historical place in Prague which includes several sights. For me, the most impressive is graveyard. Old, clean and maybe too loud. Visitors act like they have no respect at all, but... Search around and you will find Dvorak, Smetana, Neruda and lot more tombs. Search around the castle, walls, hidden corners.
Lovely place to visit. Been there a number of times - I keep on going back. Lovely place to just walk around, imposing entrance, great views of the city.

Peaceful and Serene. One of the most beautiful monuments in Prague. Easily accessible from all parts of the city. Following the road signs from the Vysehrad metro stop would easily lead you to this marvellous historical monument. It was winter time and the ground was full of snow. Not very crowded wither. The graveyard and cathedral adjacent to the Monument are so peaceful and quiet. The place consists of several famous graveyards including Smetana and Dvorák .We walked around the place for several hours before a security personnel advised us to head back to the city, as the place gets too lonely after evening. Definitely a recommended place to spend a few hours strolling around.
A must see in Prague. this place is simply beautiful. The historical heart of Prague maybe but so much more! Check out the Gothic Grotto

Beautiful. This complex is a lot bigger than I was expecting. I went in the winter so there was snow on the ground and was rather cold. A walk around this area is rather breathtaking. It is very easy to get to as well. Just go to the Vysehrad metro stop and follow the signs. The cathedral and graveyard are very peaceful and you should definitly not miss the views on the outside of the complex as well.
great place to spend a couple of hours and good views. Great little place with spectacular views and it was empty when we went. A walk around the walls is recommended.

A Hidden Treasure. This beautiful and indeed historical part of Prague, is not to be missed during anyone's trip here. The view of the Vltava river is breathtaking and the whole area is full of history. Make sure you go to the cemetery on the side of the cathedral, there you will find the graves of hundreds of famous Czechs (Smetana, Dvorák to name but a few).Best way to get there - Red line Metro to Vyshrad and walk through to the main gates. You wont be disappointed, and not so many tourists either.

Good views, interesting monuments. If you want to see the original statues that were on Charles Bridge (a lot of the larger ones there are modern copies) then you're at teh right place. You can see them in a vast underground hall within the walls of the Vysehrad structure. They can be seen on a short guided tour on the hour, from a small shop door near the main gate entrance to teh fortress. Well worth the 60kc charge for admission (30 or seniors).And the monuments in the graveyard, to most of the famous Prague artists, musicians etc over the last 150 years or so have to be seen to be believed. They are an art gallery in themselves.The Catholic Cathedral at the summit has an interesting treasury , and also had some well built nativity scenes still on display when we visited.When you walk out of teh main gate, down to the railway bridge, don't miss the strange cubist houses inspired by the painting movement. Unique to Prague, and the villa with the complementary hedgework in the front garden is well worth a look.

Half a day to see most of it. The high light for us was the cemetery where Smetana and Dvorak can be found. Also holds the remains of a lot of Czech authors, unfortunately outside my realm of experience. Starkly beautiful grounds in January, one supposes it is gorgeous when it's green

Very nice! . This is a very nice place in the south side of town! It is reachable by metro, line red, till Vysehrad station, from where it's a 5-10 minutes walk. It offers a great view of river Vltava and there is a great walking area and a splendid parc (which I think it's even nicer in summer or spring, with all the green ...) Anyway, a "no miss" place in Prague!!

Very old site. This place is less frequently visited, so there is not as much foot traffic. The cathedral is of course stunning and full of stuff to keekp your eyes occupied. And there is an underground tunnel to see. I loved the premises, you can see the Castle quarter in the distance

Obvious, but overlooked. This monument has a huge statue of a warrior hero astride his horse and commemorates the victory of the Hussites against a much larger army. It is set in a very large, lovely park. The buildings are not particularly beautiful, but very solid, and interesting. Most of the displays are in Czech and English, and one should not miss a visit to the underground part of the museum, where a veritable "Frankenstein's Laboratory" was used to try and preserve the body of an early Communist leader. Nothing else like it in the world.
Beautiful cemetery an great architecture. The monuments are just amazing. The cemetery is one of the most beautiful i've ever seen. The site is great. Nice place to walk and a great view of the city.
Not to be missed / Imprescindible. Las vistas son espectaculares y la fortaleza merece mucho la pena.The fort and cemetery are worth a visit and the views are unforgettable.

Worth a visit!. This is the perfect place to relax after spending hours in overcrowded Old Town streets and squares.Lovely gardens, nice cafes and an impressive panorama of the river Vltava. Must visit.

relaxing place for real tourists. If you don't want to miss a real historical sight in Prague you need to visit Vysehrad. You will find there a place to relax after spending hours in overcrowded Old Town streets and squares. But besides you will get an impressive panorama of the river Vltava (Moldau in German), Karlov district, Smichov and Kosire district on the other side of the river, and, of course, the Petrin hill and Hradcany. And if you are really sensitive you will get the feel of history and glory in the church or in the adjacent cemetery where the best Czech artists and giants are buried.

A not-so-known attraction. This is a quite nice castle, with some exhibitions, the wall, the cellar and many other things worth seeing there. As it's a little far from Old Town (Stare Mesto) and the Lesser Town (Mala Strana) it's also not that much known or visited. The good side is ... that is not much visited (not crowded). During winter some parts are closed. Check before you go.

Vysehrad is a glorious place. One of the best trips to Prague was actually this year. We made it a point to see those things that we have not seen before. Vysehrad was one of those places that we always said we would do and didn't. This trip we made it up to Vysehrad and I am so glad that we did. It is so beautiful and just like all the other reviews, quite peaceful. Our trip was this past October and the fall colors and the brisk temperatures made this place a spectacular find. The views of Prague Castel and Vltava River with the oranges and browns have made the postcard perfect pictures. Be sure to go inside the cemetery for some of the best monuments in a cemetery that I have ever seen.

A place of quiet and reflectiveness. As others have written, this really is a delightful spot and easy to find.
