We were there in October and it was so quiet and peaceful, the autumn leaves turning colour and the whole atmosphere was one of being detached from the bustle of the city. The views from the walls are wonderful, even down to looking below to see trams disappearing and emerging from the tunnel on the main road! The church there is very beautiful with some superb art-works. At only a couple of metro stops from the Museum at the top of Wenceslas square, it's a 'must-do' place.

Calm and beautiful. This is a wonderful place to spend a couple of hours sitting on the bench, listening to birds songs and cathedral bells ringing or walking and enjoying the view of Prague from one of the highest points in the city.

Beautiful an peaceful. Vysehrad has a very rich history, but what I think would interest people who travel to Prague the most, are the expansive views from above, quite different than the view from the Castle. Here, you get a beautiful view of the winding river Vltava, with all the famous bridges. It offers also a different view of the Castle in the distance. There is a beautiful St.Peter and Paul Church-beautiful, but an entrance fee must be paid. The centuries old cemetery (no fee), is quite fascinating, the tombstones are very artistic, sculptures are very unique and hauntingly beautiful. This is a resting place for many prominent families, painters, writers, musicians and composers. Among them, Bedrich Smetana and Antonin Dvorak (famous composers) and Alfonse Mucha (painter). For the czech people, and I still consider myself one of them, even after living in the US for many years, it is a trip back in history. Also, some of the famous people who emigrated to US, chose this spot for their last resting place. The park itself is quite lovely, but so is Kampa park, Strelecky ostrov and Petrin, and they are much more central. This is the first time, after many visits to Prague, that we found time to visit there. We were staying in hotel Aria (Mala Strana) and because " time is money", we decided to take a car arranged by the hotel for about $20 one way (very comfortable Mercedes ride). The great advantage:saving time and avoiding climbing the hill. The driver took us there from the other side (not by the river). I would not call a taxi on the street, they would surely drive you around circles, if you don't know the city.If you are staying in a hotel that picked you up at the airport-as many hotels in Prague do-then such ride could be negotiated. Later, we walked down the hill, many steps, took our time and many pictures. The tram, the stop is just at the bottom of the hill, is very convenient, stops at the National Theatre and you can exit there and be close to the Center. Next stop is close to the Charles Bridge. If you cross any of the two bridges, Legii by the Theater or Charles, you will end up in the heart of Mala Strana.

The Cemetery is Worth the Time. This cemetery has been compared to Pere Lachaise in Paris; it is nowhere near as large, but the headstones, many of which are sculptures, make this a must-see cemetery. Although hardly quiet due to ongoing work on the Church on Sts. Peter & Paul, which is next to the cemetery, this is a place where you can get away from the crowds and see gorgeous art, free of charge. Notable Czech luminaries buried here include writers Jan Neruda and Karel Capek, and composers Dvorak and Smetana. Plan to spend at least an hour, and make sure you have your camera!

Quiet and beautiful. Vysehrad is a lovely place to visit far from the throngs of tourists in Old Town. It's a little hard to get to, either by tram or Metro, but worth the effort. The church is quite beautiful, with the interior covered with paintings of saints and Biblical scenes. The park is pretty with nice sculptures. There are nice distant views over Prague and the castle. But the real stand-out for me is the cemetery where Dvorak and Smetana are buried. Both graves can be found rather easily, although you have to search a bit for Smetana which is at the back and Dvorak is nearer the front on the perimeter wall. There is a bust of Dvorak. The gravestone for Smetana includes the opening notes of The Moldau. The painter Mucha is also buried in a large group tomb. The various funerary sculptures of other persons are really beautiful, some very moving. One is of a woman stepping down toward her grave with her husband following behind, as if she is leading the way. There are many others. If you have a pretty day, you'll be glad you went.

nice walkie. for our romantic trip to Prague, it was nice having rest from monuments and history - next time we will visit gardens with our daugter and her first bike for great and long riding. many points where you can just sit, think, read book, talk to your love or buddy... many points where you can check views on prague from different way

Beautiful views looking down towards the castle district. Vysehrad is a long walk away from the old town but public transport will bring you to it also.The cathedral of St Peter and St Paul is the imposing structure on the site and the interior is adorned with painted and decorated walls and ceilings.The reliquaries of numerous Czech saints are in the cathedral as well as some very nice alters and paintings.The view of the Vltava river is stunning on a bright day with the castle off in the distance and it makes for some very nice photos.Worth a visit but I wouldn't put off some of the more famous sites to see it if you are pressed for time

Don't skip Old Town, but don't miss Vysehrad in Prague. You need to see Old Town and the Astronomical Clock and climb to the Castle. But when you've tired of crowds, don't miss this equally historic area of Prague that's poised on the rock, overlooking some of the most beautiful vistas in the area. It's said to be the original settlement of the city of Prague. It offers history and art including the vineyards, Basilica, 14th century fortifications, 11th century St Martin Rotunda and the Art Nouveau cemetery, burial place of Alphonse Mucha and Antonín Dvořák. But it's also a park with century old trees, and when your kids need to run off some steam and you're feeling like your brain may burst with facts and impressions, come here. It's a peaceful cobblestone stroll and not crowded.Food is moderately priced and Vysehrad entrance is free. It's accessible by public transit. I rate Vysehrad among the best parts of Prague and would trade off many other sights to spend a few hours here.

Lovely, relaxing place. I have visited Vysehrad a few time but never get bored with it. It's a beautiful park to walk around with fantastic views from the walls. The church is beautifully decorated & the cemetry has wonderful statues etc.Go beneath the walls into the undergrounf chambers to see some of the original statues that were on Charles Bridge.There was an art exhibition also when we visited. The food at the cafe is very good.

Pargues second castle. Hardly an original title but the sight of the old Royal Castle which consists of a large church and massive castle walls to the south of the main centre is very pleasant. Quiet with great views across town and of the river. Worth a half days wander.
Very relaxing place. A nice big park with an old church and small exhibition. 30-40 minutes walk from city center or by a metro, there is a special Vysehrad stop. Nice view on the city from above.

Definitely worth a visit. We walked along the river to this lovely park. Maybe took about 30-40 mins, we didnt really time it as we were just enjoying the walk. The park is such a peaceful retreat after the crowds in the old town area. Great views up and down the river from the old walls. The trees were displaying fine autumn colours which we loved. Even if you think you dont ever need to see another church on your holiday, do go in to this one. Allow 2-3 hrs, especially if you stop for a coffee i nthe cafe.

A view of the city like no other. This is a beautiful place, peaceful and away from the bustle of the city although it is only two stops on the metro away from Wenceslas square. The view of the old wall snaking through the city was breathtaking I would thoroughly recommend a wander.

Amazing views over the Vltava River. We spent a few hours at the Vysehrad National Cultural Monument and park - just walking round and soaking up the atmosphere.The spectacular views over the Vltava River, the lovely old church and the cemetery held our interest for a few hours. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful. Great place with magnificent views, perfect for afternoon relaxation, pretty and quite, you walk on the path surrounding the castle and the city view changes beautifully

The Visherad cemetary. This is for people who love to find the resting place of poets, writers, painters and musicians. The Smetana Tomb is quite beautiful, and so is the Dvorak one. The most popular is Karel Capek, the Tchek equivalent of H G Wells. View of Prague is great from the garden and there is a church with incredible ceiling decorations.

Amazing panoramic views. Having been to Prague several times, I'm amazed that I had not been here before. There's something for everyone. Romantic walks around the park, kids playgrounds, marvellous photo opportunities and hoards of history in the churches and cemetery. Don't worry there's also a few cafés with lovely cold beer when you need a break.

Beautiful, expansive site worth a visit. If you are into fortresses, cemeteries and such, this is a really very interesting location. Not quite as much a tourist trap as some of the more popular destinations, so you're less likely getting caught in a swarm of people. The downside is that there are not a lot of venues in this fortress that are available to the public, so there is a chance you will not get to see everything there that you might otherwise want to see. That is a minor issue in the overall location, as there is still plenty to keep you occupied. I would absolutely recommend this spot.

So much history....a must during a Prague visit. Beautiful grounds; the Basilica of St. Peter and St. Paul is incredible as well as the walk through the neighboring cemetery to view the grave sites of many famous Czechs

Worth the time as it is different from the rest of Prague. The main reason I went to Vysehrad was because it was close to the Congress Center, but I think it is definitely worth the short metro trip by itself. Our visit included walking through the cemetery (remains of many famous people from Czech history), spending time in the park, and seeing the basilica of St Peter and Paul. The best part was the view across the Vltava River, especially on a clear sunny day. I think this is worth the time if you have more than one day, as it offers a different atmosphere than other parts of Prague.

History with a View. Site of one of the earliest Prague settlements, the climb up to the top of this hill is well worth it. Some wonderful very old buildings are the backdrop to spectacular views looking up the river and over the rooftops to the castle and both old and new towns. A lot of Czech luminaries are interred in the cemetery, which features some pretty spectacular graves. Beyond all this, there is a sense of this being a special place, a power spot if you will, and it's worth just sitting back on one of the benches and drinking it all in.
worth the short subway or bus trip from anywhere. great views of the city, an old, old fortress now a park with a small art gallery, and a great walk around the ramparts

Excellent views. We spent a very pleasant half day here, soaking up the magical atmosphere and enjoying the culture and spectacular views.There is a magical feel to this area and we were very lucky to be blessed with a warm, sunny t- shirt day that made the views even more beautiful.Take time to visit the cemetery, the Gothic Church of St Peter and Paul and the views over the ramparts.

Interesting park, good for a wander. Decided on a trip to Vysehrad on my final day in Prague. Wasn't sure what was there but it was actually pretty interesting. Large park area, big church, a grotto with an exhibition of archaeological finds in the area. A "viewing gallery" - basically a walkway round three sides of the park which all overlook Prague itself. You can spend a good half-day wandering round. There are a couple of cafes in there too though I didn't try them.

nice walk. I walk there from the confrene center, just next to the hill. the garden is very relax, really a nice place for a picnic. I didn't enter the church, but the cemetery was very nice, wuth many unique tombstone. walking from there to the center took me about 30 minutes, and on the way I saw the "Jinger and Fred" house

Great Getaway. My personal guide took me here, and I am very glad she did. This is a great complex away from the hubbub of central Prague. It has a totally different feel from the rest of the touristy parts of the city, yet fits right in with the whole cultural experience of visiting Prague. The views over the Vltava, the beautiful cemetery, the lovely church, and the peaceful gardens make this a nice getaway.
Not just a monument. There is so much to view there, the monument, great view from the city, local cheap food and beers. Good place to walk around.
Amazing art!. But what an ugly building! Prague is full of such amazingly beautiful buildings. Every corner you turn leads to such beauty. But this building, though full of wonderful art, is UGLY.

Yes. Walk the Iron Bridge to Peaceful.. A local spot for calm, dog walking, history, beauty. Start at Vyton and walk up past Cubist homes. Walk back down and cross the iron bridge and view the river as trains rush by. This place is for those who want history, cemeteries, gorgeous church and real people. Cake and coffee in small cafe is a must if there in January. Go there and just hang out.

Great views and a peaceful place to come.. When we eventually found the way up to Vysehrad we were granted a bit of quietness not seen in the centre of town and expansive views with the Vitara in the bottom. We went into the impressive cathedral afterwards and were not disappointed either. The only thing I felt down about was a total lack of signposting and it took an hour to find an entrance/exit, as it was our last day we had a lot to cover and this wasted a lot of our time.

Nice spot to relax. A bit of the beaten path, Vysehrad is the site of an old fortress and is a nice green area. We'd just got back to proper Prague from the suburbs, and were in want of some peace and quiet before heading to the Lapidarium. There isn't much at Vysehrad to physically do in my opinion, but it's a nice quiet park with a historic church and some old buildings dotted around. As an antidote to the suburbs or busy tourist areas like Old Town Square, its perfect.

Fantastic!. I thik I kind like the palce even a little bit more than The Prague Castle. Of cource, there is a fantastic view over the Vltava river, marvelous gardens to walk or just sit on the benches or on the grass....The Castle could be easily access by line C of the Metro, or with Tram from the Charl`s Bridge. Do not miss to visit the place, it`s worth seeing it! Next to the cemetery, there is a lovely Cafe, so colourful and with very nice staff! Be there:)

Under-Appreciated, A Must See!. When tourists get to Prague, they immediately head to Charles Bridge and the Old Town. Those attractions are great, yes, but considering heading to the church, cemetery, and wonderful park at Vysehrad. It's a beautiful walk along the river to the foot of the old castle complex, then once you walk up you're rewarded with amazing views of Prague. The buildings and scenery are very nice, and it's all free. There's also restaurants and vendor booths for lunch. So much less touristy than Old Town, and it's a great way to relax and get a more authentic feel for what Prague is all about.
nice castle. It is actually old castle, where kings ruled country in 15 th century. It is located above the river with excellent view of the town.

Lovely green space, but a disappointing destination - you can take a tram back to town. Hard to believe that some reviewers suggest forsaking Prague Castle in favor of this spot. It's a lovely parkland space, surrounded by a wide wall that offers a pleasant walk around the property and handsome views. The buildings are historic and handsome, the green space clean and inviting. There's just not much to it, and it probably doesn't need to feature on the itinerary of most first-time or short-term visitors.On the other hand, it's a quick, easy get-away from 'Tourist Town.' If you had any lingering doubt that the monument is aimed at the local population, not the occasional tourist, note that the information center's materials, including the map of the grounds, were offered exclusively in Czech. If your dream trip to Prague includes immersing yourself among Czechs in a quiet, lovely, outdoor setting, this is the place.A quick note about transit: Taking the C line of the Metro gets you to a stop that's a relatively short walk to the site. For variety, consider an alternative return route. Walk down the concrete stairway just outside the main property and proceed through a short pedestrian tunnel; follow the sidewalk down along a park and take another short tunnel under the railroad tracks. A block or so ahead you'll see a tram stop served by several lines. One of these - line 18 - take you through town and uphill directly to the stop for Prague Castle. You can buy tram tickets at the Tabak right at the stop.

Worth a trip. Very quiet, away from the crowds. Definitely worth a visit.Would recommend. Loads of history. On the way back to the city stop at the U Kroka restaurant which is just five minutes down from here
except the view there is nothing. The park is nice and clean, but there was no life at all! Everithing closed and the panorama is much better from the Hradcany.

Beautiful park and National Cemetery. Quiet, peaceful oasis on a bluff overlooking the river, it is a large park with a variety of interesting things to see, including a tiny 11th c. church, the Czech National Cemetery (dedicated more to artists, musicians and scholars than politicians and generals), an Austro-Hungarian fort, and other places important to Czech history. Great place to walk, look at the city up and down the river, picnic, eat at an outdoor cafe, etc. Very few tourists go there, mostly Czech families relaxing and having fun.

Soooooo much nicer than tourist central. I read about this place and was not disappointed. A lovely quiet extremely significant cultural attraction which is the oldest area in Prague. The SS Peter & Paul church is very beautiful. The view is stunning and the grounds are definitely an oasis of peace away from the crowds. This place is so much more Prague than the usual tourist haunts. As they say, do yourself a favour.

Special. I've been 3 times - it is just lovely. Best views over the city, stunning walk, and a highlight in the churchyard where you'll find thoughtful and unique monuments to Prague's artistic departed.

historical spot not to be missed. quiet decent place with great history, oldest in the city. great view on Prague panorama. cementry where the greatest Czech having rest, cathedral in neo gothic style, highly recommended for tourists and even for residents

The oldest establishment in Prague! Visit the tombs of famous composers Antonin Dvorzak and Bedzih Smetana!. The access to this site is easy and free. Take the red line metro to Vyshegrad and them walk straight past the Congress Center. This is the oldest establishment in Prague dating from the 7th century when princess Ludmila of Bohemia lived there (the guide told us). It is a fortress that was never really used to defend Prague. It also harbors the ancient church and most importantly the tombs of Bedricih Smetana and Antonin Dvorzak, the famous Czech composers. At the entrance to the cemetery there is a list with names and locations and a map. Smetana's tomb is row 5 plot 40 and Dvorzak's is row 14 plot 35. The views of Prague from Vyshegrad are stunning. It is a nice, quiet place that includes a big park area.
Historic walk. The St. Peter and Paul's Cathedral and it's cemetery was amazing. The paintings of the cathedral were unique

Peaceful park and famous tombs. Enjoyed taking an evening walk through this park. (Would be hesitant about coming here alone after dark as it is quite isolated). The tombs are a small component of the park, and walled off. I found several names that I recognised, but a guide book would have been handy here. This would be an excellent park for a picnic as there are extensive grassed areas and trees for shade. It's close to the Prague Congress Centre and makes a nice walk after sitting in meetings for hours. The route from conference centre/ Vysehrad metro station is not well signposted so it's helpful to take a map.

Nothing so amasing !!!. First of all Vysehard is quite close to the centre, just two metro stop form Wenceslas Square (red line). Nonetheless, when you arrive there you are in a different world, perhaps much closer to the real Prague. You'll see local strolling in the park & a few tourist. The basilica is nice ((small entrance fee) and the view are good. However, you can get similar & even better views even in the city centre. Good for children to run around in the park.The end line is simple if you have spare time or not a first time traveller go. Nonetheless, on a list of priority place to see, definitely there are many who take precedence.

Peaceful haven away from crowds. Beautiful views from castle walls.Peaceful place.Take a picnic and relax.We saw the beautiful interior of the church and a brief tour round the cemetary with some unusual headstones..Also witnessed a wedding on the walls! Will def go again.

Beautiful spot away from the tourist crowds. We visited Vysehrad upon the recommendation of a friend and we are very glad we did. The entire Old Towne area, including the castle, St. Vitus and Charles bridge, etc. was very, very crowded with tourists. we knew to expect that but it was much worse than expected. Like Disneyland on steroids. we loved the Old Towne area but visiting Vysehrad was a breath of fresh air. We walked the entire perimeter of the fortress and had the most amazing views of Prague. It was so beautiful, peaceful and serene. It is located more in a neighborhood and frequented by locals. It was a highlight of our trip.

A lovely morning a bit out of the center. It was extremely hot in Prague and we decided to take a look at vysehrad park, church and cemetery. We took the metro (only three stations from Florenc) and came to a totally different setting. The park is beautiful, quiet, with benches where you can rest and a few cafes where you can have a drink or a simple meal. From the walls that surround it the view of Prague is something new and unexpected! A lovely morning out!

Not "a must.". We spent 4 days in Prague and have visited Vysehrad on the last day of our trip. There's a convinient access by public transport and the admission is free. Vesehrad is an ancient complex situated on a hill. There's a small park and few buildings within the old city walls. I enjoyed 4 big monuments connected with Czech history/legends (I think - there was no information about them either in the park or in my guide book). It is impossible not to mention a huge basilica of St. Peter and St. John. It's very old, but it was renowated in XX century, so its current outlook is not very roman. Unfortunately, you have to pay for the entrance to the church. We just had a quick look through the main door and decided that there is nothing special to pay for. Next to the church there's a cementary where importnat Czechs are burried (e.g. Alphonse Mucha). I'm not a fan of cementary visits so I cannot tell you much about it. We decided to visit Vysehrad, because many people say that "It's a must" when you are in Prague. Well... I think, it's not. Not much to see, really. I'm glad that I've stayed in Prague for 4 days and had time to visit everything. I can imagine that comming to Prague for a weekend and spending an hour or two in Vesehrad I'd have been quite dissapointed.

Excellent place to have a nice walk. We were there in the middle of the day and it was not too crowded. We visited also the cemetery, where all the famous Czech people (for example Antonin Dvořák) are burried - a very interesting thing to see and worth of a visit! There is a nice and very clean park. I recommend you to take a blanket with you and enjoy your time there.

an enjoyable place. This enjoyable place boasts with a history going back to mythical times of the Czech tribe. The National Cemetery is worth to visit even if history is not your cup of tea. The large park atop a hill bordered with a massive fortification offers many attractive views on the city, especially on the river Vltava with its islands and bridges and impressive Prague Castle across the river.
nice little getaway. We took the metro to Vysehrad, and then walked to it. It is a respite from the crowds and the views are amazing. More locals than tourists.
cemetary with famous czechs. There lands famous czech writers (Karel Capek), painters, poets, composers (Antonin Dvorak), actors, or sportsmen (Josef Bican)

Pleasant and peaceful.. Just a few minutes walk from a grand hotel and one of the main and busiest roads in Prague we walked into this peaceful place made up of gardens, passageways, history and of course the grand view over the river Vltava. One can admire the magnificent cathedral, and the old ramparts. There are also some nice eating places.You can enjoy a romantic walk amongst the cute passages and tranquil surrounding. On the whole a worthwhile visit and would recommend to anyone wanting some peaceful place.

Beautiful and relaxing. Take a respite form the crowds at some of the other historical sites in Prague and visit Vysehrad. My favorite since I live just down the hill. Beautiful grounds for walking and viewing the city from a higher elevation. Most buildings do not have a charge for entering. Several place to have a coffee or adult beverage and relax. During the warmer months there is a beer garden open which has some very interesting locals.

A varied collection of attractions on a hillside. A convenient entrance at the top of the hill is close to the Vysehrad subway station. We recommend visiting the Basilica of St Peter and St Paul and the adjacent cemetery which contains the graves of important Czech figures including Dvorak and Smetana, with the corresponding artistic headstones. Do not miss a special collection at a corner near the entrance of the Basilica. The ruins on the site are of moderate interest and the view of Prague is outstanding. One can exit at the bottom of the hill and take a tram back to the city.

Best view of Prague. I used to live right under the Vyšehrad park / monument / Cathedral and it turned out, that it was the greatest place to relax, have fun and get a great view of Prague. It must be seen when visit Prague. Also do not forget to visit Vyšehrad cemetry, right next to the Cathedral, where most famos people are buried.

Very peaceful park, superb cemetery. This place is like a park complex, with a lot of space to walk, a few places to have a drink, a cathedral, a cemetery and many other stuff to see. The cemetery is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen with many statues, flowers, very colorful and eye-catching. It is also the resting place of Dvorak and Smetana, the 2 most representative Czech composers. The view from the place is also gorgeous, being an old fort placed on a hill.
A magical place. This is the place of the czech mythology and it is filled with magical atmosphere. The views are amazing too.

Great place to spend a relaxing day. Lots of open space to sit and soak up the beautiful surroundings. There is fantastic views of the city from the walls. Great place for a picnic. Easy to get to, take the metro line C to the Vysehrad stop and walk from there, following the signs. About a 3-5 minute walk.

Nice, quiet place to relax, while still soaking up history. Be sure to visit the cemetery! It's amazing how many different styles of graves/headstones are in there, as well as graves of many famous Czechs. We also enjoyed seeing the views from the top of the hill - one can see forever from up there.

Beautiful place to visit, a must!. From this place you have beautiful views of different parts of the city. Furthermore it is a perfect place to just relax and be away from the city for some time. There are also very few tourists to be found here and more locals. When we visited it was very quiet. We had a nice afternoon here, just strolling around. Also the church of st. Peter and Paul, which is placed here, is worth a visit.

Interesting, but not what I expected. This is a place full of interesting history and it does deserve a visit. First of all, it was a castle at some point, but it was not anything like Prague Castle or all of the other castles I have been to. I was call it more of a fortress and church now. I was there on a day when it was pouring rain- I had a coat ad hat so I spent a lot of time outdoors, but there was not a soul around and that was kind of cool, but also kind if eerie. The graveyard at the church has some of the most elaborate tombs I have ever seen (which includes some famous names like Anton Dvorzak) so that is also worth some time to explore.

A quieter place to explore. Easy walking access downhill from Vysehrad Subway station and then continue down after exiting and take #24 tram back to the city. Some nice restaurants in the park as well as just after the lower exit. The decoration of the interior of the Church of Sts Peter and Paul is partly art deco and beautiful to see. The adjacent cemetery is worth visiting because of the relevance and fame of its occupants and eclectic mix of headstone designs. Lovely river views and a nice green area to escape to from summer crowds.
Quiet and beautiful park. I can't say that it is somehow special place, just nice park with cathedral, impressive fortress walls and views on Vltava river.

The most beautiful place in Prague. A bit farther away from the center the place does not have giant flocks of tourists, which was a very nice change. The panoramic views are amazing and the park overall is a beautiful place you can wander in for hours (even the slight rain and the mean-looking black cloud heading towards the city didn't bother us). Didn't go in to see the church as by this point we basically saw more than enough churches for out whole stay in Prague but the cemetery adjacent to it had some very artistic headstones. Definitely a must visit an easily the most beautiful place in Prague!

Big walk up, don't miss the gold and jewels. The $2 ticket to the ancient church is well worth it; the jewels alone are a knockout. The wall paintings are in style of Alfonse Mucha, not by him but maybe a student; the altar area is superb.

Great escape from the city rush. It is a peaceful place not far from the city centre with wonderful views of Prague. There are many intresting sights to see or you can just have a nice walk through the park. Definitely worth visiting!

A Neighborhood Castle. This castle dates back to the thirteenth century. Like many castles, there are just ruins remaining in places and some parts have been rebuilt. This is charming because it is in a neighborhood and is used as a park by regular, local people. We went early on a Saturday morning. The views were lovely. We could see the river and even crew shells out for a morning row. There is a wonderful portion where one can walk along the ramparts. Unlike some of the areas in Prague where everything is overrun by tourists, this is a little off the beaten path and is relatively serene. It was fun to walk along the ramparts and see the wonderful views of the city. It is a nice place to wander, think, and imagine.We went into the church, The Church of Saints Peter and Paul, which has also been rebuilt over time. I found it charming because the walls are decorated in art nouveau style. There are many depictions of saints, especially female saints, in the style of Alphonse Mucha, who is buried in the cemetery adjacent to the church. I don't think the wall decorations are considered to be the most important artwork in the cathedral, but I found them completely enchanting.From the Old Town, one can take the Metro up to the Prague Convention Center, then walk toward the church spires. Eventually, you will run across the brown tourist pointers which will point the way to the entrance. There is no charge to walk around the grounds. Entrance to the church is about $3.00.

A Serene Surprise. if you visit one park-like place this should be the one. There is lots of history happening here; including an important cemetary, a church, gardens etc. We saw some of the best views of our Prague trip from atop Vysehrad. The area is easily accesible by metro (or even walking) but feels further away from the action that it actually is. There were some interesting shops that were different and better priced thann those below. I found some beautiful handmade replica medievil glassware. The best part was later that same day when I saw the originals in the Decorative Arts Museum. If you have the time and want something to do that is quieter and slower paced, this would be perfect.

Definitely worth the visit!. My husband and I wanted to see something outside of the main hub of the city and thought this seemed perfect. You can take a metro, but we usually prefer walking as it is the best way to see a new city! It's was just over 3 miles from where we were staying in the Mala Strana area and was a beautiful and scenic walk to get there following the river. If you have the time, the walk was no trouble at all! However, we did have a little trouble finding it at first.....walking along the river, there WAS a small sign indicating where to turn off to head up the steps to the park, but we missed it and had to turn back...so just make sure you have a good idea how far down the park is before you set off:) Another tip-we came in the back entrance of the park (where the stairs lead you right up to the cemetary and St. Peter & Paul church), and went up a series of many MANY steps. Would not recommend this route if you have trouble with steps, have a stroller in tow, etc. However, once we we were in the park area, we saw another more main entrance that seemed to be what all the locals used with flat cobblestone path.The park grounds are beautiful and many benches to sit and just take it all in. I absolutely recommend walking around the top perimeter of the fort, the views were spectacular and some of my favorite pictures from our trip were here. We followed the cobblestone path all around and saw many interesting buildings, as well as the amazing church. It was just a beautiful park with amazing views and gorgeous grounds. It was definitely NOT a tourist hot spot, which we loved. I really enjoyed the peacefulness of it all and seeing all the locals meet there!We went here on the last day of our trip and it was one our favorite memories by far! Beautiful and a much needed getaway from the Charles Bridge/Old Town Square tourist scene. If you make the time to get here, you won't be disapointed!

With all there is to do in Praha you might overlook it , but don't.. With all the other places to see and things to do in Praha this site gets overlooked, but it shouldn't. It took until the third time I visited the city to walk my way up but I must have spent 3 1/2 hours visiting the gardens, Cemetery, Cathedral and the walking paths. It has some spectacular views overlooking the city and from some great angles as well. The cemetery is filled with Artists, Composers and other cultural icons from the Czech past. I brought a sack lunch and enjoyed it the garden while doing some people watching. If your looking for a good spot to picnic in Praha this would make a great place. You will avoid the vagrants who hang around Letna and the Train Station and there is plenty of room. It's a good walk up from the streets below but if you have been in Praha long enough you will be used to it. Plan on spending a couple hours here. Don't forget your camera.

DO NOT MISS. This is the most beautiful spot in Prague. From the top of the wall, you can see all of Prague. Take the time and walk the entire circumference. The monuments in the cemetery are amazing, St. Peter and St. Paul's Cathedral is beautiful and there is a large grassy area that just invites you to lay out and contemplate the long storied history of this site.

Good panoramic view. nice gardens. Free and quiet.. Nice cemetery and gardens, even for a picnic. Panoramic view of the river.Ticket for the church is cheap but unneeded. not much to see and treasury is pretty small.

A quiet place close to the city centre. We went there on a rainy day and it was a really quiet and nice place to spend a few hours.The view over central Prague was spectacular and this would have been a perfect place for a picnic if you went there a sunny day. We did not try the restaurants within the complex but they did not seem to be that special. It is easy to get there by metro to Vysehrad station.

The rain was pouring, but we didn't mind!. We visited Vysehrad on our last day of vacation, Monday, December 24, 2012. It was a horrid day. The rain was pouring and it never really stopped. After having a nice late lunch at Kavarna Slavia we hopped on the train for the short trip to Vysehrad. Once off the train, there were no signs on how to actually get to the site. But because we knew that this was a fort on high ground and we were armed with a map, we found it fairly easily to find. It took us about 4-5 minutes to get to the site from the train station. Once at the site, we checked out most of the former casements and castle fortifications. This was the seat of the first Czech kings before the dawn of the 10th century. The views from the castle complex were great. We also visited a small museum that was in an underground cellar that offered a respite from the rain and was full of interesting objects. I spent a lot of time here as my husband had to leave to find a bathroom! The day was ending as we visited the Vysehrad Cemetery. Boy, was it spooky! Cold rain was pouring down, the wind was blowing, dead flowers lay around the graves mixed with new Christmas wreaths. Only a handful of people were about the site because of the cold and rain. We looked for the famous gravesites, but couldn't find any without a good map. Even though the rain was pouring, we still had a great time. We were armed with umbrellas and waterproof winter jackets and waterproof boots. I would definitely recommend this site because it gives you a break from the city, it is steeped in history, and the sprawling rocky hilltop complex is stunning!

Not very famous but very nice. Vysehrad is the second castle in Prague and it is a little bit far from the centre. Mostly its not added to tourists maps but its really worth the visit. There is a huge park around one of the most beaufitul cathedrals in Prague,where you can sit down and just enjoy your picnic. Also you can see and visit there a cemetery, where are many famous Czech writers, actors and artists and its for free. Also the price for the cathedral is very low. From Vysehrad you have a nice view on Prague and Moldau and a BIG PLUS for me is that there are not so many tourists.

Very quite and a place with amazing views. We chose to walk here instead of take a bus or tram( and its not as far as it looks). Go on a Thursday/ Friday and you can catch the fresh produce market on the way which was just lovely.There is alot to see, but at the same time not much. There are very little sights that you will see at the place itself, with the church and the cemetery the main attract. The walls when you enter are fabulous, however the view from the top of the whole of prague is what you go for. Its so tranquil and quiet, with a lovely little place to drink at( however rather expensive), and a play area for the kids. Worth a morning out to see.

Silence and great view. In early mornings you can walk here in silence without meeting a lot of Peoples. Only a few dog-owners.The view of Prague is amazing. The Church is also wort a visit. If you are hungry or just want a beer you can try a traditional czech restaurant in a basement: Restaurace U ztracených klíčů, at Lumirova nr 23. I have tried their schnitzel ,,,, yammi

Underrated. Had extra time one day and dicided to visit this -slightly out of the way- castle. Loved it! Preffered it by far to other more popular places such as Wenseslas Square. Less tourist, best views of Prague!
fresh air. Cool place on a warm day. There's a great view and it's peaceful. It's a good place to get away from the crush of tourists and traffic below.

Beautiful oasis in the city. Large green areas, beautiful view of the city and few tourists. It's easy to get there, just take the metro to Vysehrad and walk for a cpl of minutes, and still the tourists seem to miss it. Bring something to eat. The restaurants and cafes are mediocre.
A beautiful View of Prague. Vysehrad was a beautiful place to visit, a fabulous view, and a nice Beer garden to enjoy a sunny day!

Great views and place to escape the crowds. This place is a great spot when you had enough of the city centre crowds. It takes just minutes to get there by metro or tram and it's absolutely magic. We spent a couple of hours there walking around the walls, parks and visited the cemetery of famous people where rest for example Bedrich Smetana, Antonin Dvorak, Karel Capek, Alfons Mucha and Bozena Nemcova and the Basilica of St Peter and St Paul. We enjoyed the views of Vltava and the city. Lovely place to spend a sunny afternoon. Also there is no admission fee.

Nice place to visit.. Essentially a park, cathedral and a graveyard, this area of Prague is great to get away from the packed streets of the old town. The paths following the edges of Vysehrad also offer some of the best views over the city and river. A nice spot to spend an hour or so.

Nothing spectacular. A cathedral, a cemetery, a pleasant walkway around a pleasant park with large statues. All up on a high ridge overlooking the Vltava River and Prague's city landscape below. Certainly a good view.

Interesting graveyard and great views of Prague you don't get anywhere else. We went there not knowing anything about the place. The graveyard is quite interesting and worth a look. I would like to go back knowing more about the place, like the famous people buried there. The church is new by Prague standards but still very impressive and worth the visit as well. We walled through the park area and went to the wall for the views. This is what impressed me the most. I have never seen these views of Prague in any guide book. This place should be visited but I think you should plan at least half a day and read up on the monument first and go in somewhat educated.

Worth a visit if you have time. got the red metro line out to Vysehrad and had a pleasant wander around, enjoying the peace and quiet.The views to the old town are great and the cemetry is worth a visit if you like that kind of thing.we walked back into town, stopping for lunch at the Staropramen Brewery just across the river, and then along the river back to Charles Bridge via the Lennon Wall.

This place is magic. 15 minutes walk down south from Karlovo Namesti metro station, I arrived at Vysehrad to visit the graves of Bedrich Smetana and Antonin Dvorak. Outside the cemetary gate was the church of St Peter and St Paul. The doors were closed, so I walk around where the vineyard was and from there had a view of Vlatava river minus the many bridges. The church opened at 5pm. Went in to witness a baby baptism service. Later had coffe at a cafe opposite the church. When I asked the waiter, what he thinks of the place, he said "this place is magic" :)
Nice park. Busy park, files with locals. Has a nice view and a small museum about communism and Czech history. If you have free time go for a walk and check out the surroundings.
Love this place!. I like this place, always go there during summers. Nice beer garden. Good place for day time walk. I would like it if they have some resturants there!
Pretty view. Pretty view from the hills - everything is spread before the eyes so clearly. Cosy streets, beautiful small buildings.

Lovely area, well worth a visit. We really enjoyed walking through this scenic area, with its lovely views across the river and landscaped areas to relax and unwind from the hustle and bustle of the main city. There are cafes and beer gardens in the area, which on a chilly afternoon provided welcome refreshment and would be a great way to while away a summer's evening. Our main reason for visiting this area was to stroll around the cemetery; sounds morbid but we wanted to see Mucha's memorial after visiting the Mucha Museum earlier that day. The cemetery is really interesting, and there are many memorials to artists and musicians buried here, including Smetana and Dvorak as well as Mucha. The memorials are works of art in themselves, with sculptures and painted decorations to admire.
Beautiful. This was one of the highlights of Prague for me, beautiful area. Make sure you spend a few hours wandering the grounds.

Excellent views of the city. The views from the top of the walls is amazing. Has a 10th century building, some of the original statues from Charles Bridge, and some incredible sculpture in the cemetery. It is also where Antonin Dvorak and Alphonse Mucha are interred.

Great views of the city. We went there around 9am in the morning. Most of the places were open at 10am. So, we walked along the wall which has very nice views of the Prague. There are many look-out area to see the Prague from different angles. The entire complex is so peaceful and charming.We also visited the church which is very beautiful. do not miss the treasure exhibition at the left corner of the entrance.

Great spot with great views. Recommend getting just a bit out of town to visit the Vysehrad area. The park is lovely with a beautiful gothic church (only 30 Kc entrance--well worth it). The views of Mala Strana and the river are great. It was a peaceful diversion from the hustle and bustle of the city. This is a short walk from the Vysehrad metro stop. There are also several beer gardens and cafes to further enjoy a sunny day.

Hidden gem of an area. It was a bit out of the way but I'm so glad I visited Vysehrad. It was like another town within Prague itself full of green spaces and great views of the city. A true hidden gem on Prague in my eyes.

A nice relaxing stroll.. Take the red line metro and get off at Vysehrad stop and its a 10 minute walk to the walls and the start of a very nice park. Originally this was a fortress complex guarding the approach to the bend in the river and there are some wonderful views down the Vltava looking away from Prague where the city thins into countryside. The park and the sculptures and the church are lovely, there is a particularly interesting albeit small exhibition at the moment of chalices and reliquary crosses in the church that is worth seeing but the jewel of this area is the cemetery. Many famous Czech artists, painters, writers and actors are buried here and it's rather peaceful, the sheer variety of headstones and crosses and the sculptures are well worth seeing, from art deco to orthodox there is a lot to see.
Best place. One of the best place for relax in nature in Prague. Beautiful joyful walks every season, summer hanging out, playing football or just sitting in grass,having a beer. I do love Vyšehrad.

Nice relaxed place. As an inhabitant of Prague Vyšehrad area is one of my favourite places. Nice area with a bit of history and still quite and not full of tourists, green park with many places where you can sit and just relax. Na hradbách restaurant is also nice situated on the Vyšehrad´s walls and have really good beer and grilled stuff.
A lovely walk. Enjoyed this walk through the park and around the church and graveyard . Much more relaxed and less crowded than the castle. The views from here are great.

Vysehrad. Vysehrad contains beautiful views of the city and shouldn't be missed. When we visited, we were able to take our time exploring the grounds and weren't overwhelmed by crowds of summer visitors that are present many other places. This is a great place to relax and get some great views (and photos) of the city.

Nice views and Cathedral. When you get to Vysehrad you will see some of the nicest homes in Prague as well as getting some great views of the river and city. The church at the end of the park is amazing. The interior is all art nouveau painting. The cemetary is very interesting as well.

Do not miss the Church or Cemetary. Wonderful walk..easy to get to from the metro (about 10 min walk or less?) The interior of Sanits Peter and Paul church is all done in the Mucha style. Soft peaceful less grand of an interior that that of St. vitus.Some of the most beautiful headstones I have ever seen in the cemetary..not creepy at all..the whole area seemed imbued with love and care.... little quiet cafe right near the church

Special place. If you've seen all the regular attractions in Prague, you must spend part of a day exploring Vysehrad Fortress. The view of Prague is one of the best and while you are there, you must go into the Casement to see the collection of some of the ORIGINAL statues from Charles Bridge which are kept there to preserve them. The cemetery and the Church of St Peter and Paul are beautiful also. There are not many tourist visiting Vysehrad so that makes it extra special!

A hidden gem. The Vysehrad castle was recommended to us by Caroline and Jan of Taste of Prague. They recommended that we visit the Vysehrad on a Saturday morning and then walk down to the farmers' market on the river banks, and that's exactly what we did. The views, the gardens, the church, the cemetery - we loved it all. As an added bonus, you get to see the local side of Prague. There were only a few tourists at the Vysehrad, and just locals at the farmers' market below, which was both a delicious and fun experience (you eat your food, listen to the band, feed the swans, watch the river and the Prague castle in the background).

Give yourself plenty of time. We walked up here after a long day at the castle and Petrin hill and relised we weren't too far to go visit 'Pragues other castle' Well we got up here and even though our guide book (Lonely Planet Pocket Prague) said it closed at 5 everything there closed at 4pm.It was still a beautiful complex if not a bit off the beaten track, but it was quiet and I'm sure it would have been even better if we had got there before the different buildings closed.

Great place, good view. Got there almost by accident.Park, church and fort battlements are very pleasant. View of Prage - one of the best!!!Most of the visitors are locals, so prices at the restaurants and caffees are within reason.

Excellent views. Vyšehrad excellent views of the city from the citadel ramparts. Don't stick to the main road through the park, climb up onto the walls and look around. Be sure to start from the Vyšehrad metro station (line C) as that avoids a long-ish walk up from street level. Instead, walk down the hill and steps to the river, and in good weather it's then a pleasant walk along the towpath back towards the centre.

A relaxing, stimulating walk with spectacular views of River and City. We got off Metro at Vysehrad, walked 10 mins towards the river and this brings you out on top of the old fort battlements with cliffs that drop to the river below, a camera is a must for great view photos. Then visit the old church and the cemetery for interest and atmosphere. Exit the park and there are a couple of nice cafe bars as you enter the sloping street. Then walk a few blocks downhill to the river where you can walk back to the old town along the river banks, popping onto one of the islands along the way. You will also go right past the Fred and Ginger building. The walk back takes about an hour. Just lovely.
well worth visiting. Well worth going. Slightly off the center of town but just hop on the #3 tram. Church is great and has great bells.

Loved Vysehrad. We heard about Vysehrad on our tour of the Town Hall. Vyšehrad is a historical fort located in the city of Prague only 15 minutes away from the town centre via the Metro. It was probably built in the 10th century, on a hill over the Vltava River. Situated within the castle is the Basilica of St Peter and St Paul, as well as the Vyšehrad Cemetery, containing the remains of many famous people from Czech history. It also contains Prague's oldest surviving building, the Rotunda of St Martin from the 11th century. It was the site of the first Prague Castle. Local legend holds that Vyšehrad was the location of the first settlement which later became Prague.We loved the church and thought it had the most beautiful interior we had seen and that's saying something considering Prague is full of beautiful churches. The grounds are so peaceful and the views over the river just lovely. When we visited everything was covered in snow but I bet the gardens and grounds are even more beautiful in summer. It's well worth a trip to.

Nice stroll around the city wall. We had no expectations when visiting Vysehrad. We know nothing about it. It was a nice way to spend 2-3 hours, walking around the city wall, looking and the church and cemetary and other monuments. Also the view of the Vltava is great.
Awesome view and amazing cemetary. A bit out of the way but well worth it.Very old part of Prague with an amazing cemetary.Very small fee and awesome park area.Used to be a castle.

A Most Impressive View. We spent an entire morning walking the grounds of Vysehrad Castle -- even in the winter time the grounds were quite impressive with the view across the city while walking along the top of the outer wall. Equally impressive was the view of the Vltava river and Prague Castle, the second castle of Prague. Most impressive was the fact that Vysehrad was the founding point for the city of Prague back in the 10th century. There were various biergarten type places to stop and enjoy all the views from this location. It will be gorgeous here in the springtime when all the various garden areas and vineries start to awaken from their winter slumber! This would be a fantastic place for a summer picnic with all the trees and sights to see,

Hidden treasure. We were not surprised that this place is kept such a a secret. It is far off the beaten path and if our hotel had not been in close vicinity we also would have missed this gem. But so it was only a ten minute walk to get to the grounds. Once there we enjoyed how peaceful it was. Again, as for so many places of interest, it's best if one comes prepared with some knowledge of the history to fully appreciate this place. A poster below gave a pretty detailed description, so I leave it at that. Don't miss this.

away from the crowds. this is a beautiful park. there are great views from the river here. several cafes to get warm drinks- I was a bit leary of the grog and warm wine didn't sound appealing- but boy was i wrong- just try-

Best way to waste a few hours. Vysehrad is a great place to get a birds eye view of the city and take a peaceful walk. We walked around Vysehrad grounds for hours, then stopped off for some apple strudel and honey cake in the grounds cafe! One of our most enjoyable days in Prague

beautiful spot. This is a lovely place to visit and walk around seeing an area that was settled a long, long time ago. A close walk from the metro and clearly defined where to walk to. Has great views of the river.

Vysehrad (Vyšehrad). Vyšehrad, at one time the second Prague castle, a princely seat in the 10th century and a royal seat in the 12th century. Situated at a strategicaly important place overlooking the Vltava river on the Prague basin. Its significance was understood by Charles IV who built a Gothic fortress here. In 1420 the castle was destroyed by Hussits troops and the area was transformed gradually into a little town. Vyšehrad became a baroque citadel in 1654.Vyšehrad Cemetery, the resting place of outstanding personalities of Czech science and culture, is dominated by the common tomb Slavín, with sculptural figures by Josef Maudr from 1892. The architectonic remodelling of the cemetery and the design for Slavín was the work of Ant. Wiehl in 1889-1893. In Park is sculptures by Josef Václav Myslbek - Ctirad and Šárka, Závoj and Bivoj, Lumír and Song and Přemysl and Libuše.Vysehrad area - church St Peter and Paul was remodelled 1887 in the Neo-gothic style.

Great Graveyard, other sites not open.. We managed to find the Vysehrad National Monument with easy, however on arrival parts of the educational attractions were not open. The small museum has a small selection of objects but nothing spectacular. The surrounding area is great to walk around if you have the time. The absolute highlight was the graveyard in the church grounds. The array of headstones and decorative artwork on the graves is a must see (for anyone into art history/decorative arts/history) and should not be missed.
Interesting. This was an interesting sight, but very cold in winter. Worth a trip, but not the highlight of our trip.

Beautiful Views. Vysehrad has some seriously stunning views of the city - especially at twilight. There really isn't much left to see up there except the church and the cemetery, but I think it would be absolutely wonderful during the summer, as there are lots of benches and sprawling lawn areas - a real breath of fresh air. Come up here even if it's winter, though, to get some pictures better than the postcards.

Charming. Charming area of town with small eateries and pubs mixed with historic attractions including St Nicholas and Our Lady Under the Chain churches, Wallenstein Gardens. and the Lennpn Wall Less crowded that the Old town.

Hidden gem. This place is well worth a trip. You can see the traditional cemetery (with Dvorak and Smetana's memorials) and the church is incrediblely decorated inside. It's high up so can be windy but there are places to get a hot drink.

Place to feel history. Cathedral an cemetery with a lot Czech history. Great park and the neighborhood if you go down the hill from the park. During the winter not as interesting especially in the evening, everything is closed very early.

Off the Beaten Track but well worth a look. We vistied this monument on our second day and it was ous favourite trip of all. Its about 20 mins on a tram ride from the Old Town. You pay 24KN (approx 80pence) and climb the steps to the hilltop. The monument is to the origins of Prague and includes the Church of St Peter/Paul, Cemetary, Cellars, Museum. The Church is highly decorated with Art Nouveau images. Its free to wander around. The churchyard includes the graves of Alphonse Mucha, Dvorjak, Smetana and the statuary is wonderful. You might walk past the cellars without a second glance but check them out. For 50KN (approx £1.80) you are led down a .6km passage into a grand hall of six statues from the Charles Bridge. The Museum at the opposite side of the complex is also 50KN and is full of some of the first archaeology from Prague along with myths and legends of old Prague. All in all this was a really cheap day but fantastically interesting. An added bonus was the garlic soup in the Terrace cafe in front of the church. Absolutely wonderful and the waiter was very friendly.
Do not miss this.. We almost missed this. We went on our last day in Prague and what a shame if we had missed this. Beautiful vistas of Prague, quiet, off the beaten path.

Peaceful, uncrowded with great views of the city. The “other” castle in Prague may not have the showy lights that Prague Castle does, but it’s a beautiful place to visit. Easy to get to from the trains, you’ll first encounter the beautiful round private chapel that was later turned into ammunition storage! The door hinges on it are impressive and the small tower is beautiful. The grounds have statues on the spacious lawns, and on the far side near the water are the ruins of the old castle. The church here is incredibly beautiful as well. The red tiled door and sculptures on the outside are gorgeous! As you cross the front of the church heading toward the wall, the views of the city and the river are amazing. Try to go on a Saturday morning and then walk down the hill and across the road to the edge of the water to visit the Farmer’s market. They have a variety of cheeses, meats, fruits and vegetables along with some handcrafted items. Get a hot mead, wine or coffee and it makes for a lovely walk!

Interesting gem just off the normal tourist trail. We stayed in a hotel which was just a short walk to Vysehrad and given the hustle-and-bustle of the old town it was wonderfully tranquil. Certainly worth a visit.

Pretty Views Of Prague... This is a much less visited place but in my opinion a must see.The views of the city from the top leave you speechless...and since this place has less tourists...you can hardly find a soul or two while you take a leisurely and picturesque walk!It's easily reachable by a combination of public transport and a MUST SEE.
A Calm place close to the center. There is a lot of people everywhere in the center, so to have a bit of calm with nice landscape around you, it is the place to be.

pleasant get-away from the inner city tourist crowd. Vysehrad is definitely worth a visit. You can easily spend half a day there.Go to Metro Vysehrad. From there a pleasant walk of 10 minutes to the 'castle' grounds. There is a few coffeeshops and restaurants. Enjoy a glass of good Czech beer there. Or just the view down to the river and into the centre.Most special and worthwhile is the old cemetery, full of works of art and being 'home' for so many famous Czechs.

Prague's other castle. This castle wasn't on my tourist map and I wasn't able to find any information in my city guide either. I just heard the Vysehrad was also worth a visit... And it definitely was! It took me a while to get there by foot from the old town city centre, but it was worth the effort. The view from the castle also very nice, you can see different parts of Prague. The church and the cemetery are very beautiful as well. It's like a very little town on its own... You can walk around for a few hours and afterward I can guarantee you that you'll feel relaxed and very peaceful. Also very beautiful during winter time, even when the visibility is a bit poor.

stopped in time... A short trip..As you wonder around the area it is like taking a trip back in time. The cemetary has some of the most beautiful grave sites..quiet and peaceful ..Make sure you get up on the wall around the town, as the views are unreal!!!

The best for me. Particularly the basilic is great and Vysehrad for me is the gem in Prague. It's one the most important sites in Prague with nice walls and from these walls, you'll have a great look over Prague.

Worth the Effort. A little off the beaten track it is easy to get there by tram and walk up the hill. The church is beautifully decorated and the Cemetry is well worth wandering around, including the graves on Smetana and Dvorak

Good half day trip. If you want see something different from prague centre, it is ideal for trip Vyšehrad. We reccomed use underground to get there. - Station Vyšehrad, From wall is really nice wiew on Vltava river and part of city centre. From vyšehrad you can go down and near the river back to the centre.
hustle bustle. this bridge is totally pedestrian.... busy busy... interesting views and statues all the way across.. lots of street artists.....lovely at early evening........

In the outskirts of Prague, but worth a visit. The metro station Vysehrad is nearby. The old castle area with a quite impressing Cathedral is nice for walking around in particular in good weather. Fantastic view to the City and the River.The cemetery at the church has the graves of the great composers Smetana and Dvorsac.There are several cafes in the area for a break and a good beer or lunch.

Wonderful last day in Prague. Vysehrad is wonderful. Easy to get to via metro. Highlight was visit to Church of St. Peter/St. Paul and an extend walked through cemetary. I can only imagine how beautiful the park area is in the spring/summer. Did this on our last day and it was a relaxing way to end our visit in Prague.

TIME OUT TIME. Fifth time here,first was as early as 1979 and "a must" for some silence after busy hours of day and night.A morning destination after the breakfast,take metro C and spend half or an hour wandering in this historic castle park,lots of view,lovely with fog,head down to a cafe boat for a quick coffee before rushing back to your touristic squares.....

A place to rest in peace. This is the original place of the Prague Castle from which only parts of foundations are preserved. The views from here are magnificent, the parks serene and the most famous cemetery in the country a place to reflect. Antonin Dvorak rests here ...

Prague's other castle. It was a bit of a trek, but we went to see Prague's other castle, and spent a good few hours walking around the grounds and the cemetery. It was a nice relaxing afternoon, and well worth the trek.

Refreshing in local experience and great views. This is the location of the cathedral of Peter and Paul, a very nice church. The cemetery alone is worth the visit. Beautiful gravestones. Excellent views of the city and river from the heights. Easy to reach via trams. Beautiful park area also. I am very happy that I made the visit.

Interesting, tranquil.. This well laid out park and museum is worth visiting for historical reasons and for fine views of the city. Take refreshments and enjoy the peace after the crowds down in the centre.
Worth visiting if you fancy a walk in the fresh air. Got away from the crowds of Old Town for 3 hours and thoroughly enjoyed a wander around this area, which is easy to reach by Tram or Metro.

A pretty place a little out of the way. A serene and peaceful area, a little outside of the main attractions. We had lunch at a small cafe in the area, walked the perimeter for some gorgeous views of the river and made our way back into town.
Beautiful views of the city. Stroll the walls/fortifications for great views over the city, river, residential and business districts. Relaxing and beautiful (and free).
Not too many tourists - luckily. Wonderful places - park, cemetery and church - full of art and history. Great view of the city from the top of the hill.
impressive. We enjoyed the entire area, it was like a little history lesson, but I was impressed by the 20 minutes tour of the secret corridor

Not to be missed. Sadly we left this to the end and were running out of time but we enjoyed the spectacular views and the real sense of history. The church, is the only original building still standing and is worth a visit.

Don't miss it!!. This is a delightful park. A huge fortress with high walls on a hill overlooking the whole of prague. You can walk on the walls of the fortress in a near complete 360 degrees with stunning views over the whole of prague including back at Prague Castle. One of the highlights of our trip and we would highly recommend it. It's a little further away than most Prague attractions but we walked to and from and it was very pleasant. A must do. If you walk there then don't forget to stop at St Cyril and St Methodius Crypt - a very moving and powerful museum that honours some very brave people that resisted German occupation. Probably our overall highlight of our time in Prague!

Completely worth a visit. This is located right next to the Danube up a hill. It's beautiful and good peaceful walk around the park grounds and cemetery. We visited this after we visited Frank Gehry's Fred and Ginger House. Definitely worthwhile if you have the time for the beautiful views and walk in nature.
Fantastic beautiful place. One of the most beautiful cathedrals I've ever seen. It is a true wonder of the world. Everyone who visits Prague must see it.

Lovely spot. This is a very pleasant area for a walk. It is a set of fortifications which gives some very fine views over the city. The graveyard of the St Nicholas church contains the graves of Dvorak, Smetana and Suk if you are musically inclined. It was rather quiet when I was there on a warm Sunday and I found it quite peaceful and relaxing. Some nice old buildings, red squirrels and parks. Good number of eat and drink spots too. Easily accessed by metro

Great for easy walk and relaxation. A little bit displaced from Prague's central attractions could be easily skipped, which would be a great mistake. With spacious parks, great views and fascinating old cemetery - just beside Gothic cathedral which dominates the whole place, Vysehrad is definitely quiet oasis totally worth visiting.
Must see, if not just for the view. The place has nice atmosphere, nice views, all in all, for and afternoon picknick in a walking distance (2 km) from the center great idea

Worth the effort.. This park and historical site is very peaceful and interesting. The church is stunning, very famous Czechs are buried here (Smetana, Dvorak, etc) and the oldest church in Bohemia, the little Rotunda church, is delightful to see. There are a couple of inexpensive and good cafes/restaurants here inside the walls, too.

Beautiful and peaceful. Many people, myself included, comment that Prague is heaving with tourists ... but not here, though it deserves just as much attention as those much-thronged attractions in the City centre. It is easily accessed as it is just 2 metro stops from the centre. Get off at the Vysehrad station, you then have a walk of about half a mile - there is the occasional signpost.Vysehrad is enclosed in castle walls and is set very high above the Vltava - the views are absolutely spectacular. Looking down from the walls, you can make out the roofs of some of the cubist houses at the foot of the cliff. You can actually walk down to ground level - easier than walking up. The parkland within the castle walls is a pleasure to walk around and there are 2 or 3 places where you can stop for a drink or some food. Perched on the cliff face is a 14th century ruin of a watchtower, known as Libuse's bath - Libuse was the daughter of a mythical Czech king.The 2 main landmarks are Basilica of St Peter and St Paul and the National Cemetery. If you walk around the cemetery you will see quite a few famous Czech names on the grave stones.If you can get here when the weather is good, it provides an exceptionally relaxing experience, so don't tell anyone about it.

Good viewpoint and nice place. This place is 10 minutes from center by subway - do not miss it.You can walk on old walls - there is a great view to city and river. Cathedral is very nice, but when I was there entrance was prohibited.

Vyšehrad, Prague. Really a beautiful place, breathing with peace and history, despite the numberless visitors. Architecture lovers, a must see place to go to. I'm sharing with you my sketch of the Capital Dome of the St. Peter and Paul. An amazing piece of architecture.

great venue. I personally think this is a better overall experience than Prague Castle having been to both a number of times. This castle is not as restored and is more open and laid back than Prague Castle. A great place for a picnic and people watching. Breathtaking views up and down the river.

Get away from the crowds! Enjoy great views!. Beautiful cemetery for important and famous czech people such as Dvorak, the music composer. Then there is the church with colourful doors which were closed when I was there. Passed the church there is a very large garden with huge statues of the founders of Prague with a small museum about the beginnings of the city. From this garden you can have awesome views of the Vltava river and part of Prague in the background. I strongly recommend a visit if you want to spend some relaxing, quiet time away from other tourists and take some incredible photos especially if you come in the late afternoon like I did. This place is popular mainly with czech families, couples, runners and walkers.

Nice views over the River Vltava and Prague. If you have couple of hours to spare you should climb the rock where the Vysehrad is based and strall around. It is almost tourist free place and you have beautiful views over the city and the river Vltava
Great views and nice park. I am so glad I visted this area. I actually went twice. The views are spectacular. Also, the church is a must see as well as the cemetary. Absolutely beautiful

Great views. This was really pleasant historic site. The church has awesome art nouveau decoration and murals on the interior. The site has really unique views of the river and the city. Therea are also a couple really nice cafes.
peaceful afternoon. Lovely to get out of the city, very peaceful, well maintained easily accessed and very interesting place

A time to reflect. On the recommendation of the proprietor of the guest house in which I was staying while in Prague, I took the ten minute walk to Vysehrad and I was very pleased with my experience there. The whole area exudes a very calming and peaceful feeling and it was quite nice to reflect on Prague's past, it's beginnings right there overlooking the beautiful river and the people buried in the cemetery who spent much of their lives in Prague, making it the remarkable city that it is. While Vysehrad is not on the top of the list of typical tourist attractions in Prague, it is well worth the trip...for the history,the views of the city and the river from high above the normal "touristy" hustle and bustle ...and certainly for the opportunity to reflect on Prague's amazing history.

Vysehrad Church. We took the metro down and the tram back. A worthwhile visit. A quiet site after the bustle of the Old Town. The cemetery was worth visiting. Some of the national heroes of the Czech Republic are buried here. There is a map to help you find them, for example: Anton Dvorak. We didn't think the museum was worth the entry fee. Just wander the surroundings and look at the view of the river. The church is lovely, a small fee. There was an interesting exhibit of photographs while we were there. We even saw a wedding here that day.

Don't Miss The Casemates. Loved going here, such a beautiful and peaceful place - very much for the locals and not too many of them either. We went in summer, it was very hot and lovely to walk around the ramparts and see over the city and the river. I would recommend strongly not to miss the casemates, which could easily be done. Either approach from the Brick Gate or make your way to the Brick Gate (very easy, go to the Rotunda and keep walking on down the cobbled path until you see the big brick built gate) and go to the right hand side. There is a small exhibition or you can pay 50kc (adult, or 30kc for children) to go on the guided tour which is on the hour. It's not much of a tour as such, but you are taken through a cool tunnel (feels underground but is not) and after 5 minutes or so of walking you come to an opening of a big hall. It's dark and atmospheric, and you can see the 5 or 6 original statues from the Charles Bridge. I believe they use this for art exhibitions and sometimes weddings. The tour guide doesn't speak great English, so it's backed up by a printed sheet which gives all the information you might otherwise miss. Definitely a must see, very different!

Lovely place. Online and pocket guides didnt say anything special about place, but my boyfriend and decided to give it a go, and we were surprised how a pretty place stayed without tourist's attention! The view from Vysehrad is really pretty, and taking a walk around the place is so relaxing..it's like peaceful oasis in the crowded city. There is also a beautiful church with an old graveyard where important people from 19th century are buried...Overall, a pleasant experience!

Vysehradan is wonderful. my pocket guide didn't say anything spectacular about this and I had doubts on whether I should visit it or not but I'm glad I did. The monument is located in a quiet park and the view from there it's really beautiful. It is best as a break from the crowded center of the city.

The origins of Prague. Vysehrad may be a little far away from the center, going there is worth it! I were positively surprised by the cemetery, which was really beautiful. If you're courageous enough you can walk along the riverside to the "Dancing house".

A Real Gem. One of the highlights of our stay was spending a day here, far away from the crowds but with some of the best views of the city. Great for a quieter picnic to chill out during a busy week.
strolling time. quite a wide area covered, nice cafe in the middle, lots to gaze at and the stairs down to the road were not too steep, enjoyed the views
The "other" place. I found this castle/church quite by accident, seeing it from the river. It was less crowded than the main castle by the Charles bridge and very peaceful.
Lovely views and walk. The view from Vysehrad is mind blowing. The panoramic views of the entire city and the valley are wonderful. Had a nice walk around and it wasn't too crowded.

Prague's other castle. Visited this as it was near the Corinthia Hotel where we stayed. But well worth going to if staying elsewhere.Quite a change from the crowds of the central attractions. Site of a former Prague castle, with a few original buildings and more recent rebuilt walls etc. Leafy and relaxed.intersting bailica with frescoes in art nouveau style. Moving to see the graves and memorials for Dvorak and Smetana in teh national cemetery next to the church.Fabulous views of the Vltava river from the ramparts.
Worth visiting!. Even if it wasn't in the center, we loved this place for it was not crowded by tourists and we found there a well maintained park. The church and cemetery are also worth visiting.

Lovely place. This place is very much underrated. We went there on our last day, after seeing all the major tourist attractions multiple times. It was easy to find -- just two train stops from Museum station. Vysehrad is located away of the tourist crowds. We really enjoyed a walk in this park overlooking the entire city. When we got tired of walking we found a nice restaurant with outdoors seating, not fancy -- mostly local people enjoying fresh food and beer.

Beautiful and tranquil - take the kids. We live here and this is where we go to get away from the tourists. The views are stunning, the atmosphere tranquil and there is a great kids' playground which is in the shade. Unlike many other Prague parks it isn't overrun with dogs. Don't miss the beautiful Art Deco murals inside the church. Take your camera or a book and just soak up the peace and quiet. It's also lovely in the snow.
History and beauty all In one. When you are looking for a get away from old town this is the place to go. Amazing views of Prague and the church of St. Peter and Paul.

Away from the crowds.
