Although only a couple of tram stops away this is a peaceful and quite place for a walk, its a steep approach up to it via a lot of steps which are on the left just after the traffic lights bu the railway bridge, once up there its a world apart, wonderful views of the river and a relaxing place to sit and stroll about

A beautiful place to spend a relatively quiet summer afternoon. Vysehrad is a beautiful fortress that doesn't seem to be visited much by tourists, which we thought was great! Its a great place to wander slowly, relax on the grass, or try to find the graves of the famous Czechs buried at the onsite cemetery. Walk around the fortress walls to see some spectacular views over Prague.

Quiet spot, great views. Little hard to get to but when you do the walk around the ramparts of old castle and the park are lovely. The view down the river to Hradcany castle is Prague at is beautiful best.

Cosy place where you can see lot of locals. You can read everything in your guide book, so I will tell you something not that known. When you enter the last gate, before you pass around the rotunda, turn right and climb up. There is a little courtyard with grill: you can have sausage, very cheap beer or Kofola (Czech lemon Cola) and many other little foods. It has view on the city, lot of locals and very nice atmosphere. Of course, you must come during summer or at least during weekend.

Chill out and walk the ramparts. An excellent place, not well advertised, but worth going to after the hustle of the old town. You can walk the ramparts, which are really well maintained, the monuments and odd open air exhibition are worth a view as well. All in all a hidden jewel, worth half a day and an excellent coffee and cake.

Peace of mind. This is my favorit place in Prauge. Here you can walik arond in peace and quiet, there are plety to se, for example the Basilika Minor. The wiw over Vltava is incredible, there is a big playground for the children and plety og plases to get fodd and drink.

Beautiful and peaceful. Lovely place to spend half a day wandering around the grounds and take in the impressive views. There was a Czech wedding taking place on the grounds whilst I was there, adding to the magic!

Beautiful basicilla and cemetery. Spent a lovely and quiet afternoon here, wandering around the rotunda (the oldest building in Prague--I think!), the monument to plague victims, the Basicilla of St. Peter and Paul (with some beautiful art nouveau/Mucha-esque paintings), and the cemetery. Fewer tourists in this area, but lots of history and great views of the river and city.
Picturesque. Absolutely mind blowing view of the river and castle fortifications ! Feels like a movie

Beautiful with less tourists. While most tourists visit the Old Castle in Castle district, there is another nice castle worth a visit on a hill near the river, Reaching it is fairly easy as its on the metro with the same name. You can also stroll along the river and reach the footsteps to go up. The graveyard there is very interesting with some really old tombstones of some famous philosophers, doctors, musicians etc. The other interesting thing is the walk along the Main walls and having wonderful views of the city in 3 directions.
Old paganic atmosphere. But spoiled by the christian cover (coat) though. One of the oldest settlements in Prague. catacombs below. Worthy seeing.

out of the city, in the city. This is a great place to spend a day. The old section is on a hill which offers great views of the city looking towards the castle across the river. the cemetery/church/sculpture garden are part of the beauty and history here. A must do if you can walk the hill.
a peaceful oasis. Get away from the tourist hordes! This is easy to get to as well. We found the graveyard interesting. Views on Prague are excellent.
Worth a visit!. Offers some spectacular views of Prague from the Vysehard hill top and has a lovely garden, if you choose to laze around in the afternoon and want to take it easy.

Beautiful place for recreation and evening walk.. This park and monument are sometimes skipped by the visitors of Prague, but I think that the beauty and special ambience of this sire makes it one of the "must-to-visit" locations.

Beautiful place. Third time here and it still amazes me. The bell of this church rings in a much more beautiful melody than the one on the old Prague Castle. Advised to go right before any O'clock hour

Great views of Prague. Here you won't find as many tourists as in the centre, so you can 'quietly' enjoy the walks and views. The park itself is quite big. You could easily spend an hour or two there. I would especially recommend the cemetery there. Some famous Czechs have made it their last resting place and they wouldn't want you to miss it as some of them are quite big.

Very Nice. Vysehrad is another must. I'm lucky enough to see the cathedral outside my window and I never get tired of walking the grounds. You can take a tram or the metro to get there (will still need to walk a bit). It's never crowded, it has a peaceful cemetery with lots of famous people buried there, the singing of birds is so relaxing it can put you to sleep...I could go on forever. Plus, there is an amazing view of Prague Castle from there! Best to go at sunset.

Away from the crowds. Its in the opposite direction from the other main attractions, its rather quite and on a sunny days its where the locals hang out! you'll see families, couples all around. Great views from the other side of the city.

Marvellous atmospheric cemetery. Vysehrad is more than just a cemetery, but it is the cemetery which is really the reason to visit. You'll find the graves and memorials of the great Czechs, especially cultural figures - composers Dvorak and Smetana, for example. It is a packed, chaotic graveyard, with remarkable monuments all competing for attention. There are marvellous examples of Art Nouveau, but also more recent, even modern, objects which can be very idiosyncratic (Czechs seem to have an eccentric streak). Like, a gravestone with a ski leaning against it? Or a caricatured face?

Not to be missed. Get away from the tourist crowds and go and visit this remarkable place. The Church of St Peter and Paul is spectacular as is the graveyard where lots of dignitaries are laid to rest. The views from up there are amazing and give you a different perspective. It's a peaceful place with plenty of parkland and trees to give shade. We walked back into the centre and would say it was about a 20 minute walk.

A quiet oasis. Vysehrad is beautiful, serene and historic. Its just a little ways off the beaten path (you can get there by metro or tram) which makes it relatively free of giant tour groups. Wonderful views of the river and the Prague Castle. Lovely grounds with plenty of areas to sit and relax. The cemetery is very interesting and is the resting place for many Czech artists including Dvorak, Mucha, Neruda... Just a very pleasant place to visit one afternoon.
Beautiful views. Fantastic place to while away a few hours, soak up the atmosphere of ancient Prague and take in the fantastic views of the city and river below.
Very very very beautiful place !. It's a reason to return in Prague more and more. It's really fantastic place. I'll be there soon.

Chill in a park!. I recommend this place if you want to just chill in a peaceful and quiet atmoshphere above the whole city, especially during a sunny summer day. Good place to eat a picnic, study while sunbathing or take pictures of the Prague panorama. The cemetary with all famous Czech personalities is also worth visiting.
A nice stroll through the park on a spring day. We hot to the Cathedral just as a burisl ceremony was taking place. Very impressive. The cemetary is well kept and the river view is nice.

The small castle. Although you won't find a castle exactly like the Prague castle, Vysehrad is absolutely beautiful and a wonderful, peaceful alternative to the tourist smothered Prague Castle. It has a cemetery with the most famous Czechs and a beautiful lookout over the entire city of Prague.
must see!. a lovely place! quiet and perfect for a nice walk through the gardens up to the Church. The entracne to Paul and Peter's Cathedral is 30 KC and the rest are free of charge.

Visit the casements!. Vysehrad and the park surrounding the fortress are definitely worth a visit but we wouldn't have gone there a second time if we hadn't been recommended a visit of the casements. They are quite hidden in one of the arches of the Brick Gate entrance and you have to wait for a guided tour but they take place every hour, on the hour, so it's not hard to plan for that. The fee is 50 CK, the whole tour takes only about 20 minutes but it's something that you don't see every day! Especially because people concentrate on the better known sights up there you could be as lucky as we were; we were only four people visiting the place so plenty of room to admire the fortification walls from the inside and time to ask the guide questions.
nice park. Nice park - little bit of significant history. Do not miss the view.

Absolutely lovely. It is one of the places not very advertised in Prague, but certainly one of the best. It has a big and amazing park, and some interesting historical sites. Visit the Casemates! They have the original statues from Charles Bridge. The tour is most interesting. Take the time to walk around, the view is magnificent.

My favourite Prague discovery. It looks like it's miles away on a map, but it's a brisk 20 minute walk from the National Theatre. Just stroll along the Vltava, past the dancing building thing (boring) and climb the mosaic stairs off Libušina. The views are wonderful, the church is stunning, the cemetary alone is worth the walk (Dvorak, Mucha et al). And try and find The Devil's Pillar. If the weather is favourable, pack-a-picnic.

Vysehrad. A great place to escape the crowds of central Prague. Take the Metro to Vysehrad and its a short 5 min walk. (The tram will mean a much longer uphill walk). The views from here are fantastic, high above the river Vltava you get great views of Prague. Free entry and I think this is one of the oldest parts of Prague.A highlight is the national cemetery where many famous Czechs are buried. The gravestones and tombs are works of art in themselves, and there is a beautiful church nearby. Children's play area, restaurants and lots of open space lead to a relaxing visit.
beautiful. This was a great place to spend a half day walking around and looking at the views; Jan Purkynge buried here!

Nice rest from crowded tourist spots. Not many tourists here, so a pleasant place to walk around. See the graveyard with some very unique monuments, famous Czechs, and the cathedral. We were there on Sunday morning and had to leave to get somewhere else,. I would have enjoyed spending more time here.
Not so crowdy:). A very beautiful place! Not so many tourists as in the city centre, so you will have a chance to rest:)

THE must-visit destination in Prague!. A fort on a hill, with amazing views. The national graveyard for the famous; Dvorak, Smetana, Kubelik, Suk, Smetacek (to name a few composers & conductors) are buried there. A magnificent church, underground crypts, a restaurant & more!

a low key experience. It's a park, with: lovely views over the Vltava, some nice statues of legendary Czech heroes, a small graveyard with some famous people, Basilica of Peter and Paul (lovely, with art nouveau paintings of saints; 30 Kc adm), rotunda of St Martin. We didn't do the Goticky sklep (cellar) because we were tired, but apparently they have some archeological items. Small map with pics (mouse over the list) at http://www.praha-vysehrad.cz
My biggest surprise in Prague. Saw Vysehard at night – the fort, the church, the grounds and the parks, the view – a gem, incredible ambiance. My biggest surprise by far.
National monument. Good views from here and an interesting monument. Museum not open on mondays though.
Really best view on Prague castle.. Nice panorama of Prague castle, quiet place for walking and refreshing.
solitude in Prague. Take the metro to the stop of the same name and take a 10 minute walk to a perfectly maintained park with historic and religious monuments and a good view of Prague.

Beautiful view!. Came here after a nice afternoon in the Botanical gardens. We managed to come during sunset here and the view is just marvelous! Have a stroll around the place and just enjoy the skyline. You will see Prague in its full glory! There is also this very cool cemetery and church to check out! A very romantic place ;)

Great view. It is very romantic place to go to. You have an overview of the whole Prague with the Castle as well. I recommend you this place the most in the summer as you can bring a bottle of wine and enjoy the hot summer evening.

Good strolling and picture taking. Kind of off the beaten track a bit, although not really all that far out. Nice place to stroll about, with great views of Prague Castle on the other side of the Vltava River. Also the final resting place of Czech luminaries like Smetana.

Off the beaten path. Vysehard is a treasure in the city, w/o the tourist crowd. The main entrance is only 300 m from the subway station. I was there in one weekday evening (5-7pm) in the summer, and saw many locals, family and couples there after work. You get to have a good and different view of Charles river, old fort walls and some monuments, and Dvorak and Smetana's graves. The cemetery was a bit creepy and cold, and Dvorak's grave was hard to find. So beware.

What a hidden gem!. Perfect day - lovely view, quiet gardens, great cafe, awesome art gallery run by a wonderful woman who was full of life and charm! The Chapel of Saints Peter and Paul is gorgeous: I'd never seen art nouveaux paintings of major saints before and they are wonderful. The cemetary is sombre of course, but striking in it's cultural significance. Watch for the hands on the tombstone - a joyful ode to their owner and a whimsical take on the quality of remembrance. I was struck by the colloquial date format on the gravestones - I like it very much and would like to adopt the convention myself. Don't miss this place!
Excellent views. Loved this place. Could have sat there forever looking out onto the river. Bottle water is quite expensive there so take your own if you are on a budget.

Peace and quiet with great views. This haven of peace and quiet is easily reached by metro. There are lovely views of the city and the walk back down to city and river is excellent. There is a small cafe/restaurant which serves drinks and pizza at a reasonable price. There is also a kiosk for coffees etc. Well worth a trip.

Peaceful and Fascinating. I stumbled here almost accidentally. It was a rainy day and my friend and I were almost completely alone in the whole area. There was an okay view of Prague, an interesting graveyard, a very cool church-thing? I actually didn't know at the time, but that was the Cultural Monument. I also loved the huge statues of the Czech mythological characters just outside - I wanted to know their stories. There was also a playground for kids with simpler versions of the legends. And finally, when I was there, there was a photo display about the holocaust and about how many children escaped to England by train. It was so well put together and I ended up in tears. After a little bit too much crowd (I'm not really a big city person), this was the perfect retreat for us for an afternoon. It felt somehow more personal and authentic than the more crowded areas. Well worth a visit if you have time for more than the Prague basics.
beautifull view of the city. Nice walk along the river and arrive to the Castle...maybe to much for not in "shape" people...

Beautiful Art Nouveau Painted Decoration. A beautiful spot in Prague that is not completely overrun by tourists. Take the redline metro to Vysehrad station. Make a picnic from goodies gathered at the market/ Marc's and Spencers/ Tesco. Take in gorgeous views of Prague as you stroll along the rampart walls. The inside of the church (closed on Mondays, last I checked) is decorated with an art nouveau motif. They even have a relic of St. Valentine that young couples come to visit on Feb. 14, and the historic little cemetery is the resting place of some of the most beloved Czechs. After your visit, you can walk down the hill to the river side where you can catch a tram, enjoy a stroll back towards the town center, or have a beer in the outdoor beer garden at the foot of the hill.

beautiful place. I have a friend in Prague who took me here today for the first time. It's peaceful, beautiful and the church and cemetary are well worth the visit. Dvorak is buried here, too, which made it even of more interest. Worth a stroll

The Original Prague Castle. just a few stops on the Metro from the centre to the first Prague castle. Travellers note that it requires a walk up a fairly steep hill to get there - but the views are very worthwhile.

What a surprise!. I'd read so many great things on the internet about Vysehrad that I had to go. It was a nice park, watching people have a great time. Lovely place to walk around, great views. But, the most spectacular thing was the cemetery. I love cemetery's and this is the best one I have ever seen. It was more of an art museum. Beautiful and unusual headstones. I heard Dvorak is buried here, but I was short on time and didn't see it.This is right on the public transportation and easy to get to.

The Heart and Lungs of Prague. This monument and surrounding recreational area is rarely visited by tourists to Prague, which is more the pity as there is a unique blend of culture and open space at your finger tips. Enjoy the church (and graveyard) or a walk along the walls where there are spectacular views of the city. Numerous refreshment outlets compliment the park surroundings rather than dominate them. A lovely place to finish our trip.
Beautiful architecture and view. Beautiful architecture and catacombs. Advise to visit catacombs, which are very interresting.

The "Pere Lachaise" of Prague. Vysehrad makes a wonderful walk out of the centre of Prague and offers spectacular views back to the castle (walk south along the embankment, then look for the turning left after the Vyton railway bridge - there's a gold-lettered sign). But make sure you take the time to wander through the national cemetery and spot the famous names from Czech cultural life through the ages.

The best place to go for a date in Prague.. Absolutely romantic, quiet, charming and amusing place. It is the best place to go for a romantic walk, or even by yourself, enjoy the silence, fantastic view and visit some of the famous Czech artists.But please, do not tell anyone :),

On the opposite bank of Vltava river. Not so famous as Prague Castle is area of Vysehrad. The main dominant is gothic church of Petr and Pavel with very nice interieur decorations. Next the church you can find small churchyard where many of Czech famous people are buried.You can find there composers, painters, actors, conductors and poets as well.

A nice surprise. I did not put Vysehrad on our visit plan, but my friend, good in finding secret locations, pulled me to go there. Quite far from city center, but worth a walk. We climbed the hill, enjoyed the view of the river in a very calm location. We visited the Cemetery, the cathedral with its architecture and there was an exhibition in a cellar with some of the site history. You won't regret it, I think this is a place that most of the tourists don't know, so be one of the few to visit it.

Away from the tourist, yet the best of Prague. Great place to spend few hours outside, beatiful views of Prague. Try to walk around the entire area. Great playground for chilren as well, famous cemetery and catedral. Most restaurants in the area are not good/expesive. If you like to eat something, try the bistro at Holiday Inn hotel.

Prague's best kept secret. I was quite hesitant to write this review because, being a little selfish, I wanted to keep this beautiful gem a secret only for locals like myself to enjoy. Out of all the tourist destinations in Prague, Vysehrad is the least visited for one simple reason - it is away from the tourist track. You see, Prague has 3 metro (subway) lines, the red, green, and yellow lines. ALL of Prague's major attractions are on the green line...ALL EXCEPT for Vysehrad which is on the red line. And if you don't like riding on underground trains (you can't see anything after all), almost ALL of Prague's tourist destinations can be reached using tram # 22 and # 9. Unfortunately, the only way you can reach Vysehrad by tram is to take tram # 17 and hike up a hill.Why is Vysehrad worth visiting? A number of reasons. First. It is steeped in legend. From Vysehrad Hill, local legend says that Libuse prophesied that Prague will become "a golden city." And when you are on Vysehrad Hill, you can see what Libuse foresaw...which leads me to the...Second. Vysehrad has a spectacular view of the Nusle valley and all of Prague. From one end of what is left of the medieval walled fortress to the other, you can enjoy a different view.Third. Take some time in the National Cemetery. There you will see the final resting place of some of the Czech Republic's most notable citizens (Mucha, Smetana, Dvorak).Fourth. The Minor Basilica of St. Peter and St. Paul is a fine example of gothic architecture.and finally, Fifth. Vysehrad is not inundated with tourists. Yes, you will see the occasional student groups there. I myself have had picnics with several of my classes there. But for the most part, Vysehrad remains the locals' best kept secret.
nice. this is another highly recommended place, really fantastic

Do try and go here!. We ventured on the metro and walked to Vyserhad and then caught the tram back from the base by the river. What a lovely place to explore, great views. Fantastic church, the Art Nouveau murals inside were just stunning! Interesting to find Dvorak and Smetana's graves in the graveyard. Walked down to the tram passing examples of Czech Cubism. Well worth a trip!

Lovely little surprise. Going here was kind of a last minute add-on one day but I'm so glad I did. This area is up on a bluff & one of the originally settled parts of the city & seat of royalty due to its' defensive position. As a result, there are great views. a beautiful little church & cemetery with many famous Czechs buried there. Great network of paths to walk while appreciating the ancient buildings & monuments. It was not busy at all & was a nice break from the crowds at all the usual tourist spots.

go there. go to vysehrad ,visit the cementery and the church,it is a beautifull place ,specially for couples.....................metro C wich is the red line,2stops from museum,higly recomende for couples,,in love

Great place to visit, any season. I like in Prague so often we're going for walks in Vysehrad park...last time we took my sister and her bfriend there, last December...despite the cold evening they loved the place and its historical atmosphere

Wonderful 2nd castle. Visit the cemetary and go inside the 'basilica peter & paul', it is easily worth 30KR. It is stunning but also has a very special feeling and I wanted to stay there all day long.
Quiet with great views of Prague. A short tram or metro ride from city center, you can spend an hour or three visiting the cemetery, touring the old fortifications, or simply watching the river.

Great history. This attraction was only 10 minutes walk away from our hotel (Otakar) and was well worth the visit. There were fantastic views from the top of the walls. A restaurant, cafe, toilet facilities, gallery, cathedral and graveyard are all there. The graveyard was the most interesting, with graves belonging to famous Czech poets/writers, and some of the oldest graves in Prague.

Worth venturing out of the city centre. This is about a mile south of the city centre, but an easy tram ride and well worth the trip. You get great views up and down the river and a different view of Prague Castle and the city. Recommended.

Czech National Identity. In the cemetery at Vysehrad are buried a number of Czech national heroes, Smetana, Dvorak, Capek and Neruda. The setting is fabulous and the views out over the Vlatva and the city breathtaking.
Beautiful and peaceful. Stunning views, great place to get some amazing photographs.
Nice views of Prague. Good for a stroll and nice views of Prague and the river Vltava.

Another nice surprise. We got the metro to here about 8.30 one evening and were pleasantly surprised by the quietness. We had a really lovely walk and would love to visit again - beautiful and romantic. I have read about Prague since I came home and was fascinated by the history of Vysehrad
worth to visit. vysehrad is one of the best places in prague to take a walk, has very nice city view and is not that touristic as the other places

Hidden gem.... This place doesn't get much mention but is a nice visit. Has an interesting cemetry to czech heroes plus the original Charles Bridge statues are underground (for viewing).
Also some nice views of Prague as well...
Vyšehrad. Historically interesting place. Very quiet. Breathtaking iew of Prague.

Revealing the soul of the Czech city. A perfect day in Prague has to start at the castle. No, not Prague Castle, the other one. Here you can enjoy an authenticity beyond the classic tourist experience.Vysehrad is where Prague was born, a brooding fortress perched high above the Vltava. It is a quiet place, you don't see many tourists there because it is not in the centre. At weekends locals outnumber tourists here - picnicking or walking their dogs.You can stroll in the Slavin cemetery where Dvorak & Smetana are buried or you can visit the Church, or just walk in the park and enjoy the beautiful views over Prague. Finally you can amble back to the Old Town along the Vltava.
Great in the Autumn. There wasn't much here, but the grounds around Vysehrad were pretty colourful during the fall of the leaves, and was quite easy to get to following the signd.
Quiet and Peaceful. Excellent view of Prague from the citadel.Graveyard has lots of history

Worth to visit for the view. I absolutely recommend you to go to Vysehrad if you are in Prague. The view is very nice. My advice would be to take the metro to Vysehrad then make your way down the hill via Vysehrad and take the tram to go back to town. If you take the tram, it would be a hike to get to Vysehrad. If you take the metro, it would be a walk downhill from Vysehrad.

Another view of the city. Yet more wonderful views of the city, and a brilliant cemetery (!). We tried to find the southern entrance as recommended by guide books and got an unintended tour of Podolski suburb. Loads of cafes open inside even in December. Worth a look
gorgeous vista. the vysehrad not only fills up with history.. overlooking praha, it's vista are simply amazing.. the sight of the oldest baroque church was also inspiring..

A pretty, open, and educational visit. This area is very interesting, and exploring it is a lot of fun. It is a little out of the way, and so less "touristy," but full of nice surprises, including a small, but interesting historical display, and a tour of the underground storage areas (where you can see the original statues from the Charles Bridge!). We had a really nice time here.

Church, Cemetery, Views. Came here on the Saturday - to avoid the throngs in the old town and castle areas. Pleasantly busy. Don't expect great age, the twin spired church is C19 and photography not allowed despite an entry fee, and policed by a fiercesome woman. Nice park to the south and a large cemetery of notables to the north and east but I had only heard of Dvorak and Smetana! After a nice beer in the sun walked the ramparts high above the Vltava and enjoyed the views to Prague Castle and the occasional steam train on the railway bridge below.
Great change of pace!. Much less crowded than St. Vitus...we enjoyed the soothing colors and relative simplicity of the art deco frescoes.

Vysehrad - A Forgotten Place to Understand Prague's History. What is known as the Vyšehrad Castle is actually a large area comprising different attractions that my wife and I slowly discovered while walking around the premises.Historians believe (without full agreement) that the castle was built around the 10th Century and that it became the first settlement to give birth the city of Prague. Strategically, it dominates a hill over the River Vltava (the famous Moldau River). No wonder Vyšehrad Castle means "The Castle on the Heights" or “High Castle”. Its 1,000 years of History saw various periods of oppulence and decadence, dominance by kingdoms around, armies from France, Austria and others, each one either attempting to destroy or to improve Vyšehrad. Most important of all, Vyšehrad so much participated in Prague's history that Czech kings considered Vyšehrad a place to stay or a historical route to go before being kings.What impresses anyone that visits Vyšehrad is its complexity as it contains a castle, now ruins of a large fortification, the beautiful Church of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, a Rotunda, large parks with plenty of statues, a casemate and the famous Vyšehrad Cemetery, everything surrounded by large walls and paths where one can walk between the walls and vegetation.In the 19th Century, the Vyšehrad Slavin Cemetery was built. Slavin means Pantheon and that is where many famous people were buried including Antonin Dvorak, Bedrich Smetana and many other many Czech composers, artists, sculptors, writers and intellectuals since 1869.The imposing Church of Saint Peter and Saint Paul was built in the 11th Century, saw destruction and re-construction, being the last one at the end of the 19th Century.But, from everything we saw there, three things really caught our attention: the first one was the calm, large and relaxing park almost in the middle of the complex. I don’t know why, but we felt some sort of peace while walking through the park and seeing big statues representing historical people, including the Libuse Princess which started a dynasty that ruled Prague for more than 400 years. Was it maybe because Libuse was considered to have visionary powers (I would probably say, today, a “psychic” in a very good way) that prophetized Prague would be a big city? We don’t know.The second thing that caught our attention was the astonishing view of Prague from the hill where Vyšehrad stands, with the Vltava River calmly flowing below. While we were there admiring that grandeur, I could not stop thinking about how inspiring was for Dvorak and Smetana to write the beautiful pieces of art praizing their beloved Prague. I could almost “hear” Má Vlast while on top of the hill.We stayed there for quite a while just feeling the scene, the vibration, the warm Sun and the light breeze.It did not go unnoticed for me a middle-aged man there with an opened book on his hands, occasionally reading it and then staring at the river and the surroundings, back and forth. Nothing in this ritual denoted fatigue or rush; on the contrary, he seemed to be relaxed and trying to locate himself in the environment. I could not resist talking to him. Because I was very frank in asking him directly that he was kind of seizing the moment there, in his bare English, he told me he was a Czech advocate often visiting that spot in order to replenish himself with the energy emanating from that place. He showed me his book from a Czech writer stating that the place we were at was exactly one of the four vortexes of positive energy located in Vyšehrad. Chatting a little bit longer, he translated for me another passage of the book – and that came as another surprise for me – although famous, Vyšehrad would not really be emphasized as touristic attraction because it would only “naturally attract” those visitors that would “feel” the vibration of the place!Well, well, well!... I don't know anything about energy vortexes, nor they would exist there, nor there would be such an “attraction force” driving some people to the place. All I know is that we where there and that we felt the relaxing environment and its beauty.Unfortunately, we had to leave Vyšehrad behind because we were heading to Paris on a more than 1,000 km drive through Germany.I hope one day we could go back there; this time, we would spend far more time to see and feel once more what we felt there. And we encourage you to do the same when visiting Prague. May the Vortex attract you to go there as well!
Vast Museum. Many exhibits here from armor to entomology. This was a fantastic solution on a rainy day.

Quite pretty. We didn't have a whole lot of time to spend here, but I'm glad we went. The cemetery is very pretty, with beautiful tombs, especially around the sides. There are some gorgeous mosaics and sculptures. I was very disappointed that we weren't able to get in to St. Peter & St. Paul. (It's closed Mondays), as I heard it's beautiful. It is a bit of a walk from the metro station, so be ready for that.

Very beautiful park. Very beautiful park for walking to see some historic buildings and an astonishing view over prague and the Vltava river, i`ts so important to take a camera with you while you are walking in the park because you will find a very good sight to photograph. best time to visit is during the sunset .
worthed. In one word I liked Vysehrad national monument, more than prague castle.

This is an overlooked spot you should see. A lot of folks concentrate on Old Town, New Town up to St. Vitus, and this is a bit on the other side of town. Very gorgeous. Very peaceful. LOADS less tourists than those other places mentioned. The Basilica of Sts. Peter and Paul is gothic with an AMAZING art nouveau interior. Wholly worth a few hours of time to go to Vyserhad, walk the walls to see an amazing view, stroll down paths and relax in a park!

Romantic place vith riverview. It is a bit fahr from the centre, but it is worth visiting. Start at undergrout Vysehrac (C) and contiue through the park to the Cathedral of st Paul and Peter.The place, where you can see the river is famous by a brave horse, which jumped into in to save its master.

A hidden gem. I hate to tout it too highly, simply because I don't want it to become overcrowded with tourists like Old Town and Prague Castle are, but we thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Vyšehrad this past week. The cemetery is particularly worthwhile for music and literature buffs, with its graves of Antonín Dvořák, Bedřich Smetana, Karel Čapek, Raphael Kubelik, and Karel Ančerl.

Fortress with nice views, good park for picnics, a bit of a hike. Vysehrad is an ancient fortress with a beautiful church (Peter and Paul church) and slavic cemetary (Dvorak is buried here). There are lovely views from the south walls, and the park is nice for a picnic or stroll. It is a bit of a hike on the metro, however, so be prepared.

Vysehrad – Oasis of Peace and Beauty. I stayed in Lida Guest House within walking distance from Vysehrad, which used to be the seat of the Czech kings, and decided to do a walking tour of the area. I am a student of history and enjoyed entering the ancient fortifications via the ornate Leopold Gate. I saw the pretty tiny “Ave Maria” chapel and walked on to see the remains of the baths of Libuse which was a defence bastion.I walked through the National Cemetery with its decorative grave stones and Slavin, or Pantheon. The cemetery is peaceful and very lovely. I do not normally visit cemeteries but this one was really special as was St. Peter’s tiny beautiful cemetery in Salzburg.I walked through Vysehrad’s gardens with its huge statues and benches on which to relax, and enjoy the view. I walked to the Casements and saw the Cihelma (Brick) Gate which is an entrance to tunnels that goes underneath the ramparts.I had a wonderful view of the New City portion of Prague and from another vantage point I had a panoramic view of the Vltava river with its boats and bridges. It was a quiet and restful time away from the tourist "hordes" one finds at the main attractions. I enjoyed the exterior view of the 11th century Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, which dominates Vyšehrad, and took pictures of it but was disappointed that it was closed at the time of my visit.I left Vysehrad via the Tabor gate and took the metro (one stop) to the guest house where I was staying, having enjoyed my visit to Vysehrad.

A Historic site not to be missed in Prague when you have surplus time. Vyšehrad is a serene place to have a walk around and enjoy a panaromic view of the elegant city underneath-Prague. The park gives you a very comprehensive account of the monarchic story behind this historic city and its very archaic in design. If you are hungry after walking long, try the Thai restaurant just nearby (the metro side) .Avoid rainy days and tired moods as you have to walk a lot.If you have a surplus time after getting high and boozing is over this place is not a bad one to visit and get some fresh air and feel.

Stunning view on Prague. Vysehrad is a castle located in the city of Prague. It is one of the oldest monuments in Prague, built in the 10th century. For some time, it competed with the Prague Castle over the official seat of Czech kings. Vysehrad was built on a hill over the Vltava river. It is one of the monuments that you see from any place in Prague. Despite its excellent location, it does not get the attention of other sightseeing places such as the Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, Old Town Square etc. It offers a great view on Prague, an impressive basilica and a cemetery, containing the remains of many famous Czech people. There is a nice café with normal prices. Vysehrad is actually one of the spots where Czech people go for a romantic walk or a meeting. We, Praga Medica, recommend Vysehrad to our customers as it offers a nice relaxing place after their laser eye surgery or any other medical procedure. Vysehrad is easily accessible by metro line C. It is approximately 500 metres from the metro station.

See a peaceful side of Prague. Vysehrad was one of my best experiences in Prague. Easily accessible via tram and metro. A gorgeous swath of gardens, churches, gates, monuments, and cemeteries. Amazing views of Prague. Far from the tourist throng, a time to relax and enjoy the incredible beauty of Prague.

Good for peaceful walks and great views of Prague. We were recommended Vysehrad by a Prague local and it turned out to be a really nice place to visit. There is a metro station at Vysehrad and its only a short walk to the entrance to the fortified centre. You can walk around most of the walls whilst getting superb views of Prague. The park is pretty and peaceful (and has many red squirrels) and the graveyard is a worth a visit to see the superbly adorned graves.

Peacefully Impressive. When I visited Prague with my wife our hotel, Corinthia Towers, was located a short walk from this site. We decided to talk a walk around on the last day of our stay. We're glad we did.It's a lovely area with nice views and some interesting statues. Vysehrad Cemetery is also worth a visit, the tombstones are amazing (I'm not a big fan of graveyards but this one was very interesting).

Deserves more attention. As far as I could understand this is first settlement in Prague from which they moved to Hradcany. This is a very peaceful place with an amazing view from the top. I think this place deserves more attention, it is a must see in Prague, much more interesting than the Jewish neighborhood. I was there an a Monday, I am guessing that on weekends it could be very crowded by the locals. Take the Metro C and then return by Tram#17 along the river. Entrance fee to the Basilica Minor is 30Kc.

Great lookout. You're mainly going here for the views. There's a walk around the top of the old ramparts which gives you wonderful panaromic views across the city skyline. When I went here, ok it wasn't busy but there were enough people here. But I suppose on the tourism scale in Prague terms, it wasn't a big amount of people. Most were locals taking an evening walk.There's some green park areas too, a graveyard and gift shops. It's not that hard to get to, just get the Metro to Vysehrad. When you come out of the station, the motorway should be on your right and some office buildings on your left. Keep walking straight and you will eventually reach the old ramparts and the historic site, which you will turn right into, under the old gates. It's about a 5-10 minute walk.It's a great place to go to have some time to yourself, have a look across the city in the afternoon, take a few pictures and walk.

Very quiet and more goods views. There is not much to see at Vysherad. There are some ruins and more modern buildings. The real reason to go there is for the views. The fort overlooks the Vltava and offers excellent views to the South, West, and North. Be warned that there is significant climbing and lots of stairs. If you do go I recommend walking down the East bank of the river and past the dancing house.

quiet part of Prague. This is the place to relax. Take Metro to Vysehrad (on yellow line), walk across the square, and you'll get to Vysehrad.It is quiet place, you don't see many tourist there because it is not in the centre. There are beautiful views over Prague, you can visit the cemetary where are famous 'dead' Czech people or you can visit the Church (close between noon-1PM), or just walk in the park and enjoy the views. On your way back there is a restaurant (on the left side of the road just before the entry arch) where in the summer the do barbecues for very good prices (Steak - 80 KC, beer - 20 KC...etc)On the last picture (with the bridge), you can see the tall building. So it is a hotel Corintia Towers and next to it is Vysehrad Underground station.
